PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. How does the Government reconcile the statement on page 42 of the report of the Interdepartmental Committee on Economic Strategy released by the Treasurer last year that 'Since 1975-76 . . . the overall burden of taxation (as a proportion of GDP) has increased' with the statement by the Prime Minister on 21 August 1981 to the Tasmanian Liberal Party State Council that 'Statements that the overall burden of taxation on Australians has increased since 1975 are totally misleading.'? Is the Government being misled by its top level advisers? If so, what does it intend to do about the source of such misleading advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sought to make the point on a number of occasions that if anyone were to judge appropriately the full burden on the people of Australia as a result of the Government's expenditure decisions, it would be necessary to take into account not only the burden of taxation but also the deficits that have to be paid for. Therefore, a very real measure of the burden that governments are imposing upon taxpayers and upon the citizens of this country comes when we look at the cents out of every dollar produced that are spent by respective governments.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the six years of this Government we have reduced by around 2 1/2 cents in every dollar produced the proportion of national income-gross domestic product- taken by government. If we put that into current day terms, it would amount to $ 3,700m in the course of a year. In other words, if we were spending the same proportion out of every dollar produced as Labor did in 1975, we would be spending $3,700m more and that would be about $600m for every taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —$600m for every taxpayer?

—The figure would be $600 for every taxpayer, $3,700m overall. I thank the honourable gentleman for the correction. It is no good honourable gentlemen looking just at the tax burden when the tax was just not meeting the bills of government. The deficits have to be paid for and it is the claim on the total resources of the nation made by governments that is of concern to individuals in this community.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL INQUIRY INTO WAGES AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the House of the reasons for the decision at last Friday's Premiers Conference to abandon the national inquiry into wages and industrial relations? Is the Minister negotiating with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, employer groups and State governments to resolve difficulties which would have been discussed at such an inquiry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the honourable gentleman that a great many discussions went on with the employers, through the Confederation of Australian Industry, and with the unions, through the ACTU, in advance of the Premiers Conference held last Friday. In fact, the last of the discussions that I had with the employer and the union groups was at the National Labour Consultative Council meeting on 5 February. I am sure the House would appreciate that if the national inquiry was to have been a success then it would have needed the full-blooded co -operation and support of the principal parties involved in industrial relations -the employer groups on one side and the unions on the other. Of course, the States have a very direct role to play through their constitutional responsibilities in this field of industrial relations and one of the critical questions would have been the division of constitutional power between the States and the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: As we know, the ACTU said publicly, following an executive meeting late last year, that it was directing its affiliates not to participate and that the ACTU itself would not participate. Of course, that was a matter of great concern to the Government. I held private discussions and continued my discussions with the ACTU at that last NLCC meeting. The employers had said that they would participate, but they had always had reservations about the inquiry's practical outcome. When the matter came before the States last Friday the States recognised the long-term nature, of necessity, of the inquiry. They recognised that we could not hope to get a report within, say, two years, that there would then have to be another process of consultation and that then the political consideration of it would have to be gone through. So everybody was facing the prospect that it could be three or four years before any meaningful outcome could be seen. Anyone who has worked in this field of industrial relations knows how difficult it is to get change and reform in the system.

So the Premiers decided that they would look to more immediate proposals that could be examined to produce more immediate changes. The States and the Commonwealth have agreed to look at demarcation disputes, which I think everybody recognises are matters of grave concern to the community; at the maritime and waterfront industry, where we need to get together with the parties directly involved to see whether we can improve in a much more immediate and direct way the state of industrial relations; and at the divided jurisdictions between the Commonwealth and the States in a way which would produce a complementary industrial relations system in Australia where there is much more consistency and cohesion between the Federal and the State jurisdictions.

On that basis the Premiers, in an atmosphere of a much greater sense of urgency -if I might say so-than we have experienced before, have asked the State Ministers for Labour, together with myself, at their next meeting on 4 March to tackle these problems urgently, to appoint a working party and to report to the Premiers Conference in June. I can inform the honourable member for Kooyong that a great deal of discussion went on before the decision was made at the Premiers Conference to abandon the inquiry and that there is a sense of urgency being brought to bear on key areas of industrial relations to bring about some immediate change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. It follows the answer he gave to the question from the honourable member for Macquarie a few minutes ago in which he claimed that the most reliable guide of government's claim on resources is the level of taxation plus deficit. Is it a fact that as a proportion of gross domestic product the level of taxation plus the deficit under Labor was 25 .6 per cent, but under the present Government has been 26.3 per cent-much higher ? Is it, however, more significant to recognise that under his Government there have been massive transfers of responsibilities from the Budget to government authorities and to the States? Is it therefore, in a sensible economic way, more proper to look at the total public sector size under the Fraser Government compared with that under the Labor Government? If one does that, is it a fact that the average public sector proportion of gross domestic product under Labor was a little over 35 per cent, that under the Fraser Government it has averaged 38.6 per cent, and that documents supplied with the Budget make it clear that it will be nearly 40 per cent this year? In those circumstances will the Prime Minister more accurately and creditably address himself to reliable economic indicators rather than manufacturing spurious claims?

—I doubt whether many people following the honourable gentleman would be able to stay with him in relation to the figures. The plain fact remains that over the last six years the Commmonwealth has reduced its claim on resources from between 30c and 31c in the dollar--
—This is a totally dishonest claim.
—If the honourable gentleman does not wish to have an answer, he need not have an answer.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker. The public sector, because of the way--
—The Leader of the Opposition will state his point of order.
—Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister is giving--
—The honourable gentleman will refer me to the standing order under which he is taking his point of order.
—Well, you do not expect us to sit here and listen to this fictitious nonsense that the Prime Minister manufactures. It is totally dishonest.

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I allowed the honourable gentleman to make what really was a statement rather than ask a question. He knows that the Standing Orders ought not to permit that. However, he was allowed to state it in silence and I would ask him therefore to extend the same courtesy to the Prime Minister when he gives an answer.

—Is the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs aware of the sometimes unfair disparity in the price of petrol in the States of Australia? Realising the difficulty in overcoming this problem, will the Minister be in a position to release the findings of the committee set up by him to look into this real problem facing the motorists of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Franklin is a great supporter of the industry and is a person who has taken a considerable interest in it. In fact, of all the members in the House, he is one who takes a particular interest in this industry . Because of that, I have here this morning the figures in relation to the States' taxes that are applied to the justified price by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. They are probably worth noting because they add to the consumer price: Sydney, 2.0c a litre; Adelaide, 1.33c a litre; Perth, 1.60c a litre; Hobart, 1.75c a litre; and Melbourne, 2.05c a litre. These prices add considerably to the consumer price to which the honourable member referred.

ANSWER.PARA: On top of that, because of the anxiety among many motorists as to the pricing policies pursued by the oil companies, the consumer affairs Ministers in Australia have asked that a report be prepared to see whether some rationality can be brought to prices in this area.

It is well known to all honourable members that the Commonwealth has no control over retail prices. We have an influence over only the wholesale price, and that is the price to which the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority directs its judgment. I hope that when this report is made available-it certainly will be-it will be considered by all State Ministers and we will be able to see what we can do in relation to helping the vexatious problems.

In the short term I can say only that the variations in prices of petrol in Australia depend very much on the competition from site to site. In some areas competition is keen, which brings about discounting, and in other areas where competitors are few and far between a very high price is frequently charged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really believe that?
—I do. It is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TREATMENT OF JEWS IN THE SOVIET UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of the harsh and cruel treatment by authorities of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics of the Jewish minority in the Soviet Union? Is he aware that the Soviet Government is deliberately discouraging Jews from leaving the Soviet Union? What action can the Australian Government take in regard to this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of and is deeply concerned by the Soviet Union's continuing violation of human rights in its treatment of its Jewish population. A particular cause for concern is the very marked decline in the number of Jews allowed to emigrate. It has declined from an average of over 4,000 a month in 1979 to several hundred a month recently. Those figures do not reflect any significant change in the numbers of Jews wishing to leave, but rather a deliberate obstruction by that government of Jewish emigration. This obstruction has been accompanied by intensive harassment of Jews applying for exit visas and the number of rejected applicants has increased considerably. Some have been tried on false charges and sent to prison and labour camps.

ANSWER.PARA: At a time when the Soviet Union is participating in international conferences dealing with the Helsinki Accords, this violation of human rights is even more noteworthy. There is a continuing suppresion of Jewish religious and cultural expression. This occurs against a background of hostile propaganda in the Soviet media. The Government is in full accord with the United States Government's strenuous efforts in negotiations with the Soviet Union to allow free emigration of Jews and others who wish to leave the Soviet Union. The Soviet Government's actions in this regard are totally unacceptable to everyone concerned with human rights and, indeed, must be condemned. They are among the factors inhibiting an improvement in relations between the Soviet Union and the United States and its Western allies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that over the last six years Commonwealth recurrent grants to the Prime Minister's old school, Melbourne Grammar, have increased threefold from $180,000 a year to over three quarters of a million dollars this year? Has the Prime Minister been personally responsible for the fact that funds going to wealthy schools such as Melbourne Grammar have increased at twice the rate of those going to the most needy Catholic schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis of the honourable member's question is quite inaccurate. The question that he has put this morning in relation to the funding of non- government schools indicates that he is not aware of the basis on which the Commonwealth provides recurrent funds to the non-government schools. So I take this opportunity to inform him of the facts. The Commonwealth Government has a firm policy on both needs and freedom of choice. We believe that a parent should have the right in this country to determine to which school he or she sends his or her children. We believe that in relation to needs schools should be appropriately funded. So in the schools where the resources are greater than they are in other schools-that is, what we call group 1-the Commonwealth provides a basic grant of 20 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a government school. I emphasise that figure. The Commonwealth provides only 20 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a government school.

ANSWER.PARA: In the next group, which is group 2 covering schools with lesser resources as measured by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and not measured in an arbitrary way by the Government, the Commonwealth provides 30 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a government school. In the lower resource levels are the type of school to which the honourable member referred, the Catholic parish schools. I emphasise that some 85 per cent or 90 per cent of children attending non-government schools are grouped into the group 3 area. Those schools will receive this year 38 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a government school. Next year, 1983, the Government will increase its support for those children to 40 per cent.

So it is quite wrong to suggest that the children attending schools in group 1 are receiving more support than are the children attending schools in group 3. I have indicated that for group 1 it is 20 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a government school and that this year for group 3 it is 38 per cent. I wanted to make that point very clear. I also take the opportunity to indicate that the Commonwealth and State governments throughout Australia accept full responsibility for educating children in government schools. On average it is costing the taxpayer about $1,700 a year to educate a child in a government school. Commonwealth and State governments together provide roughly only half that amount on average to children attending non-government schools.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BUILDING SOCIETIES: TRUSTEE STATUS FOR DEPOSITS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware that Victoria has recently granted trustee status to deposits with building societies? Will this initiative have any likely effect on the amount of money available through such traditional housing loan sources? Are there lessons for other States in this Victorian initiative?

—I understand from Press reports that the Victorian Government has given effect to a proposal to grant trustee status to investments in permanent building societies in that State. I will make only two comments on that. It underlines the fact that this is essentially a matter for the States and that the control and responsibility for building societies, which are major home lenders, are in fact State matters and State policies can have a very direct bearing upon the operation of institutions of that kind. I believe that the conferring of trustee status will have some beneficial effect on the permanent building societies' capacity to lend for housing. It is difficult to put a figure on it but I do not think there is any doubt that it will have a beneficial effect. Quite obviously, if that is the case other parts of Australia , including those States that do not have trustee status, which I understand to be Queensland and New South Wales, might well examine the matter. That is, of course, a matter for those States to determine. I say also to the honourable gentleman that I understand building societies in the Australian Capital Territory do not have trustee status. As a result of the honourable gentleman's question I will have a talk with my colleague, the Minister for the Capital Territory, about that matter-without, of course, wishing to pre-judge it.

—I ask the Prime Minister: Did the Queensland Premier recently tell the Prime Minister of his intention to offer Queensland Aborigines leases, on so-called 'good terms', for the reserve land on which they now live? Is the Prime Minister aware of a recent statement made by Mr Bjelke-Petersen that he had informed the Prime Minister of his plans during last week's Premiers Conference and that the Prime Minister had replied: 'That suits us. That sounds pretty good.' Is the Prime Minister concerned that such a leasehold scheme is in direct conflict with the wishes of most Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland, as advised to and by every Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and every relevant committee of this Parliament? Does his reported answer to Mr Bjelke-Petersen make inoperative repeated assurances from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that a new land tenure scheme would be worked out in close consultation with Queensland Aborigines? If not, what consultations are planned? Who will choose the participants, and how?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has advised me on a number of occasions that the proposals of the Queensland Government seem to be acceptable against the principles that the Minister has enunciated on a number of occasions. He indicated that he thought that the negotiations within Queensland were proceeding in a constructive manner. I conveyed that advice to the Premier. I have no idea of what he might have said subsequently, but obviously the proof of the matter will be in the final decisions that Queensland announces. I asked the Premier when these matters would be finalised. He indicated that he thought that decisions would be made shortly. Once the matter is fully public, obviously it can be debated.

—I ask the Minister for Transport: Will legislation be introduced in this session to appropriate funds for the next three years of the five-year road funding program? In view of the cost escalation since the present level of funding was determined, will consideration be given to restoring funding levels to overcome the very serious problem of road needs, encompassing traffic capacity needs, transport costs and road safety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Cowper for asking the question, particularly in view of the fact that a very large number of local government representatives are meeting at the Lakeside Hotel in Canberra at this very minute. The Minister for Industry and Commerce has just returned from opening the conference at the Lakeside. I have just had a quick word with him and he advises me that it is a very impressive gathering. They have an extensive agenda before them.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is, in fact, giving consideration to the next three-year funding program for roads. The honourable gentleman will recall that in 1980 we announced a five-year funding program for roads, allocating $3,650m for that purpose. Of course, we have passed two pieces of legislation in this Parliament to appropriate two years of funding up to the end of this financial year.
The Government will be looking at the construction cost indexes that have been produced by the Bureau of Transport Economics and also by the Treasury in association with the Bureau of Statistics.

I assure the honourable gentleman that we will take note of the resolutions that are carried at the conference today. We will also be taking into account such things as the escalation of construction costs that has occurred in the road area. I cannot pre-empt or commit the Government to any extension of the amount promised but the resolutions and the views of local government will be taken into consideration when we are drafting legislation for 1982-83 and the two successive years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister and refer to his repeated assertions that household disposable income has increased by almost $3 billion over the past year. Is it a fact that the share of household disposable income in national income has fallen from 69.3 per cent in 1975-76 to 68.4 per cent in 1980-81. Does this fall in the disposable income share represent a loss from households of $1,200m per year? If so, and recognising that the deduction of higher income taxes is the cause of this loss, when will the Government take steps to hand back to the people the $1,200m per annum which they have lost under the Government's high tax policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable gentleman has missed a very cardinal point. National income goes not only to wage and salary earners but also to profits and to welfare. One of the tasks--
—You don't understand what you are talking about, with the greatest of respect.
—The Leader of the Opposition will remain silent. I ask him to extend ordinary courtesies of the Parliament and to cease interjecting.
—He is just making a fool of himself.
—The Leader of the Opposition again is not interested in the answer so he need not get it.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will proceed when the House comes to order.
—Ask him where his bat and ball are.
—The honourable member for Adelaide will remaint silent.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order.
—Ask him where his bat and ball are.
—The honourable member for Adelaide will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Brisbane has a point of order.
—Yes, Mr Speaker. My point of order is that I am very interested in the answer to that question. Is it fair for the Prime Minister to deny this information to the House and the people of Australia?
—The Prime Minister is entitled to answer as he chooses.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade and Resources. What action can the Government take to counter the French Government's proposal to increase European farm support prices by 16 per cent this year? Will the British Government oppose such a rise, to his knowledge? Would such a rise be disastrous for Australia's exports of beef, dairy products, sugar, fruit and other products into third markets where European surplus production is dumped?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —The price support scheme being used in Europe in association with the Common Agricultural Policy has been of concern to agricultural countries around the world. The high consumer price--
—I take a point of order. Could I ask that the Minister speak into the microphone. We cannot hear him.
—The Minister is addressing his answer to the question. I ask the officers in the broadcasting booth to raise the volume of the sound reinforcement system.

—The high consumer prices, plus the intervention subsidies, have been a major incentive to increasing production within Europe. The situation has changed so much over the last 10 years that today Europe, instead of being an importer of many agricultural commodities, is one of the largest exporters of many major agricultural commodities. It is the world's largest exporter of dairy products. Last year it was the world's largest exporter of sugar and a major exporter of beef and grain. It has completely distorted the world trade pattern in agricultural commodities. Just recently the Commission of the European Communities recommended to the Council of Ministers that there be approximately a 9 per cent increase in domestic prices and an increase of about 6 1/2 per cent to 7 per cent on cereals, cereals being the one exception. However, France has proposed that there ought to be a 16 per cent increase in domestic prices. This is contrary to the point of view of the Commission and certainly some of the other member countries. Yesterday I had the opportunity of talking to the British Minister of State for Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. He assured me that Britain would not go along with the suggestion of a much higher price which is being recommended by the Commission because it could see the deleterious effect that was resulting from the ever increasing consumer and intervention supports being given to agriculture and from the accumulation of surplus stocks. So I have to say that I think the only way in which we are ever going to get any changes to the Common Agricultural Policy of accumulating these surpluses is by airing our points of view, registering concern and hoping that that might place some moral persuasion on them to try to alter policies that are having such serious effects on many countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that the granny bond scheme outlined by the Victorian Minister for Housing, Mr Kennett, this week depends heavily on the Federal Government agreeing to legislate to provide for tax deductibility of interest rates? Since this involves a major commitment by the Commonwealth Government with far broader implications than housing policy, will the Prime Minister state what consultation, if any, he has had with his State colleagues on this important matter? Has the Commonwealth Government agreed to support the Victorian Government by immediately introducing legislation for such tax deductibility? If not, why not?

QUESTION.PARA: The honourable member continuing to ask his question-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. The last part of the question is out of order but the first part was in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the Premiers Conference last week the Commonwealth put the point of view that there are two sides to the present problems of people paying off home loans or wishing to gain a home loan and to establish themselves in their own houses. One involves the availability of money for house lending and the other involves the price at which that money can in fact be lent. It is important to understand the nature and the extent of the problem. It is a very important one for a number of people within the Australian community. People who took out home loans five or six years ago and have been paying them off ever since are, on the figures shown to me, better off than they would have been when they first took out the loan. People who have taken out a loan within the last two or three years could be in a quite different position because their houses have not appreciated in value so much and they have been hit more by the higher interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: In discussing these matters with the States it became apparent that the States had not given a great deal of consideration to the implications of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System for State savings banks and for permanent building societies. These are two traditional avenues of substantial lending for home purchasers, as the honourable gentleman would know. Therefore, the Commonwealth put it to the States that they should see what they would want to do or thought should be done to achieve a greater flow of funds for house lending purposes. This is what the States are meeting about today.

I also indicated to the Victorian Premier yesterday that it is my understanding that some of the building societies lend for purposes other than home purchase and that merely restricting permanent building societies to lending for home purchase would in part increase the capital flows available for that purpose. I would be expecting to hear from the Victorian Premier, and I suspect from other Premiers, after today. I do not know what they are going to put forward but I hope they will have some positive and constructive proposals and suggestions to make. I think the matter had better rest until we have heard from the Victorian Government or from other Premiers, if they wish to tell us what they believe ought to be done about instrumentalities that are established under State law and within their charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware that I now represent Australia's most populated electorate and that three of Australia's largest electorates, namely, Fadden, Fisher and McPherson, are contained in Queensland's south-east corner? Is the Minister aware that every month thousands of Australians are shifting to Queensland and that the ability of Telecom Australia to meet the demand associated with this growth appears to have slipped further and further behind? Will the Minister intervene and cause a further shift to Queensland of Telecom's development programs? If he can satisfy himself, as I am satisfied, that more capital expenditure is necessary, will he permit Telecom to meet what has become a screaming need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, initially, before I respond to the honourable gentleman' s question, may I extend a welcome to Australia to Mr Zhang Xiang Shan, who is the Director of the Chinese Broadcasting Association, and his delegation who are sitting in the diplomatic gallery.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to my colleague the honourable member for Fadden, I think it will be interesting if I repeat to the House something of the way in which Telecom has been expanding its capital program to meet the very real needs , not only in the honourable gentleman's electorate but also in the adjacent area of Queensland, in which I am told the population is growing possibly at an even greater rate than it is in the honourable gentleman's electorate. Indeed, this year Telecom plans to spend about $5m more than it spent last year on capital works in that region. It has increased its staff by some 34 per cent. On the technical side, in that part of Queensland it has increased its staff by 44 per cent. In addition, an engineering group comprising five engineers and nine support staff controlled by a supervising engineer is moving to the Gold Coast to try to ensure that that region of Queensland does get an improvement in the services which, regrettably, seem to have suffered both from growth in traffic in the Telecom system and, of course, growth in demand for new phones as a result of the population explosion. Knowing the interest of my colleague the honourable member for Richmond, I do not doubt that that demand will spread south of the border as well.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a problem in particular areas of Australia. That is one such area. There are other areas on the western side of Sydney and in some regions north of Brisbane where there are greater than normal demands. Telecom is endeavouring to meet those demands by expanding its capital program wherever it feels it desirable to do so. For that purpose the Government has reconsidered the available capital funds that should be spent by Telecom this year. The Government has decided that from the available funds of Telecom, without increasing its demand in the public area generally-that is, its borrowings-it will permit Telecom to spend on capital works an additional $20m above that which it had previously allocated. It is hoped that, as a result in the honourable gentleman's electorate and, I might add, other electorates around Australia, there will be an improvement in telecommunications services for the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his responsibility to ensure the satisfactory performance of his Ministers. Has his attention been drawn to the results of a survey of employers published in the December 1981 issue of the publication Inside Trade Unions, which contains new evidence of the unsuitability of the Minister for Industrial Relations to hold that office? It has been shown that only 3 per cent of employers consider that the Minister's performance has been all right, 40 per cent say that it has been poor and 56 per cent say that it has been terrible. In the light of that new evidence, will the Prime Minister take steps to relieve the Minister for Industrial Relations of this sensitive portfolio as part of a constructive attempt to improve industrial relations in this country?
—If the honourable gentleman wants to continue to bemuse himself with polls, he can live in his own fairyland.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Resources and is supplementary to the question asked by the honourable member for Macarthur. Is Australia's capacity to effect moral persuasion with the European Economic Community affected by Australia's own import barriers? Has the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Council just left the way open for the EEC to remove some of the trade preference that it grants Australia in retaliation against protection afforded our motor car and footwear industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid we still have a lot to learn from the EEC regarding restrictions on trade. As to the reference to the submission that was made this week to the GATT Council, this is a result of a protest that the EEC lodged against certain import safeguard arrangements that we have implemented for motor cars and footwear. It is not a new issue. It has been going on for a substantial period. It is a matter of interpretation of Article 19 of the GATT regarding the application of safeguards. We have been defending our approach and we believe we have support for the action that we have taken being quite legitimate under the GATT. The Council of GATT decided-in the interests of harmony, I suggest-that the matter be deferred for another month to see whether the contesting partners could come to some resolution. I might add that we are also engaged in another action in GATT regarding the EC policy on the dumping of sugar on third markets. We have estimated that the EC's subsidised exports are costing the Australian sugar industry somewhere between $80m and $120m a year.
—How much?

—Between $80m and $120m a year, and that has been going on for some years. So Australia will certainly be to the forefront in lodging its complaints and it has no embarrassment as to the action it might have taken to protect some of its own industries.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) agreed to:
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 9 March 1982, at 1.45 p.m . unless Mr Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

DEBATE.TITLE: QUESTION TIME: REFERENCE TO STANDING ORDERS COMMITTEE

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition has indicated that he wishes to raise a matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to move a motion referring certain matters to the Standing Orders Committee. I have provided the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) with a copy of the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Orders Committee for examination, report and recommendation:
The standing orders and practices which govern the conduct of question time, taking particular account of:

(1) The definition of relevancy in answers to questions and the setting out of criteria to define relevancy in accordance with legal definition. (Example, Stephen's definition in the Digest of the Lawo of Evidence 12th Edition. 'Any two facts to which it is applied are so related to each other that according to the common course of events one either taken by itself or in connection with other facts proves or renders probable the past, present, or future existence or non-existence of the other').
(2) Length of answers to be subject to a time limit.
(3) The need for clearer definition in the standing orders about the practice in relation to supplementary questions.
(4) Senators who are ministers to attend the House to answer questions.
(5) The appropriateness of setting down specified sitting days as days on which questions will be directed to ministers about particular departments.
(6) Question Time to be a minimum of 45 minutes.
At this point I propose to address myself very shortly to these proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the honourable gentleman does that, I direct his attention to item (3) 'Supplementary questions to be allowed'. I suggest that he may wish to consider giving greater definition to that itme because 'supplementary' may not necessarily mean 'consecutive supplementary', which is what I think the honourable gentleman has in mind.
—Perhaps if I altered it to read, 'The need for clearer definition in the Standing Orders about the practice in relation to supplementary questions'.
—Yes, so that the direction to the Standing Orders Committee is clearer concerning what the honourable gentleman is moving.
—'Supplementary' in parliamentary terms would mean ' consecutively'.

—No. That is a point that I want to take up. If I may address myself to these points, the first thing I would say is that Question Time, like just about every other aspect, if not every other aspect, of parliamentary procedure has become debased to the stage of being pretty much meaningless to the administration of the affairs of this country. One feels some discomfort in acknowledging that, but if one is candid one has to. What is happening is that in this Parliament very little information is transacted between either side of the House at Question Time. In the course of debate, I have yet to recall an instance, in more than two decades in this place, where the opinion held by either side has been altered. The nature of the political debate has reached a stage now where it is more important to make a point and to establish it to the public. I suggest that, if that is what the parliamentary chamber now is, as I believe is the case, it would be better if we respectively, in our parties, set up our own communications booths and spent most of our time there trying to communicate to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: If, on the other hand, we take the potential of this chamber seriously, as I do -I believe that it can be reformed in important ways-there is an overwhelming case for demanding that, with the greatest urgency, we proceed to explore ways in which we can improve the Standing Orders.

Mr Speaker, obviously you harbour concern about this because I noted this week in the newspapers an account of an address which you delivered. Although I do not agree with the conclusions that you have arrived at, vis-a-vis a change in the nature of the political institution to something more akin to a presidential one, I do acknowledge nonetheless very big changes are taking place and a momentum developing more by default than otherwise, and therefore lacking direction, which I suspect could take us into altogether the wrong sort of area, the wrong sort of system of operation.

It has been said that the institution of Parliament is a Samson within the democratic system. I suggest that we have shorn the hair of that Samson by the way in which this institution functions. For my part, I genuinely extend to you considerable sympathy, in spite of the rather terse observations I have made from time to time. You do have difficulty in handling the proceedings of this House because of deficiencies in the Standing Orders.

I focus my attention very quickly, therefore, on the motion that I have put before the House. It is restricted to an area which, at least at the moment, is the most vexatious. I refer to Question Time. The first point I put forward is the need for definition of relevancy. I suggest that perhaps it ought to be in accordance with legal definition. Perhaps it should not be. Perhaps that is too precise, too rigid and stultifying for the more free flowing exchange and expression that should take place here. However, I think we could do without some of the robustness that we have seen in recent times. Some of that robustness comes forward in response to the irrelevancy of answers given at Question Time. What the deuce is the good of asking a very seriously contrived question-contrived in the sense of representing some serious research-about, say , taxation and then getting an answer about jam? That is about the level of many of the answers we obtain in the Parliament. Cheap point scoring in the course of giving answers bearing no relationship to either the question or indeed to the facts of a particular set of circumstances is calculated to provoke reaction and to interfere with the processes of business in this House. I think we need collectively to explore the relevancy of questions.

The length of answers should be subject to a time limit. I recognise that that would be extraordinarily hard to define and administer but we have now reached the situation where some Ministers are notorious for their dinner-bell type answers. As soon as they start answering a question members get up and walk to the dining room because that is more of a diversion than the tedium of listening to these endless dissertations that produce very little.

I mention, then, the need for a clearer definition in the Standing Orders about the practice in relation to supplementary questions. I believe that should be seen in association with my fifth point, which is the appropriateness of setting down specified sitting days as days on which questions will be directed to Ministers about particular departments. I believe there is a need for supplementary questions. That does not necessarily mean consecutive questions from one side of the House and not one question from this side of the House, one from the other side of the House and then a different question again from this side, as we have now, but a question and a supplementary question from this side of the House where the person who has asked the question in order of call declares that he wants later to ask a supplementary question. That is a much more effective way in which to extract relevant information which is of benefit to the community.

Another role of Question Time in this institution is to ensure that Ministers are in fact in charge of their departments, that they do know the business they are conducting as administrators. That is important to the Parliament and to the public. It is no less important to the Prime Minister who must be assured that his Ministers are in command of the responsibilities which have been allocated to them. So, I suggest as a critical part of a strengthened parliamentary proceeding that, if my proposal were accepted, on certain specified sitting days questions would be directed to Ministers about particular departments, because then we would be moving somewhat akin to the House of Commons procedure in relation to Question Time when there are a series of follow-up questions. Nothing is more directed towards establishing the competence of a Minister and the degree to which he is in charge of his department than that. Honourable senators who are Ministers ought to attend the House to answer questions. It is unproductive to ask questions in this House about departments which are administered by Ministers in the Senate. I believe this House is as much entitled to information about departments administered by Ministers in the other House as we are entitled to information from Ministers who are seated here.

Finally, the sixth point concerns the duration of Question Time being a minimum of 45 minutes. I do not believe that the length of Question Time is a matter that should be dependent on the mood of the Prime Minister or the Leader of the House on any given day. I do not believe, for instance, that if a Prime Minister -God forbid that this should be in any way interpreted as referring to any living person-were in a surly mood on one occasion because Question Time had not been going his way and he withdrew like a pained Mr Ichabod, that Question Time should immediately fold up. I do not believe that at all. I believe it is a right of the Parliament, not of one or two people, even if, for the time being, they happen to be the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House, or whatever.

Mr Speaker, this motion is put forward in the spirit of constructiveness. It is a response to the tensions, the controversy and the disruption which have occurred in the Parliament since this Parliament resumed. It has sat for merely a fortnight. The experiences, however, are not isolated to this parliamentary session. They have been evident over the past several years. More than that, it is clear that the sort of resentment that has been evident-the tempo and level of it-has been welling up to much higher pitches in more recent times because of the way in which Question Time is falling apart.

I repeat, Mr Speaker, that this is in no way directed as a criticism or a censure of you. I repeat what I said earlier: You preside over, often, an extraordinarily difficult situation and in circumstances in which Standing Orders do need considerable shoring up to give you indisputable authority to direct the course of the affairs in this House most effectively and efficiently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion. I think everybody in the House would agree that there is room for much improvement in Question Time. That is no reflection on anybody. Questions are not answered and there is a great deal of difficulty in getting this definition of relevance. I just address your mind to the fact that if questions are to be asked there must be criteria to be followed. There are 12 inhibitions or restrictions placed on the asking of questions. For example, questions must not contain arguments, imputations, epithets or ironical expressions. But we can get all of them in the answers. The school children's judgment of this House last week was that 'it is a disaster'. They are right, not because of attempts that were made to obtain information but because of the low grade vaudeville which often takes place to score points. For example, questions asked last week might have been related to tax or inflation but we got answers about what happened under the Whitlam Government, what is happening in New South Wales or what should happen in Tasmania. They had nothing to do with what was asked.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very clear that we can get a definition of relevance. It has a legal definition. It is a question of facts being related to each other. If there is to be some clear ascertainment of what is sought in the question, the answer ought to relate to the question and to nothing else. Other parliaments are able to do this, and I think it can certainly be developed here.

It would not be difficult to allow the asking of supplementary questions. They would be asked immediately after the answer was given. This happens in other parliaments. They must relate to the previous answer and, of course, there would have to be an allowance made by way of discount so that honourable members on one side did not keep asking supplementary questions all the time. One supplementary question could be asked from one side but then two questions would have to be asked from the other side if that were the way it was to be done. Question Time should certainly continue for 45 minutes. But if the time allocated for Question Time is rationed, then also the time for the question and the time for the answer must be within reasonable limits. Usually 12 questions are asked in the 45 minutes.

All of these things can be readily looked at. I think the matter just requires an understanding that we are here to seek information and also to give it to the public and to the media. It does us no good to have nothing but disarray. In the period I have been here, in my view, the disarray always eventuates from the fact that in the answers to questions Ministers are anxious to score political points. I know that is a natural aptitude of politicians, but it does nothing to help the business of the House. I think the House of Representatives Standing Orders Committee would agree that there is room for improvement. I think what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has moved is very worth while. I think it could be readily brought into operation and that it would assist you, Mr Speaker, in the administration of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Government does not oppose the reference to the Standing Orders Committee, any such support for the reference does not necessarily endorse the contents of what either the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) or the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) have said or of the motion itself. I think that if Question Time has been debased, it is not peculiarly the fault of the Standing Orders. I think that to the degree to which the behaviour of members on both sides of the House- interruptions, disruptions, refusal to comply with your directions, Mr Speaker, and so on-is not a matter which is specified within this motion, some of the cause, at least, of those schoolchildren's remarks the other day can be sourced to that, rather than to any deficiency, if such exists, within the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the contents of this reference, there are a couple of things that I would say. First, quite obviously, within this place there is a range of members with different views and attitudes as to the nature of the Standing Orders and what they should contain, particularly concerning Question Time and the procedures of Question Time. The procedure of questions without notice, as it exists in this Parliament and others around Australia, is different from those that exist in other Parliaments. It is suggested that we move down the track outlined in the motion, that is, allow supplementary questions in a form different from that now specified in Standing Order No. 151. For those honourable members who perhaps do not recall that Standing Order, I will read it out:
Questions may be asked without notice. At the discretion of the Speaker supplementary questions may be asked to elucidate an answer.

In other words, there is already within our Standing Orders the procedure and the capacity for supplementary questions to be asked. But the concept, as I understand it, being advanced by the Leader of the Opposition, relates in part to what is now specified under item 5 of this motion-that is, the appropriateness of setting down specified sitting days as days on which questions will be directed to Ministers about particular departments. In other words, there is to be a different concept of our Question Time, when questions without notice are asked, from that which is now in practice. I think it is well worth while the Standing Orders Committee and this Parliament debating that matter, and if it should be that honourable members on both sides of the House feel that that is a preferred form, so be it. But I think that we need to recognise that the concept of questions without notice, as it now exists in this Parliament, has traditionally been seen as an Australian extension of the Westminster system, with as many pluses as there are negatives. Indeed, it is worth commenting, for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition remarked on the number of questions that are asked at Question Time, that in terms of the time allocation, both when the Labor Party was in government and when the coalition parties have been in government, the Clerks religiously hand to the Leader of the House a time which gives the three-quarters of an hour which is accepted as the present limit for Question Time, or thereabouts, and the Leader of the House brings it to the Prime Minister's attention when that three-quarters of an hour has expired. Indeed, since we have been in office there have been very few occasions on which there has been less than 45 minutes allocated on any particular day for questions without notice.

Additionally, in regard to the actual form of answering questions, I know that the motion sets down some restraints, and I think that the Government of the day inevitably is concerned about any interference that there might be in the discretion which it is believed Ministers should exercise. Indeed, when in opposition the coalition parties were concerned about the then Government's responses, as the Opposition today is concerned about the present Government's responses. If one looks at the number of questions that were asked over that period, one finds that Question Time permitted far fewer questions than has come to be the practice in recent times. So if anything, the present length of ministerial answers is shorter, and perhaps the questions too, than in those earlier days. But it is not a matter of comparing past with present. It is essentially a matter of referring to the Standing Orders Committee a series of specific changes which the Leader of the Opposition has identified. The Government accepts the reference. It would hope that if honourable members on both sides of the House have other areas where they would suggest change, they will also refer those for consideration by their representatives on the Standing Orders Committee. The matter will in due course be returned from a report of the Standing Orders Committee to this place for consideration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Sinclair-I ask leave of the House to move a motion to enable Notice No. 19, General Business, to be called on forthwith.
Leave not granted.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Notice No. 19 , General Business, being called on forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes that motion. As you would appreciate, Mr Speaker, the Government is now seeking to prevent the Opposition from moving the motion of which it has given notice for today. It appears that whenever the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) decides to do anything in this House the Government takes fright. It happens to be a motion that has been on the Notice Paper since last November. It relates to unemployment.
—Fifteen months to the day.

—I am sorry, it is 15 months. That is how long ago it was put on the Notice Paper. It relates to unemployment, a matter affecting everybody in the nation. Is it because the motion is to be moved by the honourable member for Wills that the Government takes fright and says that it will not deal with it?
—Ha, ha!

—It is no laughing matter. Let us look at it. Under the Standing Orders we have a right to have General Business dealt with every second Thursday . Why has the Government suddenly decided to take the initiative and give Notice No. 19 precedence? There is nothing wrong with Notice No. 19, except that there are 18 notices ahead of it. The other factor is that this happens to be General Business day and it is set aside for specific purposes. That is the point. Surely honourable members on the Government's back bench who had a General Business motion which they could move would want it dealt with. Is it because it is an Opposition motion which is to be moved by the honourable member for Wills that it is to be done away with? Is the Government so fearful of what happened last Thursday that it does not want to see it happen again this Thursday?

SPEECH.PARA: The issue is: What is wrong with the administration of the business of this House? It is pointless for us to refer matters to the Standing Orders Committee when we disregard Standing Order 104, which states that General Business shall be called on on the day specified, that is, every second Thursday. The Government has now decided to do away with that Standing Order and no explanation has been given. We would have been delighted to hear the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) clearly indicate why Notice No. 19-I notice that it has been on the Notice Paper since December 1980-will now have precedence all of a sudden because the Government wants to have it dealt with as against a notice relating to unemployment. We would have had enough time to deal also with a motion to be moved by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) relating to technology and foreign investment and control. Are they not very important matters? The Government is going to do away with the lot.

Even the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) would be anxious to discuss unemployment. He is here, ready and willing to go but nobody will allow him to do so because the Government has decided to move the suspension of Standing Orders. Which members of the Government decided this? Did they decide it in the party room? Surely not. They would have been done in their own party room. Government supporters would not have allowed the Government to do this. Certainly we do not mind the Government giving more publicity to the honourable member for Wills. It will just mean more support for us in the electorate. It clearly indicates the Government is so worried about these matters that it does not want to discuss them here but they will be discussed outside.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's wrong, Tom, don't they want to back you?

—We will back Tom Uren any time. There are no problems with that . It is remarkable that the Leader of the House decides to support my colleague, Tom Uren, only about every three years and then without notice. I do not think it helps very much for me to have to say to my colleague 10 minutes before 10 o' clock: 'Tom, you are on'. At least I will give credit to the Leader of the House . He said: 'We want to do you a favour today, Lionel. We are going to bring on Tom Uren's motion'. How is he doing me a favour today? He is not doing Tom Uren a favour today and he is upsetting Bob Hawke. What is the Leader of the House going to do about it? I can talk about this matter in a jocular fashion but the issues are very serious. They concern unemployment, technology and Standing Order 104, which states that these matters have priority. This is their day. Why is it that the Government has the right to take away this opportunity simply because it has a thing called the numbers and it can decide to suspend Standing Orders?
—It helps.

—They certainly help but they are certainly not to be used. We went through a debate just a few minutes ago which reflected on that aspect. What about giving some stability to this Parliament? What about giving some credence to this Parliament? What about clearly indicating to the people watching us today that we want to debate something serious of which notice has been given? It is for that reason that we oppose the motion to suspend the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I will not hold the House up for long but I think what the Government is doing should be made absolutely clear to the House. The Government does not believe that Poland is sufficiently important for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) to make a statement on it. It does not believe that it is important to devote Government time to it when the Government has no business. It has decided to play political tricks and to seek to embarrass the Opposition by having the Opposition support what is its right in this Parliament, and a very limited right. Looking at the Notice Paper, we see that in the fifteenth month of this Parliament we are up to General Business Thursday No. 6. There have been six General Business days in 15 months when members who placed notices on the Notice Paper on the first day of meeting of this Parliament have had the opportunity to bring forward and debate those notices before the Parliament.
—It is No. 5, Gordon.

—My apologies; it is General Business Thursday No. 5. We have not even had No. 6 and we are not to get No. 5. The opportunity is about to be subverted. I have no objection to the House debating Poland and neither has any other member of the Opposition. In fact we would welcome the opportunity on the proper basis, that is, a full scale debate on a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs or, if necessary, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) who takes a leading role in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely the subject is important enough for this Parliament-if the statements which are being made by the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister outside the Parliament are sincere, and I would hope they are-that the Government should not play tricks on the Parliament and use its numbers for a subterfuge of this nature purely so that it can prevent an item of business which is important to the Australian nation and economy coming forward in the Parliament. No one in the Parliament knows when we last had for debate an economic statement or a statement on unemployment made by a Minister of the Parliament. The Government is seeking to pretend that unemployment does not exist. Matters relating to technology are vital to the future of this country and at the moment they are restricted in debate in this Parliament to a series of slogans, sayings and cliches. There has been no serious debate, in fact no debate at all, on these important matters. The Government motion is a fraud designed to achieve a very low-grade political purpose. If the Government is serious about wanting to debate Poland, the Opposition will facilitate it at any time the Government wishes. I suggest to the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) that he might treat the Parliament seriously by doing it in Government time.

Last year, the Parliament languished for six weeks purely to go through the exercise of meeting because the Government had no business. If we look at the Notice Paper now, it still has no business. It has no legislative program. The Government is rudderless. It does not know where it is going. Now it is resorting to subterfuge in seeking to use the Parliament to try to improve its almost desecrated political image. If the Minister is serious and if the members of the Government are serious, they will protect Government business by refusing this motion and will demand that the Government bring on debate on Poland with its proper status and importance as a Government initiated debate. It is within its competence at any time merely by changing the order of business on the Notice Paper over which the Leader of the House has total control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a piece of hypocrisy by the Government to bring on this particular motion on this day. No one denies the importance of a discussion on Poland. But let us look at the date when notice of the motion was given. It is 2 December 1980 and the motion concerns events to that point, commendation of Solidarity and noting the failure of the Press to report the Opposition's attitude; that is fair enough. But would not one think a few things had happened in Poland since 2 December 1980 that we should be talking about? Are we really to take the view that the last event in Poland of which we can reasonably take notice happened 14 months ago, and that nothing whatever worthy to be the subject of debate has happened in the last 14 months? I think the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) would be the first to concede that his motion, which was absolutely appropriate on the date when it was given, is now a bit of a period piece 14 months later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has control of business. It can bring on discussion on Poland any time it wants. I would welcome the chance to participate in a debate on Poland. I was there in November immediately before the military takeover. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) was there a couple of weeks later. I think both sides of the House would welcome an opportunity to take part in a very serious debate on it. But is shows contempt not just for the Opposition but contempt for the people of Poland to resuscitate this motion 14 months after the events it describes. The Government ought to be ashamed of itself. But given the thick hide of the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair), who is sitting at the table , I doubt whether he would feel ashamed about anything.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to amplify some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). There are in fact about five other motions on Poland on the Notice Paper all more recent than the motion proposed by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren). One was moved last week by me dealing with the contemporary situation in Poland. That motion calls on the Government to do something about food aid. Also on the Notice Paper is a motion by the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) which also deals with Poland and asks the Government to do something serious about the Polish refugee problem in Austria. There is a motion from the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) in similar terms to mine, though not asking the Government to do anything specific, but again condemning the actions of the martial law regime. These three motions deal with the contemporary Polish situation and it is that situation which ought to be discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have something like 1,000 people of Polish origin in my constituency. I want this subject to be treated properly and respectfully for them because the refugee situation, let alone the situation in Poland itself, is a serious problem for them. I now have to go back to my constituency and tell those people : 'If the Government has its way the only matters on Poland we are going to debate are those contained in a motion put on the Notice Paper 15 months ago'. I would have to say: 'I cannot get anything out of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in this House on Poland; I cannot get anything out of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in this House on Poland; I cannot say anything to you about the Government's intentions on food aid'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has never made a statement on the subject.

—That is right. I will have to say to those people: 'I cannot find out anything about the Government's intentions on credit or what its strategy is . All we can get is a debate on a motion that has been brought on not because we are concerned about you, not because we are concerned about the situation in Poland but because the Government wants to get off the Notice Paper a motion from the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) in respect of unemployment'. What a shabby way to treat the large number of people of Polish origin in this country who are most anxious to hear frequently from responsible Government spokesmen the Government's intentions in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not had a great deal of disagreement with government policy on Poland as it has emerged in dribs and drabs and bits and pieces in public discussion and what is wrung from the Minister in questions from both sides of the House. I would welcome an opportunity for all this to be brought together in some sort of coherent statement because what emerges from it might be very good and very satisfactory not only from the point of view of the Polish people in Australia but also the Polish people in Australia and Poland. We desperately need a discussion in this House on the question of Polish refugees. A very serious problem is developing in the Austrian camps. I have at least a couple of submissions before the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) to try to get people out of those camps. Those submissions have been before the Minister for three or four months but nothing has been done. I occasionally phone that area to find out whether or not the refugees have been interviewed. They have not been interviewed. There are clearly problems about processing the cases but they are not being dealt with. We cannot debate this matter if we are to stick to the terms of the motion that we will be allowed to discuss if the Government's motion is carried because that motion refers to events of 15 months ago and is related to the inadequacy of Press coverage of an Opposition protest on the question.

I think it is very important that the public in Australia-this is broadcast day so they do have an opportunity to hear what is being said-understands that this is part of a shabby trick to deny the Opposition its rights during the General Business debate of a Thursday. Some of us in the Opposition and on the Government side have motions down the line listed for hearing on general business Thursday. I have a motion on the Notice Paper that is concerned with the question of establishing a select committee to look into the question of injurious affection for citizens disadvantaged by the development of Commonwealth installations such as an installation at Perth Airport. This is a matter which has received considerable attention in a number of other countries. In Britain they have established compensation arrangements.

I have absolutely no chance of having that motion brought on for discussion in this House, even though I know that a large number of honourable members on the other side of the House would be interested in the matter because they have airports in their constituencies and that every now and then they attempt to adopt a responsible attitude in relation to airports on behalf of their constituents. The motion also relates to problems confronting the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott). I will never be able to have that motion brought on for discussion. Whenever the time to debate General Business matters arrives on a Thursday the Government has one manoeuvre or another to remove from the agenda the various motions of which Opposition honourable members have given notice and to bring on for debate, piecemeal, as it feels like it, other notices of motion appearing on the Notice Paper. This is not the appropriate motion under which to discuss Poland. There are other far more appropriate motions. This would be an appropriate time to discuss the motion of which the honourable member for Wills gave notice. Although he gave notice of the motion some time ago, the matter is still current. The situation to which it refers is even more serious now. I hope the motion before the House is defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in light of the Government view contained in the 1980-81 Budget papers that there will be no improvement this financial year in the already disastrously high level of unemployment and the consistent glossing over of this fact by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, in the opinion of this House, and as a matter of urgency, a joint committee should be established to inquire into and report on unemployment in Australia, with special reference to-
(1) the extent of unemployment and the degree to which it was become a long term problem;
(2) the degree to which unemployment bears particularly upon certain industries , regions and sectors of the workforce;
(3) the social implications of prolonged large-scale unemployment;
(4) the applicability to Australia of innovative employment creating schemes operating in other comparable countries;
(5) the extent to which unemployment could be reduced by implementing and expanding manpower programs;
(6) other means by which unemployment could be reduced, and
(7) the extent and nature of possible conflict between the objective of reducing unemployment and other policy objectives.

I gave notice of this motion exactly 15 months ago to the day. One would have hoped that the passage of time would have diminished the necessity for this House to take the action envisaged by the motion. Unfortunately, as all honourable members must recognise, this has not been the case. Unemployment has become a more pressing economic problem and a social phenomenon of potentially disastrous proportions.

Whilst the Opposition believes that the Government must bear a large measure of responsibility for this situation-and I will therefore be trenchant in criticism where that is necessary-I ask all honourable members to see the virtue of bringing together the best resources of both sides in a joint committee, as this motion urges, to study the dimensions of the problem and possible avenues towards its resolution.
