TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the House. The information contained in the table shows clearly that the extent of the unemployment, according to official Australian Bureau of Statistics survey data, has increased considerably during the 1970s and that over the six years of the Fraser Government there has been little improvement. During the last six months of 1981, for example, unemployment averaged more than 386,000 or 5.7 per cent of the labour force, compared with unemployment rates of 4.9 per cent in 1975-76 and 1.7 per cent at the start of the 1970s. This situation is unacceptable in a society that supposedly is committed to the ideal of full employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment is likely to become even worse during 1982, primarily as a result of the continuation of this Government's policies of reduced public spending and tight controls over money supply growth. The major forecasters are united in this gloomy assessment. The Melbourne University's Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research predicts unemployment of around 460,000, or 6.6 per cent, during the second half of 1982. The Victorian Chamber of Manufactures has recently predicted average unemployment of over 480,000 persons during 1982-83 and a post-war high in the unemployment rate of 7 per cent during that period. This is bad enough, but we have only one set of official unemployment figures on which to base our analysis-the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey data. It is generally acknowledged that there are deficiencies in the data base. Early last year the Government terminated the collection of Commonwealth Employment Service data on registered unemployment, which removed the only alternative perception on the overall dimensions of unemployment in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't want to know.

—Of course not. Quite apart from the magnitude of recorded unemployment , there are other aspects of the unemployment situation in Australia which add further disturbing dimensions to the real extent of unemployment but which are afforded little attention or about which we know relatively little. The long term nature of unemployment has arisen as a major feature of the unemployment situation during the second half of the 1970s. The average duration of unemployment has increased dramatically over this period. During 1981 the average duration of joblessness was almost 33 weeks and over 76,000 of our fellow Australians had been out of work for more than a year. In August 1975 the average duration of unemployment was only 13 weeks while at the start of the 1970s unemployed people, on average, could expect to be jobless for no longer than seven weeks. This situation is unlikely to change much even if job prospects improve. A recent pioneering analysis by economists Gregory and Stricker and others at the Melbourne University Institute has indicated that the major part in any increase in job opportunities is normally taken up by people coming from outside the labour force rather than from the ranks of the unemployed. The need for a further analysis of such movements is essential to an understanding of the dynamics of the labour market and in particular to the nature and magnitude of employment policies required to make substantial inroads into existing levels of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The uneven incidence, the burden of unemployment, also appears to be falling increasingly on certain social, occupational and regional groupings. Unemployment rates amongst teenagers, females, migrants and older job seekers have been disproportionately high during the 1970s. Let us consider teenagers. On an average annual basis, the rate of unemployment amongst 15 to 19-year-olds has been consistently over 15 per cent since 1975 and over 17 per cent amongst teenagers looking for full time work. Young job seekers with relatively little work experience or developed skills are typically not in a strong competitive position in the full time job market. Despite existing youth employment policies designed to improve this competitiveness, employment opportunities for teenagers have slumped dramatically since the middle of last year. Against a background of a general slowing in employment growth, employment amongst teenagers was actually falling in absolute terms on an annual basis during the second half of 1981. In November and December the annual rate of decline was of the order of 20 ,000 jobs, mainly in the full time area. On an occupational basis, available evidence suggests that the incidence of unemployment is falling on the lower skill categories and most of the analysis of the impact of technological change points to this trend.

We know precious little about this important influence on current and future levels of unemployment and it is imperative that more detailed and ongoing investigations be undertaken at an official level. At a regional level, in conjunction with a number of other less comprehensive surveys which have been conducted at this level over the past few years CES data provided an important insight into the local and geographical characteristics of unemployment until their termination in April of last year. Such data indicated the existence of strong geographical variations in unemployment. We now have little official information on this important phenomenon. I refer to the phenomenon of hidden unemployment because official figures relating to unemployment levels do not take account of this. Over the past couple of years increasing attention has been focused on the growth of this factor. Hidden unemployment basically refers to people who want to work but who have withdrawn from active participation in the labour force or have declined to attempt to enter the labour force primarily because of the persistent lack of job opportunities. It also includes workers in part time employment who would prefer to work longer hours if such employment opportunities were available.

Studies have been conducted by members of the Melbourne University Institute and by the Social Welfare Research Centre at the University of New South Wales. The results indicate that by the start of the 1980s, hidden unemployment was as high if not higher than recorded levels of unemployment. Sheehan and Stricker from the Melbourne University Institute, in their recent book on the subject, estimate that in August 1979 hidden unemployment was 340,000 persons compared to the recorded unemployment level of 374,000 persons; that is, total unemployment of over 710,000 persons or an unemployment rate of, effectively, around 11 per cent. The Social Welfare Research Centre has estimated that by September 1980 the level of hidden unemployed had risen to about 445,000, which was actually larger than the official level at the time, of just over 400,000 persons.

These studies have provided orders of magnitude only. However, they point to the probable dimensions of the problem and the fact that it has arisen almost entirely as a result of the prolonged stagnation of the labour market since the mid-1970s. For instance, Sheehan and Stricker estimate that hidden unemployment was virtually non-existent prior to 1974-75. We, as a community-not as an Australian Labor Party or as Government parties but as an Australian community- need to know a lot more about this phenomenon than existing official resources allow. From a policy viewpoint, the possibility of a massive re-entry into the labour market of these hidden unemployed when job prospects improve must be accounted for. In relation to mothers, for instance, renewed participation in the labour market will have important implications for the provision of child care facilities as well as for employment policies.

I will not spend a great deal of time on the grave social implications for the viability of this free society because my colleague the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) will speak in more detail upon that aspect in seconding the motion. I simply say that it would be a matter of common ground between all honourable members-with the one possible exception-that this issue of the social implications, the way in which this phenomenon of unemployment is affecting the personality of the people concerned and matters permeating into the society, is a matter of concern for everyone who is worried about where this country is going. I look forward to the remarks on that subject by my colleague.

Coming to the question of policy implications, I suggest it is incumbent on any government with a sincere interest in achieving full employment to undertake a thorough appraisal of all policies and strategies which are proffered as potential solutions to the problem of unemployment. In the current situation the role of a more enlightened set of macroeconomic policies needs to be seriously investigated. This Government continues to rely on the traditional concept of a short run trade-off between price stability and full employment, and the belief that control of inflation is paramount and must be pursued through tight macroeconomic policies which depress employment growth. Quite apart from the obvious failure of this strategy judged in its own terms since 1975, adherence to such a strategy ignores the relevance of a growing body of analysis which suggests that inflation and unemployment can be tackled simultaneously with an appropriate reorganisation of macroeconomic affairs. There is enough work about from our own economists in this country on that. I refer to Sheehan's work, Crisis in Abundance, and Perkins's work, The Macroeconomic Mix to Stop Stagflation. There is enough work about to show the truth in regard to what I am saying about this. There is also growing support for a broader policy framework to be invoked in the dual fight against unemployment and inflation; namely, the use of more expansionary macroeconomic policy in conjunction with an incomes policy to maintain wage-price stability.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As it is now two hours after the time fixed for the meeting of the House, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr N.A. Brown) agreed to:
That the time for the discussion of notices be extended until 12.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The general point is that a wide range of potential strategies exist and should be examined seriously in terms of their ability to alleviate unemployment as the priority objective while at the same time not aggravating inflation or creating balance of payment difficulties. Informed investigation and debate must replace ideological predilection. It is also crucial that the relevance of job creation schemes be investigated. This Government has consistently refused to acknowledge the potential importance of job creation schemes--
—Like the RED scheme.

—On the basis of either ideological aversion to Government expenditure or the fact that such schemes are ineffective and too costly. In particular the Government has repeatedly used these arguments to criticise the operation of the Labor Party's Regional Employment Development Scheme of 1974-75. Such attitudes ignore some pertinent facts which I should like to bring to the attention of honourable members, including the jackass on the other side. Job creation schemes are widely used in Europe as a major means of reducing unemployment. The 1978 report of the United States National Commission for Manpower Policy, after analysing the European experience in this area, concluded that if well designed, such schemes are worth that cost. Hoping that my remarks may permeate even some thick minds, I say this: The evaluation of the RED scheme conducted not by the Australian Labor Party but by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations under this Government in 1977 concluded that when viewed in a broad social and economic framework the scheme's benefits outweighted its costs. It is important to remember that job creation schemes can be specifically directed to alleviate severe examples of unemployment in certain regions or amongst particularly disadvantaged groups of unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: Community based programs, labour intensive and directed at urgent social and community needs, are extremely useful in short term alleviation of unemployment. My party has a well developed set of job creation proposals which would seek to create an extra 100,000 jobs per annum in both public and private sectors, with a number of programs aimed specifically at groups experiencing abnormally severe unemployment. These proposals are continually being refined in the light of changing labour market conditions and have been carefully integrated with our general economic policies. What we should also do as a community is to investigate the applicability of overseas experience, extensive as it is, to the Australian situation, undertaking a thorough cost benefit appraisal of particular schemes. Specifically, the costs in terms of Government expenditures must be carefully pitted against the benefit arising from increased production, income and taxation and reduced unemployment benefit payments.

A good practical example of this type of approach is the cost benefit analysis used by G. T. Harris from the University of New England who has conducted a thorough investigation of the New Zealand experience with job creation schemes.

It is important, when we are talking about this fundamental subject, that we recognise the nature of limitations on the rate at which an Australian Government, committed to achieving full employment, can proceed towards that goal. Even with the adoption of more progressive enlightened macro-economic policies and the use of specific job creation schemes, we cannot expect to move immediately to an ideal situation. The reasons for this are obvious but need to be appreciated. They include the fact that productivity growth and normal labour force expansion will require economic growth of at least 3 per cent per year just to avoid a worsening of the unemployment situation; the problem of a more rapid expansion in the labour force as job opportunities expand and the hidden unemployment re-enter the labour market; and the existence of structural forms of unemployment, that is unemployment caused by a mismatching of the supply of and demand for labour on a geographical, skill or occupational basis.

This brings me, very briefly unfortunately in terms of time available, to the role of manpower and training programs in reducing unemployment. Where structural changes are occuring at a relatively rapid rate and major alterations are emerging in the occupational and regional demands for labour, appropriate manpower policies are crucial in ensuring that adjustments to such change can occur with a minimal amount of labour market dislocation. The existing set of manpower policies has evolved on an ad hoc reactive basis. The programs do not form a co-ordinated integrated approach to easing problems of labour market dislocation and do not appear to be based on any planned appraisal of longer term market trends. Rather, they largely constitute an ill conceived mixture of trade training subsidisation-the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme-subsidies for temporary work experience-the Special Youth Employment Training Program-and school to work transition programs which are designed primarily to delay the entry of school leavers into the labour market.

The programs have inherent deficiencies, while the overall strategy has some serious shortfalls, namely, the overriding emphasis on youth when there are other labour market groups with problems of similar magnitude and little importance is placed on the need for improving the geographical and ocupational mobility of the work force. There is an urgent need to consider the applicability of training, retraining and relocation assistance programs which are capable of dealing with a broad range of problems. I conclude by saying this : Naturally my duty is to criticise this Goverment in areas in which we think it is properly subject to criticism. But I hope that I have conveyed that, beyond that, we see this as a problem which transcends party considerations, that we want to join our resources with the best resources on the other side of this House in a joint committee to look at the economic and social reality of these problems and together, all of us in this Parliament to do what we can together to look at the problem, see its dimensions and then unitedly bring our combined best talents together to see, together, how we as responsible Australians can help our underprivileged Australians who are suffering from this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. If society is able to blame the unemployed for not having jobs, it tends to exonerate itself from any responsibility for the fact that job opportunities have almost disappeared. It focuses attention on the disabilities of the unemployed rather than the disabilities of society. It focuses attention away from the need for social change and job creation. A society which is based on the ideology of laissez- faire requires a deprived population which is allegedly unwilling to work or to work hard. Not only does this attitude to the unemployed reduce the moral pressure on the present Government to do something concrete about unemployment but also welfare measures can be kept to a minimum if those who will benefit from them can be described as dole bludgers.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was here in 1974 and 1975, this philosophy was constantly put forward by the then Opposition. I quote from a speech by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) recorded in Hansard of 3 September 1975 in which he stated:
The number of people receiving unemployment benefits has jumped from 32,009 in June 1974 to 162,000 in June 1975 . . .

I might add here that the number of unemployed has now jumped to 437,200 while the hidden unemployed, as my colleague the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke ) has so aptly shown us, number many hundreds of thousands more. Mr McVeigh went on to say:
This is a disaster and it is featherbedding to bums and slackers in our society . These people are abhorred by all thinking Australians. We on the Opposition--
As the Government then was-
side of the House are totally opposed to paying benefits to people who will not accept employment when they are physically capable of doing the job and a job is offered to them.

That was the opinion of the then Opposition, and that was the philosophy it sold off to the media and the people of Australia-the dole bludger syndrome. The Government has done a great disservice to Australia, to the Australian community and to the unemployed by reinforcing this community attitude. Divisions have occurred in the Australian society and will continue to multiply unless government-backed job creation policies are developed. Without a comprehensive policy for youth, an increasing number of young people-this unfortunately includes more girls than boys-will end up on the dole. At present one in every six young lads is unemployed, but one in every four young girls is unemployed. The implications of a generation of young people on the dole have really horrifying overtones for the entire community.

The tragedy of the middle aged unemployed is equally horrifying. The social implications of unemployment will engulf us all. The danger is that Australia will remain a generally wealthy country, but it will have a growing number of people who do not have jobs and who do not feel able to play any useful part in society. To some extent, this danger has already struck. Though young people are not the only ones hit hard by unemployment, they have the highest rate and many of them face a workless future. For Australians this is a new and extremely difficult social situation.

In the last few years the idea that a higher education will get a person a better job has taken quite a battering. Faced with the fact that the extra schooling has not always produced better job opportunities, young people, and particularly those in lower income families, have reacted by leaving school earlier than they did a few years ago.

Predictably, employers and governments have reacted by blaming the schools for not making the young people more employable. To blame the schools for general unemployment is irrational. Neither employment nor unemployment is created by schools. The general economic conditions, the Government's strategy, loss of public confidence and the savage cutback in public spending have all contributed to the highest rate of unemployment that Australia has experienced since the 1930s. One could almost say that the only growth industry in Australia is unemployment. The burden of the Government's misdirected economic strategy is being unfairly borne by one section of the community-the unemployed, young or middle aged. These are the victims, and the Government seems determined to cast them into the role of culprits. I wonder how many honourable members opposite have really looked at the results of unemployment-the effect on the individual, the effect on schools, on families, on industry, on retailing, and on the general community.

Robert Kosky, the psychiatrist superintendent in Western Australia, points to the astonishing lack of reseach into the mental health of young people who experience long term unemployment. From the few results of studies that are available, he draws the following conclusions:
A South Australian study shows that juvenile delinquency was associated with unemployed status of offenders and offenders' parents.
A Victorian 1977 report says that the rate of attempted suicide in unemployed persons in a large Victorian country town was 12 times the average area rate.
In Blacktown municipality of New South Wales, it was estimated that 30 to 40 per cent of the people attempting suicide were unemployed.
Of 15 to 24 year olds who were treated for the first time by the Victorian mental health authority and who were unemployed, 11 per cent were diagnosed as alcoholic.
Of the 15,000 people under 25 years estimated to be homeless in Melbourne, the majority were said to be unemployed.
A South Australian study showed that unemployed persons have consistently reported more respiratory illness, more migraines, more blackouts and more irritability than employed persons.
Twenty-one per cent of CYSS and 35 per cent of CES clients report that they often suffer from depression.

Dr Kosky adds that none of these studies assesses personal mental health adequately; nor do they decide between cause and effect, because despite unemployment being a major social phenomenon over the past eight years, there has been negligible research into its effects on mental health.

A leaked report by the Victorian Department of Community Welfare Services- another report that fell off the back of a truck-urging the Federal Government to act on unemployment, acknowledged a link between suicide and the jobless.

Dr Russell Meares, head of psychiatry at Melbourne University, has pinpointed suicide increases to suburbs where there are high rates of unemployment. He has said that the number of young men committing suicide has jumped from 50 a year in 1976 to 75 a year in 1977-79. He has said that a study of the depression years has shown that suicides peaked in 1930 at the height of the unemployment crisis. While a lot more research needs to be done on the health of unemployed people, I believe that we should take note of the signs now before the problem deteriorates.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.15 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr N.A. Brown)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the consideration of General Business, Notice No. 1, being continued until 12.35 p.m .

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The entire family is at risk when unemployment hits. All of the members here must have had constituents in the 45 to 55 age group who have worked hard for years, reared a family, and battled to keep a home going and educate their children, and who suddenly were told that their services were no longer needed; redundant at 45 to 55. There are no jobs for breadwinners in this age group. Their despair and hopelessness is tragic to see. They spend their days looking for work and becoming more and more despairing as the weeks and months go by. Family life suffers; tensions increase. The father feels that he has failed. He does not see that we have failed him. He loses his self-respect, his dignity, and his will to fight on. His plight is multiplied in thousands throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The school leavers have their own problems. Even during school years the talk is now on whether or not they will get a job when they leave school. With some the whole attitude to their school work suffers as they become fearful of their future. Some years ago when I was speaking to schools about unemployment, no one in the groups to which I was speaking really believed that he or she personally would be unemployed. It is a different ballgame now. All too many know that they will not get a job.

Nevertheless, they start on their search for work reasonably confidently. As unsuccessful attempts to find a job follow more unsuccessful attempts, they get a bit nervous. But then, when their friends start finding work, this tends to make them feel even more uneasy. 'What is wrong with me?' they start asking themselves. They do not ask what is wrong with a society that has no jobs, or what is wrong with governments that do not take enough interest to put up some job creation schemes. They ask 'What is wrong with me?', and that is the whole core of what is happening.

Over succeeding months of applying for jobs and being rejected, they get angry, resentful and bored. They feel powerless to help themselves. They cannot keep up with their friends who are working-not on the dole that we pay. They start to feel like failures. If they are living at home, they have parental pressure on them-'Why don't you get a job? Joe Blow's son got a job.' They sit around feeling bored, lonely and frustrated. It is at this stage that some become depressed, and some start abusing drugs and alcohol in an attempt to escape the feelings of despair.

The longer the period of unemployment, the more difficult the problem. Long term unemployment sets up psychological trends that are hard to reverse-loss of interest in appearance and in looking for a job, and eventually, even if work is obtained, there is no enthusiastic commitment. They tire quickly of it, and they hanker for a return to aimlessness.

This is one scenario; there are many. As is usual, the burden falls heaviest on the poor. In the low income family, with father and mother unemployed, it increases the difficulties that young people suffer. It makes it harder to cope, and under these circumstances the poor, who have already been penalised by this social system, continue to be punished throughout their lives. I brought with me a book called The School Report which gives the experiences of seven young people in the dole queues. One of the tragic things is that they have no experience when they go to apply for a job but everybody wants somebody with experience. Young people cannot get experience if no-one will give them a job. It is the chicken and the egg situation all over again.

The social results of unemployment will be with us for a long time. Britain had Brixton. Australia does not want a Brixton; but nor does it want increased petty crime, vandalism, hopelessness and despair. We do nothing to avoid the anger that unemployment engenders. We cannot expect the young people not to be angry. Youth unemployment could be the greatest future source of social instability in Australia. Governments must take the initiative in planning an overall policy for youth. The most constructive approach would be a total plan which gave all young people a choice of three alternatives-work, subsidised study or a mixture of work and study. At the moment, if they go on the dole they cannot study. It is a case of the chicken and the egg again. They cannot study without the dole because they cannot keep themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Transitionalise.

—The Minister should try it. It helps a few. There are hundreds of thousands of unemployed people in Australia. The Minister does not seem to understand the problems he is facing, nor does he really understand the problems of the future. The present situation robs the unemployed of a decent living wage . It also robs them of their self-respect and hope for the future. The social cost of this Government's policies falls too heavily on the shoulders of those least able to bear it. The Government should forget its philosophy of survival of the fittest. It should forget its philosophy of maintaining the deficit. It has blown it anyway. The Government should concentrate on the social tragedy of unemployment. It could be the tragedy that sinks this country within the next 10 or 15 years when we will have a generation of unemployed. I agree with my colleague the honourable member for Wills that, while the Opposition is berating the Government for what its policies have done, together we should go forward and give back to the young of this country and the middle aged, who have many years of life to dedicate to work in the country, their self-respect.

SPEECH.PARA: This could happen if we could work together and actually set out an overall plan, not just for their jobs but for their health. If we look at all the reports coming through from the mental health authorities we find that the health of the young unemployed is deteriorating rapidly. I have had people in my office whose teeth are falling out of their heads because we have only a dental hospital and it can take about two years to get an appointment there. Who cares if they are going to be toothless hags at 30 years of age? Nobody does. It is time that this Government, together with this Opposition, tackled the problem. Those on the other side of the House seem to forget that we also represent the aspirations of the people of Australia. Instead of fighting us, it is time the Government asked for our help and for the undoubted talents that honourable members on this side of the House have to solve a problem that is a national tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset by way of reply to the honourable member for Henty ( Mrs Child) that we on the Government side entirely agree with her proposition that one of the problems facing unemployed youths is that they do not have experience. As she quite rightly said, it is a vicious circle: People cannot get a job without experience and they cannot get the experience without a job. That is the very reason why so much of our effort and funds has been put into training and work experience programs-to provide a subsidy and make it easier for employers to take on young unemployed people who do not have experience. The evidence, such that there is, shows that very many thousands of young unemployed people who have worked under the Government's work experience and training programs for young unemployed people, having obtained that experience, find it far easier either to stay with the same employer and be economically supported or to obtain a job with another employer. So we agree with her to that extent.

SPEECH.PARA: I must, however, inject a note of some concern at this early stage. If the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) wants bipartisan support on this matter-I am very ready to give it-I would urge him to reconsider what he said with respect to the Government's manpower programs. Honourable members will recall that the view was expressed that one of the faults of the Government's programs was that-I am probably not quoting the honourable member correctly but this is the substance of what he said-there was a shortcoming and that part of the shortcoming was that they had an overriding emphasis on youth. I think that is an extraordinary position to take. Australia has high unemployment because of its high youth unemployment. It does not have high unemployment across the board because of its adult rate of unemployment. Its adult rate of unemployment is comparatively low. The problem we have is with the comparatively high rate of youth unemployment. That is where the problem is. That is where the emphasis has to be placed. That is where we have to tackle the problem. To say that an overriding emphasis is placed on the youth programs and to say in some way that that is something which is a defect in the Government's programs is very unfair, quite wrong and a shocking indictment of the Australian Labor Party's position on the support that is necessary for young unemployed people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are desperate.

—If I am desperate, let the honourable member repeat the words he said because I believe that in substance I have stated the view he has expressed . I think it is a reprehensible view. The substance of the issue before the House at the moment is that the honourable member for Wills has moved that a joint committee should be established to inquire into and report on unemployment in Australia. The Government's reply is that we do not need such an inquiry because the Government knows, the country knows and, indeed, as I will endeavour to explain later, the Opposition knows what the problems and causes of unemployment are and what the solutions to unemployment are. We put it that a joint committee on unemployment is not necessary and that to establish one would be to do nothing more than provide a diversion from tackling the problem. By setting up a joint committee to investigate unemployment we would simply be deluding ourselves that we were doing something constructive about the problem. It would be doing little more than putting off the evil day of facing up to the real causes of unemployment and tackling them.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we go any further let us look at what the honourable member wants to investigate through his joint committee. The honourable member wants the committee, firstly, to inquire into the extent of unemployment. But we do not need an inquiry into that. We know that the full time unemployment rate is 6.4 per cent. We know that it is too high. We know that in January 1979, however, it was 7.1 per cent. The following year, in January 1980, it dropped to 6.8 per cent. In the following year, in January 1981, it dropped to 6.6 per cent and it is now 6.4 per cent. Therefore, we know that it has dropped in each of the last four years but the rate is still too high. We also know that at least the rate is better than it is in comparable countries overseas. We know that the rate is better than the 8.9 per cent in the United States of America, the 11.5 per cent in the United Kingdom and the 6.7 per cent which is the average of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.

We know also, as I have already said, that the rate of youth unemployment in particular is far too high and that it is a major economic and social problem. We do not need an inquiry to tell us any of these things. We know them only too well. Indeed, the Government is continuing to impress on the people of Australia that they must acknowledge the unpalatable facts about unemployment and face up to the real causes of it. The real cause of unemployment in this country is that it is no longer as profitable or as economic to employ people in the same numbers as it used to be. If we want seriously to tackle the problem of unemployment we must seriously tackle the major cause of it, which is the large impetus given to unemployment by reason of excessive wage demands. Its parallel cause, of course, is the shorter working hours which are being forced on to the community as a result of excessive demands by certain sections of the trade union movement, those shorter hours not being matched by increases in productivity.

The honourable member wants the committee, secondly, to see whether unemployment is a long term problem. Of course it is a long term problem. We do not need an inquiry to tell us that. Unemployment will remain a problem until it becomes profitable to employ the unemployed and until the unemployed can offer the skills and abilities that employers want. What we need is not an inquiry but an acknowledgment of this basic cause of unemployment and a resolve to tackle it at its root to bring about an environment in which more people will want to be employers, in which employers will need to employ more people and be able economically to employ more people and in which the unemployed will have more to offer. The House need not take my word only for this. The honourable member for Wills, without the benefit of the findings of a joint committee to aid him, has told us what he believes the cause of unemployment to be and what we must do together if we are to alleviate it. In July last year, when the unemployment situation was much healthier than it is now, the honourable member said, in a prophetic statement on Radio 3UZ:
If you want what I think is the real answer, it really follows from what I have been saying. I think that if I were in charge-
That is not the prophetic part; that comes later. He said:

if I were in charge, I'd be saying to the Government Departments 'now look, we' ve got to sit down with the trade union movement and with the employers and really try and explain to them what the state of the economy is, what capacity there is for wage movement, what sort of adverse circumstances are there going to be for everyone-including workers, if wages explode too fast.'
He went on to say-this is the prophetic part of his statement because it is a prophecy that has come true:
Because there's no doubt that (if) wages do explode too quickly, it can have adverse economic impacts on unemployment.

There it is in a nutshell. The honourable member for Wills was absolutely correct. It is with no joy at all that we can now record that his prophecy came true. We have had substantial wage increases and shorter working hours without increases in productivity to match those conditions. That combination of factors has given rise to unemployment in this country.

But we know all of this. We do not need a select committee to tell us any of it . What we need is a conviction to tackle the cause of unemployment already identified by the honourable member for Wills. There is no argument as to the cause. It has already been identified by the honourable member, and presumably on behalf of the Australian Labor Party as I do not notice any dissent coming from the other side of the House. That should mean that the Labor Party should use its considerable influence in the trade union movement to persuade the trade unions to lessen their wage demands, to defer their claims for reduced hours and to try to do something about increasing productivity in this country. Until we do that, and until we have the trade union movement on side-the Labor Party can do more about it than we can-we will continue to have decreasing profitability and a situation in which it is simply not profitable to employ more people in this country.

The honourable member wants a select committee to see whether unemployment bears particularly upon certain industries, regions and sections of the work force. We do not need a committee to examine those things. That is the proper area of research of the Bureau of Labour Market Research which exists for that purpose and is engaged on that work. The Bureau was established expressly for that purpose. Let us look at some of the areas of research already under way by the Bureau and the subject of papers published or about to be published by it. There is an investigation into the review of information on the labour market for tradesmen, an investigation on the pattern of youth employment in the 1970s and a review of the operations of the relocation assistance scheme. There is the first phase of the study of the effectiveness of Commonwealth manpower programs for young people, particularly unemployed young people. There is a case study of the professional labour market.

The Bureau of Labour Market Research, the universities, the Government, advisory committees of departments of labour and other academics whose job it is to investigate these things are pursuing these matters and they are matters of legitimate inquiry. But we should not stop tackling unemployment and put it off until all research is concluded. We know substantially and essentially what is the root cause of unemployment in this country. What the Government says is that we must face up to the situation. There is no point in convincing ourselves that by a select committee or a joint committee the problem can be put off. We will not be solving it in any way. The expertise is in the Bureau of Labour Market Research and in the universities. It is those people who should be investigating labour market problems. There is not one word-this is a matter of very great concern-in the motion which indicates that there might be some connection between the excessive wage demands of the unions and rising unemployment. We must face that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I interrupt the Minister. The time allotted for precedence of General Business has expired. The Minister will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day under General Business for the next sitting.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will be aware that Gordon Pike, the Transport Officer of the House of Representatives since 1951, retires tomorrow, Saturday being his 65th birthday. Mr Pike is present in the gallery this afternoon and I know that all honourable members would like some reference to be made to Gordon' s service to members personally and to the Parliament.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, it has been indicated to me that so many members do wish to speak that I have, of my own volition and with the concurrence of the Whips, allowed for three speakers from each side. If I allowed more, we would spend the whole day on the matter and I am sure Gordon would not want us to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is something that I have not looked forward to for a long time having known for a long time that Gordon was about to retire. I would have been very upset if I had not had the opportunity to say a few words. I think I speak for most members in the House when I say that there is not a more popular person than Gordon Pike working in Parliament House.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he has the most difficult job of any public servant; that is, he has to deal with the most difficult people in the Parliament, the members. They demand a plane at a drop of a hat and the miracle is that Gordon has been able to meet their demands. Over the years, members catch literally hundreds and hundreds of planes and cars. If one looks back on the number of times we have done so, the occasions on which there has been a failure of the system are so rare as to be minuscule. On those rare occasions if we were to check it up, it usually was not Gordon's fault. How he has managed to keep that benign smiling countenance is beyond belief because we are, as I have said, a most obstreperous , difficult and impossible bunch of people to handle--
—I think the honourable member has gone far enough.

—Mr Speaker, I was thinking of you particularly as a matter of fact. We are particularly difficult when it comes to getting home. I recall one particular occasion-I do not want to go into reminiscences too much because a lot of people want to speak-when the House was scheduled to rise about 5 o'clock . Gordon had managed to arrange all the plane bookings for some 190-odd people when somebody, obviously on the Liberal-Country party side caused a disruption that went on for two hours. Suddenly, Gordon had to produce plane tickets and seats for people to leave Canberra. He did it and without at any stage losing his cool.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say how deeply sorry I am to see Gordon go. I know we will miss him and whoever tries to fill his role will have a very difficult task. I am sure I express the wish of everbody here when I say to Gordon and his family that I hope we will see more of him, and that he will spend many happy years in retirement.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a sad day for many of us in this building. Gordon Pike has been a very great servant of the Parliament over a very long period. He is one of the people who has given the Parliament its atmosphere. He is one of the people who has made the workings of the Parliament possible. In a sense, it will be hard to imagine a parliament without Gordon Pike. He always said: 'Leave it with me; I will fix it' and he always did . If he had a dollar for every time he said that over the past 40-odd years, it would be nice to imagine as a retirement allowance. It is Gordon Pike's phrase and he should have copyright in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember in earlier days-there are not too many of us who do but certainly you, Mr Speaker would be one and the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) another- when transport was not as good as it is now. This was not Gordon's fault; the aircraft were not so good. We would be booked on a DC4 or a DC3. Viscounts were introduced on the route. We would say: 'Gordon, can we get a Viscount this week? ' When we had a Viscount aircraft it was a great benefit, it was a boon-we thought we would never get anything better. The difference between a DC3 aircraft and a Viscount was certainly remarkable. But that, I suppose, just emphasises the length of time, which I am sure is too much for some honourable gentlemen in this House, that you, Mr Speaker, I and the Minister for Defence have been here.

Gordon has always conducted his task in a very friendly way. He has gone beyond the call of duty. Honourable members might like to know that his service to government and the Parliament has taken a span of more than 50 years-51 years to be exact. It was in February 1931, about six or seven months after I was born, when Gordon began a six year apprenticeship as a compositor with the Government Printing Office. In November 1940 he joined the Joint House Department. Then for 10 years, from 1941 to around about 1950 or 1951 he was an attendant with the House of Representatives. From 1951 to now he has been the officer-in-charge of transport, firstly as a transport assistant, then as transport officer and now as transport manager. That is an enourmous lifetime of service to a great variety of members of Parliament who have passed through this place over the years.
I do not know whether Gordon is intending to write his memoirs. But bearing in mind what Gordon could say about a number of us, I hope he treats us kindly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that is not an invitation.

—Well, it seems to be a habit these days, Mr Speaker, for people to retire and write. I do not know whether or not that is in Gordon's mind, but knowing his personality I am sure he would treat kindly members of Parliament and make us all appear better than we are. That might be an incitement. Gordon Pike has been active in many other areas. He represented the Australian Capital Territory in hockey on and off over 20 years between 1934 and 1954. He has coached and managed many junior hockey teams. He represented the Australian Capital Territory in cricket as a wicket keeper and has been an Australian Capital Territory cricket selector from 1971. He is an A grade table tennis player. I understand he still plays a pretty effective game of table tennis. He was honoured by the Queen in 1969 with a British Empire Medal and in 1982 he was made a Member of the British Empire.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not going to be possible to replace Gordon Pike. I suppose it will be possible to find somebody who will attempt to book members of Parliament on planes, who will attempt to get them where they want to go. I would not be surprised if we hear complaints in the next few weeks about members thinking that they had got on to a plane to Sydney and finding they are on a plane to Adelaide, or wanting to go to Brisbane and ending up on their way to Tasmania. Gordon has managed to point us all in the right direction over a long time. Gordon, on behalf of the Government and all members of this place, thank you very much for a lifetime of service. A very happy retirement to you and your wife and may good fortune be with you.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gordon Pike retires after more than half a century of service to this Parliament with the warmest regard of all members of this place and the deepest affection of everyone. It has been a phenomenal and an extraordinarily generous period of service to a succession of members of parliament who have entered this place. Most of them have come and gone; Gordon has stayed on. His contribution here has been invaluable. It is often said that any army marches on its stomach. Well, politicians like to move around in more comfort than that and Gordon Pike was extremely successful in ensuring that in their movements the maximum facilitation and not the least, comfort, was provided for them.

SPEECH.PARA: He was in his own way, and still is, indisputably a skilled self-made diplomat. Members of Parliament can sometimes be anxious and difficult to deal with. They can sometimes after a long and busy day be tired and emotional, to use a journalistic buzz phrase. He has always made sure that, for all the difficulties they may present, they have been safely placed in a motor vehicle and dispatched to their homes. His lips have always remained sealed. We are grateful to him for the loyal--

TALK.START.PARA: —For both.

—For both, especially the latter. But we are grateful to him for the loyal and ever cheerful service he has given to members of the Parliament. He is a very fine man in his own right. He is a man of considerable character and firmness, which, because of the nature of his work, he has controlled in fairly obvious ways. I have noted in the period I have been here that when it has been appropriate for him to establish his own self-respect and independence he has done that with a firmness which has been impressive and convincing. In the selective but appropriate way in which he has done that he has elevated the respect of all of the reasonable members of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a remarkable situation that a man who has served as transport officer in this Parliament is held in such extraordinarily high esteem. I do not want to imply that the man who is transport officer should not be held in high esteem. But what I am seeking to project is that of all the people I have known in this Parliament, in all of the years I have been here, Gordon Pike's name comes to the fore in total more than that of any other person's name who has served in this place. We are grateful to him; we are greatly indebted to him.

He was a cricketer of considerable note in his younger days. I guess it is appropriate, therefore, to use a cricketing analogy and say that we regret that now is the time when he takes his bat from the wicket for the last occasion. We wish him well and we wish members of his family well in his and their retirement . We hope that that retirement proves fruitful and most of all joyful because he deserves a great deal of joy from life. He has given so much in service in the years he has worked here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with the very fine tributes that have been paid to Gordon Pike here today. I doubt whether in my period in this Parliament I have ever heard a more affectionate or more sincere tribute paid to anybody associated with this Parliament. I think that says a tremendous amount. SPEECH.PARA: I have not needed the service of Gordon for a good many years because I have had a ministerial staff to help me. But I recall when I was a private member just how vital he was for me and the great respect I developed for him. I want to thank Gordon for the help he gave me in making decisions because I wanted to see justice done properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled 'Review of Auditor-General's Efficiency Audit Report-Commonwealth Administration of Nursing Home Programs', together with a copy of the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The efficiency audit report of the Auditor-General on Commonwealth administration of nursing home programs is his second efficiency audit report. It is also the second such report the Expenditure Committee has examined. Nursing homes are one type of program that provide accommodation and care for the aged. Commonwealth outlays under the various Acts which relate to nursing homes were close to $300m in 1978-79, so the efficiency audit has covered a fairly important part of government expenditure. The inquiry objectives of the Committee were to assess the substantive content and quality of the efficiency audit report and examine departmental responses.

SPEECH.PARA: In various areas of the report, such as control of fees, deficit financing, and standards of nursing homes, Audit has addressed problems and issues related to improving the efficiency of administration. Most of the suggestions are worth while and should improve the quality of departmental administration. For example , in the area of fees control which applies to private nursing homes-55 per cent of the total number of beds-Audit has identified what we perceive to be the weakest area of departmental administration. The Department of Health has appointed a consultant to advise on fees control and the Committee is of the opinion that Audit has been a catalyst, perhaps an important catalyst, in this appointment. Health has accepted the thrust of the majority of the Audit suggestions for change. It is important to note, however, that a significant number of Audit's suggestions for change have been set aside by Health as being policy matters for consideration by government.

Other parts of the report go beyond an examination of administrative efficiency . One particular aspect that gave Audit cause for concern was that 'a lack of an integrated approach to care of the aged appears to be leading to increasing Commonwealth financial support to high cost institutional nursing care and to a mismatch between the real care requirements of individual patients and the types of care provided'. The Audit concern with an integrated approach to care for the aged has led the Committee to discuss, without reaching any conclusions, the advantages and disadvantages of efficiency audits being extended into reviews of the effectiveness of programs. The Committee has again recognised the classic problem of distinguishing between policy and administration. Whilst examination of efficiency could lead to consideration of policy, it nevertheless believes that reviews of the effectiveness of programs are a separate and particular type of policy analysis.

The advantages of Audit extending its work into the review of program effectiveness are more information for the Parliament and the identification of what are termed 'big savings' in an area somewhat outside efficiency of administration. The disadvantage is the danger of the Auditor-General becoming a policy analyst. This can lead to the politicisation of his Office. For example, we find it difficult to see how auditors can comment on the quantity of policy advice public servants give Ministers without commenting on the policy itself. It also raises difficult questions of accountability: Of who is accountable to whom and for what in this expanded role of efficiency audits. It is not difficult to imagine a situation in which a Minister has to defend policy in the Parliament as a result of that policy having been questioned in an efficiency audit report. I must reiterate that in raising these issues the Committee has reached no conclusions. The Committee does however urge the Government to clarify the position of the Auditor-General in this area. It may then be appropriate that the House debate these matters after the Government's response has been made.

In his 1980-81 annual report, the Auditor-General estimated the net benefits of this efficiency audit at a potential of approximately $26m. This is not so. The potential is significantly below this figure, and is heavily dependent on the States' agreement on uniform funding of nursing hours. The Commonwealth has not been successful in such endeavours in the past and if these particular savings are not realised the audit will not achieve any quantifiable savings and will even result in additional costs. To sum up, when compared with the first report the second does represent an improvement in quality. Audit has made many worthwhile suggestions for change in respect of administrative efficiency. I trust the inaccurate audit figuring will be a one-off incident and I do hope that the Government and Parliament can give efficiency auditors some guidance in the discharge of the efficiency audit function.

The Committee inquiry has been one into a complex and interesting subject. I thank the members of the sub-committee for the important contributions they have made. These members are: My Deputy, Mr Leo McLeay, Bob Brown, Harry Edwards and James Porter. I also extend my appreciation of the assistance given by the secretariat-by Dr Don Stammer, the new general adviser of the Expenditure Committee, by Mr John Howard, whom I hasten to add is not the Treasurer but who is on secondment from the Department of Finance and by Mr Malcolm Aldons, the Secretary of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-First of all, I endorse the remarks generally which have been made by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, particularly his comments about the work of the members of the Committee, the work done by Dr Stammer and the work of the Secretariat. The original report would have commended itself to members of the Parliament and the people within the community generally who are concerned about care for the aged and, in particular , the operation of nursing homes and the participation of the Commonwealth itself in the operation of nursing homes. I would commend to honourable members the report of the Expenditure Committee in connection with that efficiency audit report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no intention of canvassing at this stage any of the matters concerning the administration of nursing homes. But I would like to make reference to a part of the Committee's report to which the honourable member for Hume has already drawn attention. I refer this section of the report to those members of the Parliament and those members of the community who may be interested in the process of efficiency auditing and its place in the whole audit continuum. There is a section of the report which is headed 'Scope of the efficiency audit report '. Although, as the honourable member for Hume has indicated, the Committee raised issues in connection with the appropriateness of the nature of investigations by the Auditor-General in connection with efficiency audit, it did not reach any conclusions. But we have pointed to some of the issues involved. The easiest definition of 'audit area' is in connection with financial auditing or compliance auditing. But as soon as one moves into the area of efficiency auditing it becomes difficult to determine an appropriate boundary between efficiency auditing and an assessment of program effectiveness. The process of efficiency auditing is intended to review the efficiency of administration and the efficiency with which, in fact, the resources available in the pursuit of any particular policy, or the implementation of any particular program, are being used. One enters a grey area along that continuum when one starts to question policy itself.

I am concerned, in this regard, about the capacity of the Auditor-General's Department or any other authority to determine an appropriate boundary- particularly in light of the fact that the claim is made, quite correctly, that intrusion into areas of policy is perhaps not an appropriate role for an efficiency audit. But I am concerned about the definition of 'policy'. I do not think there is any doubt, for example, that the terms of actual legislation do themselves indicate the Government's policy in the pursuit of any of its objectives or programs. Perhaps the details of a Minister's second reading speech would adequately and correctly indicate the Government's policy. But when we go further down the line I am not sure at what point matters cease to be government policy. For example, is a Cabinet decision in connection with any program which is then communicated to the department or the authority by the Minister in fact government policy to the same extent that the wording of the Act or the second reading speech statements would be? To go further, is a direction initiated by the Minister himself to his Department an indication of policy? To go further again, if an aspect of policy is determined within the Department and the Minister gives it his endorsement or approval, does that become government policy?

In fact, during the course of the inquiry by the Standing Committee on Expenditure there was a particular instance, the details of which I need not go into, where we were advised by the Department of Health that one of its practices was government policy. On further inquiry and investigation by the Department itself it became apparent that that was not so; that the policy had been determined within the Department many years earlier.

I am concerned that if, for example, a Minister, in applying himself to matters of detail within his Department, issues directions concerning administrative procedures those directions will be interpreted as policies of the Minister and the Government. Of course, if one were to go that far it would reduce the whole exercise to an absurdity. It would mean that, the Minister having made determinations on matters of detail and their then being accommodated by this policy area, the Auditor-General or any other authority responsible for efficiency auditing would, in effect, be precluded from investigating them as matters of administration.

I would also be concerned if at this stage, because such concerns had been expressed, the Auditor-General and his officers became too inhibited in moving further along that audit continuum. As they quite correctly have said, the big savings are to be made within perhaps that marginal area between efficiency auditing and determining program effectiveness. Again, as with the initial inquiry by the Standing Committee on Expenditure-into the efficiency audit by the Auditor-General's Office-I personally found the exercise interesting and stimulating. Quite apart from the detail concerning the nature of the efficiency audit itself-related to administration and perhaps to some aspects of policy incidentally-the particular question that needs to be resolved and to which the Chairman quite correctly has drawn attention is for the Parliament itself eventually to determine where the boundaries lie.

I repeat that I would be very concerned if undue obstacles and hurdles were to be placed in the path of the Auditor-General's Office in pursuing matters which, hopefully, would not be embarrassing to this or subsequent governments but about which the Auditor-General should perhaps quite correctly indicate some degree of concern and thus achieve what he has described as some of the more significant, or big, savings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have been a member of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, which has dealt with both this report by the Auditor-General on the administration of the Commonwealth nursing home programs and the previous report on the property function of the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: As a strong advocate of efficiency audits in the lead-up to their introduction to Australia, I believe there is an urgent and continuing need to ensure the efficient administration of programs which have been implemented by the Government and the Parliament. Quite frankly, I am surprised that efficiency audits were not under taken much earlier and I do not just mean years ago but rather decades ago.

It is clear to me that, from time to time, the running of Commonwealth programs ought to be reviewed by an outside body to ensure that they are being efficiently administered. The process is used a great deal in the private sector . There is no reason why it should not be used in the public sector. I do not want to deal with the details of this report, as they are clearly set out for all to read. However, I would like to make a couple of general comments about, firstly the role of the departments which are under investigation and the role of the Auditor-General.

So far, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of Health have given evidence to the Expenditure Committee in relation to the findings of the efficiency audits which have been undertaken within their Departments. When they were giving their evidence it became clear to me that they believed one of their major roles was to protect the Department and, as such, they were extremely reticent to acknowledge examples of inefficiency which were thrown up by the Auditor. Often they would claim that audit-suggested changes were, in fact, in the pipleline before Audit made them. On occasions it was necessary for us to drag out of the Departments the fact that Audit had made a useful contribution.

Whilst I can understand departmental officers being protective of the administration of programs within their area, I believe it would be helpful for administrators to have a more open mind to suggestions for change which lead to greater efficiency in their departments. Both Departments accepted that the efficiency audit was useful. Indeed, the Department of Administrative Services had invited the efficiency auditors in when the Department was reviewing the administration of the property function. Therefore, some of the suggested changes may have already been considered by the Department, however, there still seems to be a reticence to acknowledge shortcomings in the administration. This reticence was probably more noticeable in the case of the Department of Health which has appointed a consultant to consider the implementation of many of Audit 's suggestions.

In relation to the role of the Auditor, this latest report makes it clear, as is evidenced in our report, that he is indeed fallible. However, I do not believe that this detracts from the thrust of his role as an efficiency auditor. The efficiency audit has come up with many useful initiatives in the administration of the nursing home program. Most of these are subject to consideration for implementation by the Department.

The other problem in relation to the Auditor-General which our report raises is the question of how far he can go in reviewing the efficiency of the administration of a department without getting into a review of policy. This matter has been raised by the previous two speakers and clearly the Auditor- General must take care not to venture too far over the fine dividing line between examining the efficient administration of a program and its effectiveness. If he does so, he runs the risk of becoming involved in a political discussion which I believe he would do well to keep out of.

Finally, I believe this second report is an improvement on the first. I look forward to many more such reports from the Auditor-General so that we, the Parliament, can be satisfied that our programs are being efficiently administered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -As the previous speakers have said in regard to this statement, the Standing Committee on Expenditure looked at the functions of the Auditor-General just as closely, in fact, as it looked at the report in relation to this inquiry. I would like to make a comment on two areas of the report. The first is the Department of Health's submissions both to the Auditor- General and to the Committee and the second is the area of activity of the Auditor-General himself. There is no doubt that the nursing home function of the Department of Health very much needed to be looked at. I commend to members of the House that they should read the report of the Auditor-General and the report of the Expenditure Committee on that particular function. There is no doubt that some of the changes that the Health Department made since the Auditor-General began his investigation and since the Expenditure Committee began its hearings will be beneficial. There is also quite drastic need for more changes to be made and for more accountability of that particular program. We are now looking at a program which will expend approximately $680m for this financial year; a program that has been running without much amendment for nearly 30 years. There is no doubt that some change is needed in that area in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: One particular area that needs dramatic change is that of who has the right to commit people to nursing homes and who has the right to authorise extensive care benefits. Evidence was given to the Committee that the Health Department felt that as far as the nursing home function was concerned, there should be no interference by government doctors in value judgments on other doctors' professional feelings. I think that this is quite a mistake when we consider the large sums of money being expended in this program. No one would suggest that any doctor should certify a person for an invalid pension and not have that decision reviewed by a Commonwealth doctor; no one would suggest that any doctor should certify a Commonwealth public servant as unfit for work and fit for retirement without that person being checked by a Commonwealth medical officer; and no one would suggest that a local general practitioner should certify that a Commonwealth public servant should be paid worker's compensation without a test being carried out by a Commonwealth doctor.

We find the nursing home function is the only area of Commonwealth responsibility in which the Commonwealth's own servants do not cast a professional opinion upon the professional opinion of their medical colleagues. When such huge amounts of money are involved, I think that the Commonwealth's expenditure is being too loosely organised in this area. I see no reason why Commonwealth Department of Health doctors should not make a professional judgment on other doctors in the nursing home area as they do in all other areas where doctors make submissions to the Government on behalf of their patients. I think that is an area of which the Health Department and the Government should take particular note.

The second area I would like to commend to the House for investigation is the accountability of the Auditor-General himself. In this particular inquiry the Auditor-General has extended his inquiries into the areas that he has said are areas that could be classified as policy areas rather than administrative areas. There is no doubt that in the conduct of efficiency audits the line between policy and administration must be very carefully drawn indeed and the Auditor- General has a great responsibility to ensure that his people make these investigations correctly and properly. The interesting thing is that the Parliament cannot choose the Auditor-General because once he is appointed he is really appointed for life. I doubt whether anyone would be able to get a vote of both Houses of Parliament to remove the gentleman. We do not have a chance to choose who the Auditor is and I think he should be careful about the inquiries he makes when conducting efficiency audits.

In looking at the Auditor-General's report the Expenditure Committee took the decision to examine the substantive quality of the efficiency audit report because it believed that such audits were necessary. But I would not like to see in Australia what has happened in Canada, where the Auditor-General has got somewhat out of control. In Canada the Auditor-General is said to have a new de facto power to certify policy or the substance of expenditure decisions in addition to the traditional comment on the probity of expenditure.

This raises several important issues for this Parliament as well as for the Government to look at. One of those important issues is who or what controls the office of the Auditor-General in his quest to bring the Government to account. I think the accusation made against the former Canadian Auditor-General was that he wanted to entrench the program evaluation function at all levels of government so as to push big government into becoming small government. Whilst that might be attractive to many members on both sides of the House, the Canadian Auditor-General has not shown that that in fact has occurred. This Government has not been able to do that with efficiency audits, either. We must take quite a close look as the Auditor-General moves out of his traditional area and into a new field of activity. We should ensure that an officer who is a statutory office holder does not start to exercise more power than this Parliament exercises and make sure, in particular, that he does not attempt to exercise some of the authority that this Parliament should be exercising.
