DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to oversee diamond marketing and pricing arrangements in order to protect the national interest.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of the matter of public importance proposed by the Opposition are:

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for the Government to oversee diamond marketing and pricing arrangements in order to protect the national interest.

Most members of the House would agree that very few countries are blessed with natural resources in the way in which Australia is. The resource that we are speaking of in this case-that is, the Ashton joint venture resource at Argyle in Western Australia-is unique in terms of its size. Of course, it is part of a larger diamond bearing area in which another substantial diamond pipe has been identified, at what will be called Ellendale. So far as we know the Australian Government expressed no preference nor proposed any option for the marketing arrangements for diamonds. So far as we are aware no study has been undertaken as to whether De Beers or any other marketer should be utilised in the service of marketing Australian diamonds. The Government has never raised the matter in a public way and the only attitude expressed at Commonwealth level has been by the Opposition. This is despite the fact that it was well known that marketing arrangements and options were being considered by the companies involved.

While the States have the undoubted responsibility for mining developments, the Commonwealth has clear responsibilities in respect of trade and trading arrangements. One has the distinct impression that the first the Commonwealth heard of any proposed marketing arrangements was when Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd revealed the parameters of its proposed arrangement with De Beers to the Government last week. That is hardly the attitude that should prevail from a government looking for national development from the resources sector. Frankly, without the concern expressed by the Opposition, one could speculate about the climate within which these arrangements have been negotiated. Certainly the Central Selling Organisation of De Beers felt there was no pressure for any exception to be made in its trading arrangements with Australia emanating from the Australian Government. If it were not for the Opposition and the media pursuing this matter, the Australian public would be none the wiser of the real potential of Argyle nor of the issues involved in the marketing.

The answer to the question put by me to the Minister for Trade and Resources ( Mr Anthony) on Tuesday last week, was the first indication by the Government that it was concerned with aspects of the pricing arrangements. This is at least heartening, given the previous indications by the Minister that he regarded this as a purely commercial matter and not one for any Commonwealth Government involvement. I know that the Department of Trade and Resources is doing its best to be in a position to provide the Government with valuable advice on the issue of diamond marketing. But no department can really be in a sound position to proffer advice if the Government does not encourage or permit it to gather intelligence. At this stage the Department has no diamond valuing expertise. This is not a criticism because there has been no previous requirement for this expertise to be developed. But there is now and there has been in reality for about 12 months. So it is becoming critical that the Government has this capacity in respect of pricing questions which are the central issue in any marketing strategy for minerals and which, of course, in respect of valuations and pricing, is the critical issue in the Argyle development strategy.
In the Bulletin of 2 March an article was published by Trevor Sykes about De Beers and the marketing of Ashton diamonds. On page 92 he states:
The Botswana and Namibian Governments have appointed diamond experts, usually members of the Diamond Producers Association, to check and, where necessary, query CSO valuation of diamonds.
He continues:

it takes a minimum of three years to train a sorter to a level where he or she can be considered experienced. Some take less time, and if Australia is to sort its own diamonds and thereby derive the benefits of the added value, it should begin training sorters now and in large numbers.

In other words, on those two counts there are, in the case of those two governments mentioned in Mr Sykes article, indications that diamond experts have been appointed for the purpose of CSO valuations. He points to the fact that without trained sorters in Australia, we would probably need to rely upon CSO sorters. Earlier in the article he says, and there is not much news in this but I suppose it is worth repeating, that there are 5,000 categories into which diamonds are sorted by size, shape, quality and colour, et cetera. So there is obviously a pressing requirement upon the Government to see that there is a level of competence in sorting and that there is a level of competence, in particular, to protect the revenue in respect of this question of pricing.

The real issue gets back to pricing and valuations, and the Government's capacity to have an effect upon them. Last week Conzinc Riotinto of Australia announced this arrangement with De Beers and mentioned that an average price it would expect for its produce would be around $US9 per carat. I have said, and I will say again, that the Opposition finds this figure very low. CRA backed its claims yesterday with a statement indicating the valuations of a number of other independent valuers who do support its claim. The point was made by another person interested in the trade that some of the people who value the diamonds are customers or potential customers. The valuations also depend upon whether they come from a firm of industrial valuers, who tend to undervalue gem grade stones because they are not certain what they are looking at, or gem grade valuers who tend to regard industrial diamonds as rubbish. While one could be impressed by the fact that a number of other valuers seem to substantiate these figures, I think one would need to check on exactly who values them. It has been said that if any substantial firm in the world which is competent in the valuation of either gem or industrial diamonds were to attempt to assist the Ashton joint venture or to lend its prestigious name to valuations, it would have its sites removed by De Beers. Quite obviously these people will not be involved in this calculation.

The other question is that of Endeavour Resources and Northern Mining Corporation. Northern Mining, of course, owns 5 per cent of this joint venture. It is no news to honourable members that Northern Mining is being taken over by Endeavour Resources. Endeavour Resources is owned by Alan Bond. I think it would also be no news to honourable members of this House that the price which the Bond Corporation is offering to Northern Mining tends to substantiate the claim that it believes that this project will produce much higher profits and that the diamond values will be much higher than does CRA or Ashton Mining. In fact, it is common knowledge that Northern Mining and Endeavour Resources believe the average price per carat to be somewhere around $18 to $20 which is about double what CRA believes. They are putting their money where their mouths are. They are offering a price for the shares in Northern Mining which substantiates their belief in the value of the product.

The other question involves the type of contract involved. At first indication it would appear that De Beers would offer what is virtually a fixed price contract for a certain period with a standard set of diamonds as the grades. As Sykes pointed out in the Bulletin yesterday:

Prices paid by the CSO are also guaranteed, against a master sample of the diamonds from the producer's mine. The producer's interest is guarded by an independent expert or experts which he appoints as virtual auditors of CSO valuations.

In other words, there is a sort of fixed price. There is some movement within those prices. There is a standard set of diamonds with which to compare other products and prices are paid accordingly. But we find out now, after the Opposition has pressed this issue, particularly in the media, that CRA is now saying that it will be paid prices commensurate with London prices at the time of production, which would seem to me to be a departure from the normal style of a De Beers' contract.

For the purposes of indicating some concern about the values, I have done some simple calculations, a copy of which I will make available to the Deputy Prime Minister so that his Department may analyse them. Let us take a 100 carat sample and use CRA's $US9 figure. That would be $900 for the packet of 100. If we deduct the commission of 7 per cent, it equals $63, and the figure comes back to $8.37. Then we take away CRA's estimate-not anybody else's-of 10 per cent gem grade stones, which would be 10 carats out of the 100. At CRA and De Beers' price of $50 per carat-and one would deduct from that $500 for the gems-that would leave a balance of $337. If we take the boart out, the industrial grit-17 per cent at $150 a carat-that would amount to $26 which leaves a balance of $311 . There are 73 industrial stones left which, when we divide 73 into 311, brings up an average price per carat of $4.26 for the industrial stones.

I have just had a price comparison from Henry Polak Diamond Corporation of West 48th Street, New York, a large diamond marketing firm in the United States which specialises in industrial diamonds. Let us look at the prices it is charging on its official price list for the various industrial stones: hardness testers, $ 115 to $130 a carat; die- stones, $80 to $225 a carat; maccle, $10 to $130 a carat; emery wheel dressers for 1/2 carat, $5.50 to $165 a carat; emery wheel dressers for 1 carat, $6 to $190 a carat; emery wheel dressers for 2 carats, $8 to $230 a carat; tool stones, $10 to $45 a carat; and drilling material $8.50 to $45 a carat. Even if one deducts 40 per cent from that price for an ex-mine price-in other words, allowing 40 per cent of profit between the ex-mine price and the wholesale price-there is no price, barring the poorest of the dresser stones, the things that are called congo cubes, the lowest-priced dresser stones , which gets anywhere near the residual price that I indicated of $4.26 per carat, after one does that calculation. The other important point about it is this: That is at CRA's $50 price per carat. If that happened to be wrong-and many believe it is, because we think the gem grade stones are being underrated- if that happened to be $100 per carat, that would mean that all the industrials went to De Beers for virtually nothing.

It is worth repeating that across the 49 million carats of production of diamonds in the world last year, the average price was $265 per carat, and yet the average price according to this arrangement will be only $9. It may well be, after analysis, that that figure is correct. We are quite prepared to see that. But the Government should be in a position to be able to establish that. If we reach a position in which diamonds are sold on the London exchange at prices at the time, the rest would become to some extent a calculation of the potential of the project. But I think the expectations about Ashton are being lowered. I am not sure whether they are being reasonably lowered. I think the Government must be in a position-bearing in mind that it has this responsibility for its own revenue and for exports-to take this sort of information aboard.

The gem grade diamonds of course will all go to De Beers. Under the arrangement 75 per cent will be sold through De Beers, and 25 per cent will be marketed by Australia. I cannot see why, if De Beers was prepared to make that concession to CRA and the other joint venturers, it was not 25 per cent through the whole run of mine production. De Beers says that the quantities or values of the gem grade stones are too small. If that is the case, why does De Beers worry about that? Why does it not let CRA and the joint venturers market 25 per cent of the lot? At least then we would be in a position to get some sort of price comparisons with what will be paid by De Beers. As well, Northern Mining, as a joint venturer, is likely to take its 5 per cent of the run of mine produce, and sell it independently. In fact, Endeavour Resources is in Japan now with that in mind . That would also give us some independent measurement.

I seriously put it to the Deputy Prime Minister that he should give his Department encouragement to be able to offer the Government good advice on diamond marketing, that there should be close government scrutiny of the marketing strategy, and that the Government itself should undertake, with valuers appointed by itself or taken from within the Department or developed within the Department, competent valuations of the Argyle deposit in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —The assertion made in the matter of public importance raised by the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) is that the Commonwealth Government is not sufficiently interested in ensuring that the public interest is being protected in regard to the development and sale of diamonds from the potential Argyle mine. I hoped that I might have corrected that feeling of the honourable member by the answer I gave to a question from him on Tuesday, when I assured him that we were concerned about the whole question of valuation, which I think is the key point as to whether the public interest is being sufficiently protected.

SPEECH.PARA: Up to this point in time there have been assertions made as to the value of the diamonds. It is very difficult for anybody to know accurately just what those valuations are. No actual sales have been made from the mine to this point of time. Some packages of diamonds have been presented for valuation and it is on those valuations that there seems to be some conjecture at present. But I was interested to read in the paper today some comments by Conzinc Riotinto of Australia refuting some of the allegations made that it has been undervaluing the diamonds which have been valued at this point in time. I should like to come to that question a little later.

I do not think there is any difference of opinion in the House that there is a very keen desire to see the Argyle mine developed. It is obviously a diamond mine of great significance and it will be of importance to the general mining and resource developments of this country. For Western Australia it has great significance. I visited the Argyle mine only a week or so ago. It struck me what an impact it will make for regional development in the north-west of Western Australia. This is a very remote area of Australia, particularly where the diamonds have been found. The whole of the Ord River area and Kununurra has been plagued in its development because of its remoteness and costs of transportation into the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the silly idea of putting a dam there.

—I agree with the honourable member for Fremantle that it might have been before its time, but from what I saw the other day, there are good prospects that the agro-economics of the area are changing and could be quite satisfactory. But if a mine is developed-and it will be a substantial mine-the community of Kununurra will increase very substantially and make a large settlement. I think from that settlement we will see all sorts of development taking place in that part of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ashton joint venturers started as a consortium of five companies that got together in 1972, and it was in 1976 that CRA bought into that consortium. I think it is fair enough to say that it was their exploration techniques that led to the discovery of diamonds at Ellendale on the Fitzroy River and now at Upper Smoky Creek and what is known as AK1, which is the kimberlite pipe. The kimberlite pipe was discovered only two years ago. It is hoped that mining will start this year.

Very few people realise the tremendous costs involved in the exploration for and the evaluation of diamonds. De Beers people had been across this country scanning it for diamonds previously and had not discovered them in economic quantities. It was really CRA that was successful in assessing it as a commercial diamond mine of some significance. When in full production it will have a capacity to reach about 20 million carats a year, which is about 40 per cent of world production, so that will have a profound impact on the diamond market around the world. But the success of this venture will basically depend upon the marketing arrangements.

The marketing of diamonds is a complex matter. It has largely been managed-and I say 'managed' in a cartel term-by the Central Selling Organisation of De Beers , which has promoted diamonds as something of value and has also promoted their worth as an industrial product. By managing the supply on to the market and also being largely in control of the production of synthetic diamonds, it has been able to maintain stability in prices around the world. There have been one or two countries, such as Zaire, which have tried to sell independently of the CSO, only to find that they run into considerable difficulty. For many years the Soviet Union used De Beers for selling most of its gemstones. Although it uses an independent organisation for selling now, I am told that independent organisation is closely linked with the De Beers organisation. So it sees the value in working co-operatively to sell diamonds to ensure that the best price is obtained.

If this mine is to be developed to its full potential, the first stage being $ 300m and the second stage being in excess of $500m, the developers will have to get a degree of bankability to be able to borrow the moneys for the development of the mine. That means undertaking arrangements with people who can give an assurance that they can market the diamonds. To the best of my understanding there is nobody around the world who can handle the quantity of diamonds involved in the immediate future other than CSO. I think the question that the honourable member for Blaxland has brought forward as to whether we will get proper value for these diamonds is quite a correct one. I informed the honourable member in an answer to a question asked the other day that I believe the arrangements that are now falling into place-I say falling into place because they have to be developed, and they are being developed, between the Commonwealth, the Western Australian Government and the company-will ensure that there will be a number of checks and counterchecks to ensure that the proper values are being obtained.

All diamonds will have to be sorted in Western Australia. That is a requirement of the Western Australian Government under its mining lease arrangements. It also requires that unless a gem processing industry is developed in Western Australia certain additional penalties will be imposed. I think we have to acknowledge that Western Australia has certainly done its utmost to see that Western Australia's interests are protected, in which case the national interest is being protected. It is concerned not only to have the industry in Western Australia but also to obtain the best revenue it can from the development of these diamonds. The royalty arrangement with Western Australia is that it will obtain 7 1/2 per cent of the free-on-board price of the diamonds or 22 1/2 per cent of the profits of the mine, whichever is the greater. I think it is anybody 's guess at this point in time as to which will be the greater. But certainly Western Australia would be falling down on its job if it did not ensure that it will get the proper and best value for the diamonds that will be sold from that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely what they have not done.
—That is precisely what it will be doing once the trade starts.
—When?

—I remind the honourable member that the commercial mining has not started. The project is still in the evaluation stage and only packets of diamonds have been prepared. What CRA has done in the initial stage-again, this is what I have been informed-is to give a package of diamonds to the Central Selling Organisation for it to give an assessment of their value. The package is a sample of the mixture of diamonds-the cheap gem, the industrial diamonds and the boarts that come out of the mine. An evaluation has been done of that package of diamonds. That package-it could be a similar package; I am not sure on that point-has been given to four other independent valuers around the world for assessment. CRA has also given that package or a similar package to the Northern Mining organisation and Northern Mining has sought four independent valuations.

SPEECH.PARA: Of all of those valuations seven are very much in line with the valuations made by an AJV valuer. The only one which is at variance is the one given to Mr Albert Joris for evaluation. Up to this point in time seven of the people have given valuations which are very similar to the valuations given by the AJV valuer. To ensure that the Commonwealth undertakes its responsibility of protecting the national interest I informed the honourable member for Blaxland the other day that I see it as being necessary, even though the company will have its own independent valuer watching all the time and even though Western Australia will have valuers permanently within the sorting house, for the Commonwealth periodically to do spot checks of the valuation of diamonds to ensure that everything is taking place in a proper manner. I think that with the two governments and the company involved in these valuations we should get an accurate assessment.

I want to emphasise that the problem still lies ahead. It is early days. It is a major mining operation. In the first stage something like 2 1/2 million tonnes of material a year will be moved. When one realises that the diamonds make up about one part in one hundred million parts one can see that it is a tremendous separation job to extract these diamonds and a costly job in the first place. That is why the exploration and the evaluation was such a costly business. Up to this point in time $60m has been spent on deciding whether it is worth while going ahead with the project. But we know from the initial valuations that the diamonds from this mine are basically industrial diamonds. Something like 10 per cent of them will be gemstones of reasonable quality. But 60 per cent to 70 per cent will fall into the boart, grit, industrial diamonds category. The price for those will have to relate very closely to the price of synthetic diamonds, which are produced for something like $1.50 a carat.

The matter of gem diamonds also has to be examined. The price can be influenced by the colour, size and texture of the stones. All of these things come into consideration. Certainly on the initial valuations it looks as though the value per carat by comparison with the world value for diamonds is low. Whilst there is some minor variation-a dollar or two-in all the valuations, there is certainly not a major variation. I think it is important that we be able to sell these diamonds and that this great mining project proceeds. I give an assurance to the House that my Department will be doing its utmost, firstly, to give encouragement to the project and, secondly, to ensure that the public interest is looked after.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is concluded.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Sales Tax Legislation
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Librarians and library users throughout the nation call for the exemption of books, periodicals and newspapers from the imposition of sales taxes.

The tax exempt status of libraries and schools will not protect them from general cost increases which sales tax and its collection will cause. Indeed, exemption claims on millions of items per year will themselves add to the cost burden of both libraries and suppliers.
This tax is socially injurious and unworkable, and a burden on education, science and culture.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will exempt books, periodicals including newspapers from the proposed sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Campbell,Mr Dawkins,Mr Fry,Mr Humphreys,Mr Jacobi,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Kerin,Mr McLeay,Mr Morris,Mr Mountford,Mr Scott and Mr Wallis.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5 per cent on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers particularly educational publications and books of a religious nature , is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, a clear infringement of our democratic freedom, and that no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a Sales Tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lusher,Mr Morris and Mr Thomson.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, footwear, newspapers, buildings and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mr Peacock and Mr Thomson.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for cost of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non residential area at Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interest not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public enquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representative in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's service programme is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important programme.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that monies be made available to subsidize child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programmes and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australian depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.

PETITION.TITLE: Marie-France Claude
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Marie-France Claude is the Vice-President of the Christian Democrat Party of Haiti. The party is opposed to the government of President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier, but it does not use or advocate violence. Because of her activities in the Christian Democrat Party, Marie-France Claude has been sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment with hard labour.
A number of other members of this opposition party have been sentenced to similar terms of imprisonment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government pass on to the Haitian Government the concern of the undersigned citizens, and their wish that Marie-France Claude be released from prison.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(a) Present income tax laws are unfair to single income families,
(b) All marriages should be recognized as partnerships by allowing partners to divide their joint income for tax purposes,
(c) The family, which is the natural and fundamental group unit of society, should be an economic unit in tax laws,
(d) Children are Australia's future and their individual care by a parent at home should not be discouraged by extra tax.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament will reform income tax laws to allow the joint income of husband and wife to be equally divided between them for taxation purposes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That Federal funding of children's services which has been reduced by almost 50 per cent in real terms over the last five years should be restored forthwith to at least 1975-76 level in real terms, so that children's services can be more equitably provided throughout Australia.
That Budget allocations for children's services be spent in full for the purposes designated.
That current plans to impose a means test on the users of child care services will place them out of the reach of the bulk of the users and should be dropped forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
