PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are aware that the proposed Sales Tax is only one aspect of a Budget needed to support the growth and development of our country.
And that every Australian, whether rich or poor must aid this aim.
But that the social conscience of a country must be judged by the way in which it responds to the needs of its poorest, most helpless citizens.
And that this latest imposition will be responsible for Australia being judged not only by its own people but by the rest of the world.

We, the citizens of Queensland most humbly pray that: In the cause of justice and equity, your Honourable Members will reject any attempt to impose a Sales Tax on all essential goods including packaging of foods, shoes, clothing, literature and building materials.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pulteney Street Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Division of Adelaide respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to close the Pulteney Street Post Office will cause customers unnecessary inconvenience.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will close Pulteney Street Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the members of the Congregation of St Luke's Anglican Church, Vermont, Victoria, respectfully showeth:
Our concern at the continuing upward spiral of interest rates on Home Loans, causing increasing hardship in the middle income bracket and creating a new poverty level in our suburban areas.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will work toward an Assurance to the people that Interest Rates will not alter except in a Downward trend when the rate of inflation declines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the state of New South Wales who respectfully showeth their anger and condemnation at the unrealistic low priority given to children's vocation programs and other children's services which has resulted in the withdrawal of funds from programs which provide an essential community service.
We protest at the disastrous effects this will have on parents and children.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House provide public funding for all children's services including vacation programs to ensure quality services are available for all children and parents who require it.
further that funds be immediately released to prevent closure of vocation programs for the 1981-82 financial year.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry Mr Nixon M.P.-

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent and that at the 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Subject to negotiations of details the Government has decided that Australia is to purchase the aircraft carrier HMS Invincible from the United Kingdom to replace HMAS Melbourne.The plan is to take delivery of the ship in late 1983. On commissioning into the Royal Australian Navy, the ship will be renamed. The purchase price of the Invincible is #175m sterling, which at the August 1981 exchange rate was $285m. This was quoted as a firm price not subject to escalation. The total project costs, including provision for spares, test and training equipment, necessary modifications and other support, but excluding missiles, is estimated at $478m at August 1981 prices and exchange rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The acquisition of this ship will enhance our manifest capability to deter aggression in our neighbouring regions in the decades ahead. Air power is fundamental to maritime operations. This can be provided by either, or both, shore-based and sea-borne aircraft. The value of shore-based aircraft to Australia's maritime defence will remain of particular importance for as far ahead as one can see. The carrier will provide the Government of the day with additional options, particularly in areas further from our shores and remote from our military airfields. The importance of this cannot be over-emphasised for a country like Australia surrounded on three sides by vast oceans, and dependent for its very livelihood upon trade carried in ships. There is no single scenario or contingency for which this ship is being acquired. In fact our Defence Force as a whole is not structured to meet one particular threat. There is a wide variety of circumstances which could occur during the lifetime of this ship. Our manifest ability to deter threats from developing into a conflict, and, if necessary, our ability to win out in a conflict, if it were to result, must remain of prime importance to Government.

The importance of Australia's being able to stand on its own feet and fend for itself in regional defence matters has been emphasised and generally accepted for some years now. There is nothing singular about this. It does, however, involve a heavier burden than earlier policies such as forward defence. The Government freely acknowledges this and believes it is a burden which we must be prepared to pay in this very unsettled world. The decision concerning this ship follows the decision taken in 1980, and announced by me in this House at the time, to acquire a purpose-built ship to replace HMAS Melbourne. I also announced that contracts would be let for funded studies of three designs-the Sea Control ship, the Italian Garibaldi class helicopter carrier and a variant of the United States Iwo Jima class. The Invincible class design was not selected for further study because of its relatively high cost. However, following a British decision last year to retain only two of three Invincible class ships for the Royal Navy, the British Government offered HMS Invincible to Australia at a lower, and more than competitive, price.

The early availability of HMS Invincible will also allow the refit of HMAS Melbourne, scheduled for 1982-83, to be cancelled. The Melbourne will be paid off as soon as practicable to save refit and running costs. This will also enable retraining for the new ship's company. The acquisition of a purpose- designed ship provides a basis upon which to retain and further develop a core of skills which could be used in response to an emergency or a contingency; it provides both flexibility for response and a basis for expansion. Later options for expansion would not be confined to the acquisition of purpose-designed carriers, but could include the conversion of merchant ships for limited roles. This was done with good results in World War II.

The acquisition of the Invincible should not be seen merely as a replacement for Melbourne. The Invincible is a very modern ship with a wide range of capabilities quite beyond those now available to us. Firstly, the ship is particularly suited to operating and maintaining large anti-submarine helicopters. Investigations have shown that to counter a submarine threat a combination of weapon platforms is necessary. This combination includes land- based maritime aircraft, ASW helicopters and warships. There is no simple solution. While one or two anti-submarine helicopters can operate from a specialised destroyer, examinations have shown it is more cost effective to group a number of helicopters together in a larger ship with centralised command and control, maintenance and support facilities.

Secondly, there is a need for a ship capable of planning, commanding and co- ordinating operations by a group of ships and aircraft. Melbourne is no longer adequate for this task and other ships lack the means. About 25 personnel will require living and working space for planning and control with extra communications and dedicated command displays. Thirdly, the ship has the capacity to carry for a short period a Royal Marine commando-the equivalent of an Australian battalion group. This could be a very useful adjunct to our amphibious ship, HMAS Tobruk. Further, the ship is capable of operating short take-off and vertical landing aircraft of the Harrier type, although at present it is intended only, I repeat only, to embark ASW helicopters. The ship is fitted with a ski jump to improve the performance of Sea Harrier types, but could not operate conventional carrier aircraft. The decision of whether to acquire this type of aircraft will be made at a later date.

I now turn to some details of this ship. The complement, including the air group, of about 950 men should be at least 300 fewer than the Melbourne. The precise number depends on the composition of the air groups. The ship is driven by Olympus gas turbine engines. These are not used elsewhere in the Defence Force but will be serviced in an existing facility for maintaining Olympus industrial engines in Victoria. Unlike steam propulsion systems, a defective gas turbine engine can be changed by a ship's staff in about 48 hours. The Invincible is fitted with the Link II command data exchange system. It is fully compatible with that fitted to our guided missile destroyers, our P3C Orion aircraft and planned for our guided missile frigates. The ship is suitable for commanding an Australian task group and has already been proved in this role with United States and other Northern Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces in the Atlantic.

A limit of cost of $50m is to be allowed for RAN modifications. These will include adding 450 tonnes of fuel to increase the ship's operating range to meet our basic requirement. Whilst the living accommodation is of a very high standard and air-conditioned for tropical service, space, weight and power provisions exist to up-rate this accommodation within the modifications limit if tropical trials later this year should show this to be necessary. There will also be other minor changes, for example to communications equipment, to transfer some items from HMAS Melbourne and the removal of unwanted items. The question of whether or not to retain the Sea Dart area air-defence missile system will be the subject of a special study.

I would now like to lay at rest some popular misconceptions about the ship and aircraft carriers in general. The alternative of getting a ship for operating conventional carrier aircraft, such as the FA18, now on order to replace the Mirage, is not an option for us. Modern aircraft of the weight of the FA18 require a large deck with catapults and arresting gear. There is no ship available and even the smallest practicable would be far beyond our means both to acquire and man. Vulnerability is an oft quoted concern of many. I reject this. A ship of this nature normally operates as part of a group exploiting the principle of concentration of force. Such a group has an integrated and mutually supportive range of offensive and defensive systems. The precise composition would depend on the perceived threat, but in any case would be very formidable. The ship itself, being purpose-built, has a good degree of system redundancy and water-tight integrity. The design has specifically addressed minimising the effects of battle damage.

It is often asked: is one carrier enough? In present circumstances the answer is yes. Our Defence Force must be properly balanced; one carrier is adequate for lower-level contingencies and, like the rest of our capabilities, would provide a sound basis for expansion. In a diverse maritime threat, for instance, shore- based air would be used where it could be most effective and our one carrier used further afield where its special capabilities were needed. Our Defence Force must be one coherent whole. I entirely reject the concepts sometimes espoused of all submarines or all patrol boats. Each weapon system had advantages and each its limitations.

This statement would be incomplete without mention of Australian industry participation. As the ship is already built, clearly opportunities are naturally restricted. However the United Kingdom Government has given an offset undertaking amounting to #Stg17.5m. Australian industry will also be given opportunities to participate in ship support work to the value of 25 per cent of orders placed. I wish to assure the House that the costs of the carrier will not be at the expense of our program for the development of the Defence Force, although it may be necessary to do some rescheduling. Taking all factors into account this almost new ship-one of a class of three-is a very cost-effective method of meeting Australia's defence needs.

It remains for me to express the Australian Government's appreciation of the assistance and patience shown by Her Majesty's British Government in the consideration of this considerable project. For myself I am deeply grateful to my colleague the Rt Hon. John Nott, the British Minister for Defence. Finally, may I express my personal thanks to the many officers within the Department of Defence who have worked long hours over a long period in advising on the project . I present the following paper:
Aircraft Carrier purchase-Ministerial statement, 25 February 1982.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The long running serial of the purchase of HMS Invincible has come to a rather unsatisfactory end with the statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). Regrettably the Minister's statement does not contain the types of information the Parliament is entitled to expect on a purchase which has the long term consequences for defence planning that this vessel will have. I do not accept the Minister's assurances that the aircraft carrier is not vulnerable. It has no defensive mechanisms of its own in respect of skimmer-type missiles. It is incapable in the form in which we are purchasing it of defending itself against long-range bombers of the Backfire type if it were to operate, as the Minister suggests, at long range from Australian land- based airfields.

SPEECH.PARA: The aircraft carrier has a lack of electronic equipment and is not necessarily compatible, as is said, with aircraft and our frigates. In fact the first three FFG-class vessels do not have data linkages because they were removed at the request of the Australian Government as a cost-saving exercise. Therefore, if the data linkage on the Invincible is adequate that certainly does not make it compatible with vessels which do not have adequate data linkages. I would question the adequacy because of statements which have been made that the British Navy was forced to use the Bristol, a destroyer escort vessel, in order to provide data links in exercises which were performed with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces. The carrier itself did not have these data linkages.

The range of the carrier is below that which the Navy set out as being required although I know it now has changed that requirement to accommodate the range of the Invincible. The cost of the aircraft carrier on a basic design factor basis is obviously cheap. But nothing is cheap if it is not what one requires. To sell a pensioner a Rolls Royce at $5,000 would not be cheap if that person could not afford to maintain that vehicle but could afford to maintain a vehicle which may have cost the same amount and is more closely allied to his needs.

The opportunity costs for Australian defence in the longer period and the effect on rescheduling, as the Minister has said in his very quick slipping-over of that matter, could be devastating for the overall availability of Australian defence capacity. I accept the Minister's figures because we have no other basis on which to make any assessments. The information which has been made available to this House and to the community in general is nil plus nothing. The total cost is $478m. This includes the cost of the aircraft carrier, spares, support, and some minor conversions which are mentioned in the Minister's statement. I understand that the figure does not include helicopters, the cost of which would add about $110m to $120m to the project cost. I would assume if we are buying an aircraft carrier we are intending to use it as a platform of some description as a minimum. Earlier statements indicate that at least it is intended to include helicopters. Therefore we are talking about $116m for helicopters.

I think it would be ludicrous to suggest that a carrier could carry out some of the tasks mentioned by the Minister without fixed-wing aircraft. It is necessary then to look at the availability and cost of fixed-wing aircraft. In this regard there are two potential purchases. The first is the Harrier aircraft which is available but which has a limited military capacity and certainly would not enable the carrier to defend itself in a military situation. It is not an aircraft which could operate against any land-based or carrier-based aircraft which would be likely to be in the region of its operations. The Harrier aircraft has limited range.

Documents indicate-this is not referred to in the Minister's statement-that it is intended to transfer HMAS Melbourne's radar units to the new carrier. Those units are of a Dutch design which I understand were quite good at the time of fitting. However, they are currently out of production and therefore they are moving into the obsolescent stage at the moment. The units have an operational limitation of a 100-mile radius which will place the radar capacity of the new vessel below that of any attack weapons system which may seek to threaten the carrier. The carrier is extremely vulnerable. It is vulnerable to weapons of the harpoon missile type. It has no defences whatsoever. Although that is not stated in this ministerial statement, one would expect that at a future stage we will be told that phalanxes or similar defensive mechanisms would be fitted. That has not been included in the price. I should think that is because the price was reduced to a minimum for the purpose of selling the commitment.

I return to the aircraft. The American AV8B, which is in the development stage and probably is the aircraft that will be looked at, is a strike aircraft. It has about twice the capacity of the Harrier but it totally lacks radar and also would have great difficulty in providing adequate defence, given the numbers of aircraft that can be carried, the extreme vulnerability of the aircraft carrier and the carrier's lack of electronic support systems which would enable it to integrate operations. As I said earlier, its integration-its use as a command vessel, its use as a military weapons system-would depend upon support vessels being available at all times in order to provide a total capability.

The Minister mentioned task forces. It is likely that at least three vessels will become necessary in order to provide protection for the carrier. I repeat that it has no protection of its own. If we purchased aircraft at currently estimated prices, the cost of the AV8B type would be in excess of $500m, on a project cost basis, for about a dozen aircraft, which would be the absolute minimum that could be purchased with any justification. We are really talking about a program involving a minimum of $1,000m plus if we are to have in operation a weapons system which utilises to at least some extent its full capabilities. Where does that fit into the defence budget without there being major deferrals, without damaging the program of re-equipment of the present defence forces?

We are already committed to a major program in respect of the F18. We have an announced program for Orion P3Cs. At this stage that program is at least subject to some doubt because of the situation of the United States of America relating to future orders for that aircraft. But assuming that program is to go through and assuming that the costs do not escalate in the manner suggested in some quarters-I know there are denials of that as well, but usually predictions of cost escalations turn out to be true-is that program to be interfered with? Is it to be subject to slippage? What is the current state of the follow-on destroyer program? Fairly obviously, it will suffer from slippage as a result of this expenditure which does not fit readily into the budgetary projections for defence expenditures. We have not been given by the Minister-unfortunately, we are not given at any stage-a projection of defence expenditure over a number of years so that we can examine what moneys are available to be expended during that period.

This is a vague statement. Whoever wrote it was wearing the most rosy coloured glasses one could imagine. It is designed to place at ease those who are ill at ease and to provide the minimum possible information. The carrier purchase has not been justified as a defence purchase by this statement or by any argument which has been put before this House or, to my knowledge, has been put publicly. It is in the Rolls Royce-the prestige-category. What purpose does a carrier which does not have the capacity to defend itself against land-based aircraft serve in projecting our foreign policy aims-that has to be what is meant by the Minister's statement-outside the immediate regions of Australia? Where will it be utilised and for what purpose?

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you get the NATO results?
—I am aware that electoral considerations are involved for the honourable member, but I do not believe that that is the basis on which to decide to spend public funds of this order.
—Didn't you read the NATO results?
—I read the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation results. It was talking of a two-ship concept.
—Did they intercept Russian vessels or didn't they?
—Order! Interjections are out of order.

—Were they at war or were they not? The matters we are considering involve the shape and form of the Australian defence forces for the future. The Government has decided to go for large, spectacular items of equipment and to ignore the smaller, more essential items of equipment which our defence forces are totally lacking and which are not even in prospect. No surface-to-air missiles of any capacity exist in Australia. The only surface-to-air defence missiles are the Rapiers with which the Army is equipped. In fact, before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence the Chief of the Defence Force Staff said: 'We used to have one but I think we gave it away'. We used to have one surface-to-air missile.

SPEECH.PARA: In this day and age of precision weapons, of electronic warfare, of bombers that fly faster than fighters, where do our defences stand when not only do we not have surface-to-air missiles but also we do not have any intentions of purchasing surface-to-air missiles? I base that on the Minister's answers given in this House. The Army lacks anti-tank weapons. They are not included in the five-year program, according to the Minister. The Army's artillery is, to say the least, out of date and currently is subject to slippages of at least a further two years. In fact, it has been stated that the Citizen Military Forces will not receive new medium guns before the end of this decade. There are practically no guns which would stand up to utilisation in warfare at the moment .

However, the proposal to buy a carrier can sail through all the committees in the Department of Defence and all the political machinations, and we can have it acquired in a few months without any rational or reasonable explanation being given to this House. The question is: Why is that so? I think it is up to the Minister to come into this House and give us a detailed and comprehensive reason for purchasing a carrier and an indication of where it fits into our projected or anticipated defence needs. At the moment it will be an absorber of defence capacity, not an extender of defence capacity. If, as the Minister said and as we accept, Australia is responsible and must accept responsibility for its own defences, as stated in the Guam document-if we must depend on our own capabilities-this is not a purchase which meets that criterion. I quote what one of the Government members said on this matter this week. I refer to Senator MacGibbon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Biggles.

—Of course, if he disagrees with the honourable member he is claimed to be incompetent, even though the honourable member does not know what he is talking about. This is what Senator MacGibbon said about the judgments which lead to acceptance by the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: I say this with the greatest regret but I think the senior levels of the Royal Australian Navy fail to appreciate the revolution in weapons systems technology which has taken place at sea. I think this tragic in respect of the purchase of very large capital ships.

My final comment is this: If Australia finds herself in a hostile situation, any nation capable of posing a threat to Australia will have the capacity to remove the carrier from our military inventory without any trouble whatsoever. It is totally vulnerable to any nation which has the capacity to threaten Australia. We are buying a white elephant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the opportunity to follow the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) as he is the person whom I take to be the spokesman for the Australian Labor Party on defence matters. I say 'take to be' because he failed to repeat some of the promises made by the Labor Party about the Invincible. He failed to repeat the promises made by his leader that the Labor Party would sell this ship if it were acquired. I think the Labor Party owes it to the nation and certainly to the defence forces to state clearly once again whether it will carry out its promise to sell this ship if by some misfortune the Labor Party happens to gain office. I challenge the Labor Party to make such a statement. It was all very well to make it some time before the purchase. Let us see whether the Labor Party has the stomach to destroy Defence Force morale by repeating that promise.

SPEECH.PARA: It is intriguing to hear the Labor Party lecture this Government or any other Government on the proper conduct of defence spending. This Opposition, when in government, was responsible for the reduction of defence spending as a proportion of Budget expenditure to the low level that figures available from the Parliamentary Library show. Defence spending went down to 8.5 per cent of Budget spending.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. If the figures have come from the Parliamentary Library, I suggest the honourable member table the document.
—There is no point of order.

—I am only too willing to table the bits of paper that the Parliamentary Library presented to me. The defence group of the research service has gone back into the figures as far as it could go. For example, in the days of the honourable member for St George as a Minister in the Labor Govenment defence spending dropped from 12.8 per cent to 12 per cent, to 10.8 per cent, to 9.1 per cent. It dropped to the abysmal level of 8.5 per cent in the Budget presented by the man who is now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). That was the record of the Labor Party in defence spending. It is a record of a party which is now lecturing us about the proper sort of equipment. It is a party, which if approval were required before any defence purchases took place, would have our Defence Force bereft of any major item of equipment. Look at Labor's record on the F18 aircraft or the F111 aircraft. If in fact this nation depended on the agreement of the Labor Party for Defence Force decisions this nation would be defenceless. The campaign of denigration of this ship that has been persisted in by the Leader of the Opposition and by the honourable member for Corio is incredible. We have heard such massively intellectual contributions to the debate as that from the Leader Opposition who said that this ship 'is no more useful than an admiral's barge'. I wonder whether the Leader of the Opposition has bothered to inform himself of the way this ship performed in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation trials. This ship performed in conjunction with American forces in a simulated war situation and achieved outstanding results. Yet all we get from the Opposition is a campaign of continual denigration.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard once again from the honourable member for Corio this nonsense, these non-facts which are listed as complaints, about this ship's alleged incapacity. In fact this ship, particularly after a modest $5m worth of modifications meets all the requirements of the Royal Australian Navy that have been listed in the replacement program for HMAS Melbourne. Yet we have heard continually from the Opposition that this ship is totally inadequate in terms of range, that it is a sitting duck, that it needs a fixed-wing aircraft to be in any way effective and that almost everything is inadequate. The facts clearly demonstrate that in every particular these accusations are totally false. The ships range with the addition of a 450-tonne tank certainly is within the requirements of the Navy. Its speed is faster than the Navy's requirements. It is in fact certainly not a sitting duck, as the NATO exercise shows. It has the capacity to intercept all manner of attack on it. The significant thing that emerged from this exercise is that its Sea Dart missile system, which has been denigrated by the Opposition in this House, in fact performed so well that now, as I understand it, there is serious reconsideration of the original proposition that perhaps this system should be removed. As I understand it, the Navy is now looking very seriously at the possibility of retaining this very effective missile system.

When one looks at the nature of the attack on the Invincible and the style of the comments that have been made one can see that there has been a concerted policy of denigration of this ship, of denigration of the role of the fleet air arm, of denigration of the Navy itself. I wonder what sort of comfort that kind of denigration gives to our potential enemies. I wonder what kind of support and succour that gives to the members of our Defence Force who listen to this kind of attack against the basis of the savage cuts in the defence spending as a proportion of total Budget expenditure during the period that the Labor Opposition was in power. When one puts all these factors together one genuinely wonders what is the Labor party's approach to the whole question of defence.

Let me just put at rest some of the nonsensical propositions that have been put about this ship by the Opposition. In the first place we have heard it said that it is in fact totally inadequate and unreliable in a sense for Australian conditions. The fact is that it was designed for world-wide operations, not just for the North Sea and the North Atlantic. Since its commissioning in June 1980 the ship has been undergoing trials appropriate to any new class of ship. It has not yet undergone its tropical trials; there is no doubt about that. These trials are scheduled to take place later this year. There is no doubt that while some of the requirements, such as water temperature, of the Royal Australian Navy may be more stringent than those applying to the ship at the moment, the ship's air conditioning is likely to prove quite satisfactory to our environment . In any event, there is space and power to add increased air conditioning if necessary. The aviation facilities of Invincible are very comprehensive and are determined to be adequate for the Navy's needs. The Invincible can carry up to 22 aircraft consisting of a mix of ASW helicopters and short take-off and vertical landing aircraft. By comparison, HMAS Melbourne can accommodate 13 aircraft in a hangar with a further seven on deck.

The proposed initial RAN modifications to be made to this ship on delivery total not more than $5m. I thin it is absolutely essential to keep reminding this House and to keep reminding this House and to keep reminding the Opposition that the continued allegations that it would cost us a fortune to convert this ship to our needs, that there would be an escalating price factor, once again repeated here today, are absolute nonsense. The proposed modifications include the installation of radar interrogation equipment which will be removed from HMAS Melbourne and which is totally adequate, despite what the honourable member for Corio has said. Let us face it, it is difficult to reply in debate to a spokesman on defence matters who repeats statements which are totally untrue, which are assertions of fact without any substantiation whatsoever and which set out to denigrate this ship and to diminish its standing in the eyes of the people.

Among the other things which will be done to this ship in this $5m conversion program include the installation of aircraft navigation equipment which is to be removed from HMAS Melbourne and the removal of the submarine protection sonar which is already on the ship because, in effect, it appears that it may well give more of a lead to attackers than act as a safety device. There will be an increased fuel capacity of 450 tonnes to provide an additional 1,000 nautical mile range and there will be minor communications changes to achieve compatibility with existing RAN systems. The essential point is that after these modifications have been made there will be compatibility with the communications systems of the Australian fleet and, more importantly in terms of joint exercises, with the American fleet whenever we are involved in such exercises or in effect in a wartime situation if the Americans are our allies.

It is nonsense for the honourable member for Corio to repeat the allegation that this ship needs another destroyer or frigate travelling alongside to translate her messages for her. That is absolute and arrant nonsense. It is clearly evident that the systems in the ship, when it is the lead ship in the Australian Navy, will be adequate to cope totally with communications within our Navy and, in fact, with the American Navy. That is provided for by the adjustments and modifications to which the $5m figure refers. Invincible has some excellent warship qualities which would not have been available in alternative ship designs under consideration as a replacement for HMAS Melbourne . These include extremely flexible and versatile propulsion and electrical generating systems, a high level of automation, special communication facilities , a very effective degaussing system and a citadel for gas tight and nuclear fall-out protection.

In regard to escalating costs, there is no doubt that, when one orders a ship or a plane from a builder, one runs the risk of incurring escalating costs. Honourable members of this House know that. They have seen it occur on many occasions, but to put up that Aunt Sally among all the others that the honourable member for Corio put up is absolutely nonsensical in this situation. The ship has been built. It is at sea. It has proven itself in North Atlantic Treaty Organisation exercises as an effective war machine. We know the sail-away price. It is #Stg175m. It cannot be increased. This ship will cost only about the same as a destroyer. The other costs involved, which lift its total price in Australian dollar terms to about $480m are related basically to expenditures which are to be met in Australia. They relate particularly to support systems, say at HMAS Albatross where, for example, the aviation support will certainly be provided and where, I hope, there will be a requirement for additional expansion and upgrading in order to cope with the special needs of HMS Invincible.

No doubt these other costs will be highlighted by the Opposition but elements of these principal initial project costs would include the refit and trials that the ship must go through, the purchase and manufacture of spares, the establishment of support capacity, the cost of training and the cost of assisting Australian industry in establishing capacity for support. It is vital to recognise that any analysis of the through life costs of running HMS Invincible along with the very cheap initial capital costs show that Invincible is a far cheaper acquisition than any of the alternative designs which were under consideration.

For the benefit of Australian manufacturers who may have been concerned that the purchase of an existing ship would diminish their capacity to be involved in defence contracts, I think we should recognise and be grateful for the fact that the United Kingdom Government has accepted an offset undertaking amounting to about #Stg17,500,000 after the event of purchase. Australian industry will be offered opportunities to participate in ship support work to the value of 25 per cent of orders placed pursuant to a memorandum of understanding.

The key point about this ship is that currently it is in Royal Navy service. Her characteristics and performance are known to be outstandingly successful. For any member to come into this House and denigrate the ship when it is evident that her performance has been so outstanding is to set out upon a course which denigrates, I believe, the capacity of our service to operate her effectively. This is an outstanding ship and has been proved to be so. The campaign of denigration by the Opposition is, I believe, a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to correct a misrepresentation of a portion of my speech.
-The honourable gentleman may proceed.

—The honourable member who has just resumed his seat said, in the course of his remarks, that I said that the base price, as stated in the papers, would escalate. That is not true. I accepted the $478m as stated. I said that there were additional costs, amounting to over $600m, which had not been stated in the statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen).

—I have just been totally misrepresented. I did not say what the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) alleged I said. I said that there is no prospect of the total cost exceeding the figures given in the statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) because we know the basic price and have a clear statement of what the in-Australia price costs are. The honourable member for Corio appears to be using this as an opportunity to try to create, once again, the phoney proposition that there will be additional costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, we are discussing a very large acquisition for the Navy, a quite expensive undertaking. Therefore, there seems to be some appropriateness in having just heard from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), one of the great parliamentary windjammers of our time. What is clear for those of us here who have some interest in, and certainly some knowledge of, the subject of defence, is that the honourable member for Macarthur's knowledge and interest in that subject is exclusively related to the defence of the electorate of Macarthur.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of his contribution to the debate-I am in a rather generous frame of mind today-he claimed that Invincible had proved its capacity for worldwide operations and had met all trials. That is nonsense and the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) nails that nonsense because in his statement he pointed out, among other things, that the vessel had yet to undertake its tropic trials. The honourable member lauds the capacity of the Dart missile. The Minister is so confident of the Dart missile that he acknowledges that the Government might well remove it. The honourable member is not even aware that the ramp on Invincible is inadequate for operational requirements of AV-8Bs and in the event of those sorts of fixed wing aircraft being supplied to the vessel the ramp would have to be replaced at considerable cost.

I come now to the heart of the more substantial misrepresentation by the honourable member. In the course of his early comments he claimed that expenditure on capital acquisitions under the last Labor Government decreased and quoted some statistics. In the course of that observation he imputed that the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) who was one of Australia's best Defence Ministers, was responsible for that run-down. The facts are that expenditure on capital acquisition programs at any given time reflects decisions made in earlier years. Of course there was under the Labor Government a run-down of expenditure on capital acquisitions because the preceding conservative government had allowed defence orders to run down. Under the honourable member for St George, as Defence Minister, new orders as a proportion of spending, increased. There was, in fact, a substantial amount of capital equipment acquired by the Government succeeding the last Labor Government because it was ordered by the honourable member for St George and Mr Lance Barnard who preceded him in the office of Minister for Defence.

The decision to acquire HMS Invincible is a serious blunder. It proves that the wrong people won the argument and that Australia will get the wrong defence equipment. HMS Invincible is the 'Spruce Goose' of the Australian naval defence force. The 'Spruce Goose' was, of course, Howard Hughes's military aviation museumpiece that could never become airborne. HMS Invincible will never be adequately operational for Australian defence needs in peacetime and will be totally inappropriate and quite inadequate in the event of conflict. What this boils down to is an extravagant $2,000m-plus status symbol for the gold braid at the top of the Australian navy. They do not even comprehend the developments that have been undertaken in recent years in weapons technology at sea. If they did, they would never have fought to obtain this piece of naval equipment. Only a badly managed rich country with no real defence threat could be so blimpishly indulgent as to make this disastrous decision. It proves that war and defence are too important to be left in the hands of admirals.

In fiscal terms this purchase will have devastating consequences. The Fraser Government issues the orders for these items of equipment but succeeding governments will have to pay for them. They will not be conservative governments . The outlay for new capital equipment on our external account over the course of this decade will exceed $10,000m. That will occur in a decade in which there will be serious strains on the balance of payments. I forecast that in speeches in this House some two years ago. I reminded the House of this last year when the decision was made to buy the new tactical fighter aircraft and I remind the House of it again. These sorts of blindly undertaken decisions inadequately thought through either in terms of their appropriateness for the defence requirements of this nation or their implications for fiscal strain on the Australian economy will have serious consequences for Australia in the future. The Invincible does not project sea-air power. The Minister made that claim but it does not stand up in fact. One of these aircraft carriers will not be enough for the defence needs of this country. It is too vulnerable, it will tie up too much surface equipment, it is too slow and it will result in Australia losing some $70m in Australian industry programs, which should have been available for Australian industry and to provide jobs. It is a tragic decision that will stifle future defence development and which will expose the potential defence requirements of this nation-

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you sell it?

—Of course I will. I state that clearly once again because that is an intelligent response. I will have to say it three times before it sinks in to the honourable member. This aircraft carrier will operate with dinasaurian grace and vulnerability. It will be a hostage to an environment of modern warfare because it just does not belong in the modern warfare environment. I give the House some evidence to justify what I have said. At cruising speed-18 knots-it will take about five days to get from Sydney to Darwin. What is supposed to happen in that five-day period between when it leaves Sydney and gets to Darwin? Are we supposed to send letters or, perhaps to keep the technology analagous, send smoke signals to any potential enemy while we make arrangements to get it there? I repeat, one of these carriers would not be enough.
—The top speed is 28 knots. It is deliberate deception.

—'Deliberate deception' says the honourable member for Macarthur, who is a master with his literary skills in this field. He is the only millionaire in the Parliament who has made his money through deceptive literary skills. At least two carriers would be required for a one coast effective force and three would be required if we were to have an effective force on both the east and west coasts. I said before that the Invincible cannot effectively project air power. The Minister's speech does not even commit the Government to having fixed wing aircraft attached to the carrier. The only available aircraft, the Sea Harrier, has strictly limited capabilities-450 nautical miles for reconnaissance , 280 nautical miles in an anti-ship role, 90 minutes in carrier air patrols and only three minutes combat capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: We are being sold a pig in a poke. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports ( Mr Holding) referred to it as being more appropriately called HMAS Colonial Queen. One would have to be a sucker to buy something like this. The aircraft have very poor radar, covering only about 20 nautical miles. They will be totally dependent on the carrier's radar, which is apparently to come from HMAS Melbourne. It has a range of only 100 nautical miles. Many modern anti-ship missiles have a range well beyond that. I recall, from being on HMAS Melbourne not so long ago, that the radar facilities are vastly outmoded. The Harrier, therefore, is dependent on the carrier for radar, interception and guidance. It has no data link and has only very vulnerable voice communication. It has subsonic performance only. I will not go into all the details. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) has already given details of these deficiencies.

The aircraft carrier is gravely inadequate in an operational sense for any defence requirement of this country, even in the specific role which it is supposed to fulfil. I repeat that that role is not an appropriate role for Australia's defence. It is vulnerable. Certainly it is designed to operate in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation fleet in the North Atlantic but with land based air cover, with airborne early warning systems and large numbers of other naval units, none of which it will have here. Since the Navy apparently is not installing the Phalanx point defence system, it will be exposed to skimmer missiles such as Cruise missiles launched from submarines. In the 1976 Defence White Paper it was declared by the Minister for Defence that only submarines can successfully operate when local air superiority cannot be established. The Harrier cannot do that in circumstances of serious attack. To protect our long range trade routes we should rely on not one highly vulnerable, highly expensive item of equipment which, when it is sunk, will leave a very big gap in our defence capability. We should rely on the development of strategic stockpiles and the fact that most of our cargo is carried in foreign bottoms. Closer to home, submarines and land based air power is the most cost effective way of establishing our defence. In any event, the mercantile vessels which come to this country can travel well to the south and avoid the problem of hostile naval vessels, surface or sub-surface.

We have not been given the full facts on the cost. The full facts are that the total cost of this program will exceed $2,000m. The Harrier aircraft will exceed $700m, the carrier will cost nearly $500m, the helicopters which will have to be acquired will cost nearly $100m and there will have to be additional vessels, such as a fleet replenishment vessel, which will cost $100m. At least three to four frigates will be required at a cost of $750m to $1,000m. So, it becomes a splurge of between $2,100m and some $2,400m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like your health costs.

—The honourable member for Macarthur has a very nice face but that is an awfully expensive face to save in the electorate of Macarthur-some $2,100m to $2,400m for a defence arrangement which will be totally inadequate and totally irrelevant to any potential needs we may have in some foreseeable situation. The operating costs will be the same as those for HMAS Melbourne; that is, $14m a year. At least the Melbourne has the virtue of being clapped out. It cannot avoid the high costs of operation. An Iwo Jima carrier would operate at about $ 8m a year, a saving of some $6m or nearly 50 per cent. Where is the cost effectiveness that the Government is always rubbing in?

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell honourable members of the options we prefer to look at. Two squadrons of Orions, at 10 to a squadron, would cost $250m a squadron. An Oberon class submarine or something similar would cost about $80m. The Germans now have a prototype which I understand is superior to the Oberon; it has more fire power , more range, more speed and fewer crewmembers. We would use corvettes of about 1,500 tonnes, with a speed of up to 30 knots an hour at a cost of $200m to $250m each, in a maritime attack role. They would have small helicopters and a full blue water capability. All that can be put together for much less than the cost of this particular aircraft carrier with the attendant commitments that are necessary. We could get two squadrons of Orions, four corvettes and 10 submarines for about $1,700m. We would then have a far more flexible, more numerous, more adaptable and certainly much less vulnerable naval force using far fewer crewmembers than is proposed now.

There are some figures in the Minister's speech which, frankly, have a rubbery quality about them. The Minister declared that this particular vessel has a range of some 7,000 nautical miles at a speed of 18 knots. That is rather curious because Jane's Fighting Ships points out that at 18 knots it has a range of only 5,000 nautical miles. To persuade Government members to support him, the Minister circulated a document which claimed that HMAS Melbourne at 24 knots had a maximum range of only 7,000 nautical miles. If one looks at Jane's Fighting Ships, again it is apparent that there must be some reservations as to the accuracy of those claims.

Australia's tragedy is that its defence planning does not proceed according to a coherent doctrine. Strategic thinking is threadbare and is based on antiquated assumptions. There is no clear and consistent exposition of why extraordinarily expensive acquisition programs are undertaken; of how acquired equipment fits into a balanced defence doctrine in which phased responses to different levels of threat can be adequately met and, least of all, whether there is optimum cost effectiveness in what is being done. What is abundantly clear is that too often the defence chiefs behave as if they were out on a shopping spree, spending on the brightest and the best to keep up with the defence Jones's of the world. That is inappropriate and we reject it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the Science and Technology Statement 1981-82. I seek leave to make a statement concerning this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1981-82 statement is a post-budget analysis of Commonwealth expenditure listed by agency, Ministry and by socio-economic objectives. Its aim is to provide a sound and comprehensive basis for analysing changes and trends, and for formulating policy. The 1981-82 statement contains research and development statistics covering four years. Direct Commonwealth funding of research and development increased from $620m in 1978-79 to $940m-projected-in 1981-82. This is about a 10 per cent increase over the four years in real terms. This significant real growth over the period has been shared over many areas. These include those concerned with energy research, funding directed towards manufacturing objectives, mining, health and agriculture. These figures, in times of severe financial constraint, demonstrate the Government's continuing commitment to research and development as an essential factor in national economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: Highlights

In the past year there have been a number of important developments in science and technology. The Department organised a successful biotechnology symposium, concentrating on the commercial applications of recombinant DNA techniques. The symposium brought together international experts and representatives of Australian business, academic and Government communities. An amended Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act took effect in July. The amended Act incorporates considerable changes and improvements, including higher ceilings for both project and commencement grants. In December, my Department released a discussion paper entitled 'The Bases for Science and Technology Policy' which examines the possible roles for Government in this field. The paper is an important step in developing a concensus on the concepts underlying science and technology policy. On another front, a Technological Change Committee has been established as a standing committee of the Australian Science and Technology Council. This was recommended by the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia.
Private Sector Research Development

The ratio of private sector to Government funding of research and development remains a matter of concern to the Government. In real terms, R and D expenditure by private enterprise fell by nearly 50 per cent between 1973-74 and 1976-77.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—I agree with the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). There was a small growth of 5 per cent in real terms between 1976-77 and 1978-79. However, in the same period manpower effort devoted to research and development by private enterprise fell by 7 per cent. I might stress that these are the latest figures we have. I think later figures would show a better position.

SPEECH.PARA: Private sector R and D spending as a percentage of the gross domestic product remains very low compared to other Western countries. Since the statement was prepared, more up to date international comparative data has become available. For the information of honourable members, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table illustrating the relative roles of the business and government sectors in the 15 largest R and D performing nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my tabling speech for the last statement, I stated that I would like to see the level of research and development spending by private enterprise more than double in this decade. Such an effort is essential if we are to compete internationally and yet it is a modest goal by the standards of other countries, as the table shows.

SPEECH.PARA: As well, I look forward to the Industries Assistance Commission report into the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme. I hope the report will enhance Government understanding of the effectiveness of the Scheme and its value to the economy. In another move, I have asked my Department to examine further ways of increasing the involvement of private industry in government- sponsored research and development. A nation without innovation succumbs to deterioration and decay.

The development of our own capability in industrial innovation must remain a high priority. Our vitality as a nation, and our ability to respond to rapidly changing demands, depend on our success in this task. Industrial innovation represents a major path by which science and technology can contribute to Australian economic progress. It must be stressed that only those firms which have developed their own research and development capability are able to effectively assess and utilise appropriate new technologies.

Australia cannot rely solely on buying new technology from overseas. However, it is unreal to expect Australia to generate all its own technology. Innovation is inherently difficult to foresee. New discoveries and emerging technologies can give rise to major industries in unexpected areas. The impact of the transistor and the growth of the silicon chip industry provide a powerful example. Biotechnology is a more recent case. Although sound research and development is a necessary foundation, successful innovation also depends on other complex market factors. Awareness of the role of market forces forms the basis of Government policy.

Although governments are motivated by high ideals, they are not ruled by the fundamental economic laws which guide the entrepreneur and the innovator. Industry must take the primary role in the innovation process. The Government's overall priority in encouraging innovation is to ensure an economic climate favourable to investment in research and development. Innovation and high technology policies must be viewed against the background of these macroeconomic objectives. Within this context, the Government will assist in maintaining a viable infrastructure for science and technology, including support of the free flow of technological information and skills.

Australia's long-term industrial future lies with a combination of resource development and the establishment of industries based on appropriate high technology. Microelectronics, robotics, biotechnology, new materials and information technologies are examples. High technology industries are strong performers in the critical areas of real growth, productivity, prices and employment. A study in the United States has shown that gains in labour productivity were twice those of low technology industries. Yet these gains were not made at the expense of employment. Jobs grew at an annual rate of eight times that of low technology industries. This is an experience Australia should seek to share.

Biotechnology is a direct example of the potential benefits of investment in high technology. Australia conducts world class research in this field and our scientific capability is highly developed. The prospects for biotechnology are revolutionary, and I urge Australian industry to respond to this opportunity.

These challenges are momentous. We must seek to develop effective policies in a climate of informed discussion. There has not been enough progress towards developing a community consensus on the role of science and technology in these complex social and economic issues. The Government has encouraged debate on these questions, believing that without consensus it will be difficult for Australia to meet these challenges adequately. There is a widely felt need to relate science and technology policies more closely with social, economic and industrial policies. The task is not an easy one. The science and technology statement is a key component in contributing to the basis for informed discussion on these issues. I commend the statement to the House.
Motion (by Mr Moore) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The science and technology statement for 1981-82 is accompanied by a tabling speech only half the length of the last effort of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) on 12 May 1981. The statement, that is the printed document, is a compendium of statistics and description of science and technology activities generally carried out by government departments with useful tables of comparative expenditure. The statement covers far more than the Department of Science and Technology and its satrapies, such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Antarctic Division. It provides details of projected high spenders for 1981-82 in research and development. Science and Technology itself, with 51 per cent; Defence with 16 per cent-money that is not well spent, to be sure, but still substantial; Education with 13 per cent, 87 per cent of it taken up by grants to universities; National Development and Energy with 6 per cent and Health with a comparatively low 5 per cent, leaving all other government departments to take up the remaining 9 per cent. Industry and Commerce spends less than 2 per cent of the total research and development vote-and it shows in our national performance in that area. Overall the printed statement is a useful , if dispiriting, handbook, with next to nothing on policy in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's tabling speech bears virtually no relationship to the printed statement. One can understand its brevity. It has been a tough year for the Minister and his Department. The razor gang was particularly tough on the Department of Science and Technology-of 18 bodies recommended for abolition, 11 were part of Science and Technology, including its valuable work on the impact of high technology on working conditions, and its study of technology transfer. Our scientific representation in London, Paris, Washington and Tokyo has been or will shortly be removed. We are standing still on a descending escalator. True, due to a last minute reprieve by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Budget cuts were not as savage as they might have been, but CSIRO came very close to being non-viable, and that would have been a national tragedy. The Government provided no money whatever for the Australian contribution to Starlab , the orbiting optical telescope which is one of the most exciting international projects Australia was ever involved in.

The table the Minister incorporated in Hansard indicates that in 1978-79 Australia spent 1.04 per cent of gross domestic product on gross expenditure on research and development. In science and technology as related to industrial development, the relevant figure is that in 1978-79 we spent only 0.93 per cent of GDP on research and development in the natural sciences and related areas. This is only fractionally higher than the figure for 1976-77 of 0.92 per cent and well below the figures for 1968-69 of 1.12 per cent and for 1973-74 of 1.18 per cent.

To put the matter in perspective, Australia's total expenditure on research and development is less than that of Eastman Kodak in the United States. In 1979 there was a Commonwealth Budget allocation of $450m to research and development- only 46 per cent of it through the Department of Science and Technology-while Kodak spent $459m in that year. General Motors spends each year four times as much as Australia, and IBM three times as much. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short table of the top 10 United States companies in research and development spending.
Leave granted.
