TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In research and development we are approaching the status of a Third World country, and this is accentuated, as the Minister's speech conceded, by the overwhelming control of high technology industries in Australia by foreign ownership. If research and development is carried out at head office, in the United States or Japan or Britain, there is little incentive to do basic or pure research here. In his speech on the 1980-81 statement the Minister referred repeatedly to the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme which clearly he saw as the hope of the side, and he made no reference at all to biotechnology. Now, nine months later, this is the year for biotechnological enthusiasm, with five references to it in the Minister's speech, and only one to the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth recalling that all the pressure to take biotechnology seriously has come from the Opposition. Let it not be forgotten that it was as recently as 31 March 1981 that a question to the Prime Minister about what the Government was doing to recognise the importance of biotechnology to Australia received the horse laugh in the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had never even heard of nitinol.

—That is right. The Prime Minister shoved the question off to his deputy, who in turn passed it down the line to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) who confessed in his disarming way that he had never heard of it. I was even castigated by some newspapers for asking a question about what was to them an utterly obscure subject. No one is laughing about biotechnology now, 11 months later. The Government's achievements in this area are two-it is spending $4.5m per annum in biotechnology research and it called a three-day symposium on its economic potential at the Hyatt Kingsgate Hotel in Sydney in November 1981. That is all. There has been no provision of venture capital and no collaboration with interested parties to set up a biotechnological consortium.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House that, by way of comparison, Canada plans to spend $483m in the next decade to establish a strong Canadian biotechnology industry. In Australia under the Fraser Government we are drifiting aimlessly. We have the potential to be a world leader in biotechnology, as the Minister well knows, but it is certain that without a Labor government this potential will disappear and the rich intellectual and economic rewards of biotechnological development will be reaped, yet again, by multinational corporations.

Our habitual diffidence in high technology areas was illustrated over and over again at the Sydney symposium. With depressing frequency I heard these kinds of exchanges when the possibility of setting up biotechnological industries for Australia was proposed: 'Are the Americans working in this field?' 'Yes'. 'Well, if the Americans are in it there's not much point in us trying to compete', or: 'Are the Americans working in this field?' 'No'. 'Well, if the Americans aren't in it then it can't be any bloody good'! We put the Indian sign on ourselves, and either way we are inclined to say: 'There is no point going ahead'.

There are some fundamental reasons for the low status and low priority given to science and technology by this Government. The first is the irreconcilability of the Minister's expressed aims to seek a consensus approach to the challenges of science and technology and the policies of the Government. He concedes that in his speech, saying:

There has not been enough progress towards developing a community consensus on the role of science and technology in these complex social and economic issues. The Government has encouraged debate on these questions, believing that without consensus it will be difficult for Australia to meet these challenges adequately .

Tell that to the Prime Minister. Tell it to the Treasurer (Mr Howard). Tell it to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). And while you are at it, tell it to the marines! This is a government led by a Prime Minister who has prided himself as the man who has ended political consensus. He has been the great advocate of the anti-consensus position, and in this he has been very strongly supported by the Minister for Industrial Relations.

The other point is, of course, that the Minister presides over a Department which, by its very nature, is interventionist. It cannot be anything else. One cannot have an effective Department of Science and Technology that is not interventionist. Yet the whole thrust, the whole gravamen, of the Treasury approach is that the resolution of important areas in science and technology should be left to market forces. That means that the race will be won by the swift and that Australia will have comparatively little opportunity to play any role other than a subordinate one.

The only worthwhile part of that miserable document by the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, the Myers report-one of the thinnest document intellectually, although it filled four fat volumes-ever produced even by this Government, is the proposal for a social safety net as a means of protecting victims of technological displacement. It was the only part of the report specifically rejected by this Government. How is it possible to say that we ought to be seeking consensus in this area when in that area of the social safety net, which was one of the few areas where we would have very willingly contributed to the consensus, the Government said: 'No, we are going to take an anti-consensus position'? Where is the evidence of seeking consensus by this Government? I exempt the Minister from this criticism, but from the other Ministers one sees no evidence of it. Where is the climate of informed discussion that he talks about? Where is the debate that the Minister says the Government has encouraged? When was it? I must have missed it..

I do not know anybody on our side of the House who was aware of it and I doubt whether anyone on the Government side could name the date, place and time either . It is absurd to pretend that there has been a continuing debate in which these issues have been argued out. I must say that I think that New Zealand's Commission for the Future-I do not always admire its government without reservation-has been successful in generating public debate over the last couple of years. Indeed, so successful is it that I understand Mr Muldoon is proposing to abolish it because the organisation has turned out to be much more effective in generating fundamental questioning of issues than expected.

The Minister referred with approval to the activities of the Australian Science and Technology Council. ASTEC was a Labor innovation and I wish I could share his enthusiasm for it. While some of its very specific reports have been of considerable value, its general reports, which could have been of great assistance, have been dismal, with all the crispness and freshness of week old lettuce leaves. The paper 'Basic Research and National Objectives' contained every known cliche except 'Gentlemen will please adjust their dress before leaving'. It was recognised as a disaster even by the Department of Science and Technology. That, as insiders will know, is saying a great deal. Under Labor ASTEC will be retained as a prime advisor but its membership will be expanded and rotated-and the present formula of confining Council membership to senior academics, businessmen and graziers will be changed. If ever there was an indication that Australia is not strictly a democracy as we normally think of the term but a bucolocracy-ruled by graziers-it is in the composition of the membership of ASTEC. Both there and in the Advisory Council of the CSIRO it is always assumed that graziers have some uncanny insight into the way in which Government and science works. If we look at the representation of graziers on the front bench of the Government we would be led to the same conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave the cockies alone.

—The honourable member for Werriwa is an aspiring grazier. ASTEC actually supported the proposed Natsemi silicon wafer plant the whole concept of which collapsed some weeks ago. This was an astonishingly bad piece of misjudgment on ASTEC's part. It was never viable. The technological change committee of ASTEC, set up as recommended by CITCA, is floundering already and I do not expect much from that quarter. The naivete of the advice given to the Minister is shown in his assertion that:

SPEECH.PARA: High technology industries are strong performers . . . in employment . . . Jobs grew at an annual rate of eight times that of low technology industry. This is an experience Australia should seek to share.

There is a fundamental statistical fallacy involved in that. The proposition is both technically correct and irrelevant at the same time. It is in the nature of infant industries to have high percentage rates in employment growth, even though the numbers are not great in absolute terms. In other words, starting from a zero base any kind of increase-for example, an increase of nobody doing a job to one person doing a job-is an infinite increase in employment and yet it does not mean that in absolute figures a very significant contribution has been made. A four-person firm which grows to 40 persons in two years has a 900 per cent increase and yet as a proportion of the labour force this growth is much less significant than, say a long term decline in a large firm which falls from 2,000 employees to 1,800.

The phenomenon in the United States of America has been that throughout the 1970s 13 million new jobs were created, mostly in low technology areas, and there was a net loss of 1.5 million jobs in manufacturing industry. There certainly was an enormous growth rate in Silicon Valley and elsewhere accompanied by a huge secular decline in employment in the old manufacturing States, such as Massachusetts and Ohio. High productivity is a synonym for labour shedding-it just means that output is high relative to total inputs, including labour. This statement is a profound disappointment. It reflects the way the Fraser Government has sabotaged the national interest in science and technology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 6 (1982).

The customs tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals No. 6 (1982), which operate from tomorrow, contain tariff changes resulting from the Government's decisions on recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission in its reports on springs and wire products, cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools. The Government has accepted the IAC recommendations contained in the report on springs and wire products except in respect of motor vehicle springs, which will be dutiable at 25 per cent and certain woven wire, horseshoe nails and certain pins for which minimum duty rates will continue.

The minor variations from the IAC's recommendations resulted from the Government's desire not to increase rates on certain goods not produced locally and where a significant volume of trade was involved. The effect of the recommendations accepted by the Government is that rates will be phased down over two or three years for goods such as stranded wire cables, other than those used as shafting for flexible transmissions, drawing pins and iron or steel springs, other than vehicle springs. There will be immediate increases in duty rates ranging from 19 to 23 percentage points for such goods as stranded wire cables of a kind used as shafting for flexible transmissions, springs and leaves for springs and woven wire of copper. There will be immediate decreases ranging from one to 19 percentage points for such goods as needles for hand sewing, bobby pins and springs used as original components in the manufacture of vehicles. Existing duty rates will be maintained for the other goods under reference.

The Government considered that the advantages from more efficient use of resources and lower costs to users, which were expected to result from the reduction in comparatively high levels of assistance, warranted acceptance of the IAC's recommendations. The Government had noted that the IAC did not expect acceptance of its recommendations to have any adverse effects on employment or activity in the industry.

In respect of the report on cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools, the Government has accepted all the recommendations of the IAC. The effect of this decision is that the duty rates on goods such as knives, spoons, forks and ladles will be reduced by between five and 10 percentage points after two years. There will be immediate increases in duty rates ranging from one percentage point for tool-tips to nine percentage points for goods such as rock drill bits and shears. There will be immediate decreases ranging from two percentage points for such goods as scissors and scissor blades to 14 percentage points for certain tools used in agriculture, horticulture or forestry. There will be no change in duties on files and rasps, spanners, trimming knives and furnace tapping steels.

The result of these proposals is to introduce a moderate overall reduction in duties and to introduce uniform rates of duty on certain closely related products. Acceptance of the IAC's recommendations is expected to lead to an improved industry structure with more efficient resource utilisation and some reductions in prices to consumers. The Government's decisions in relation to razor blades and the bounties on spanners and drill bits, also covered by this report, have already been announced. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Industries Assistance Commission report on cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools, springs and wire products.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Viner, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Tobacco Charge Act (No. 1) 1955 for the following purposes: To increase the rate of charge payable on sales of Australian tobacco leaf on and after 1 March 1982 from 1.1c to 2.5c per kilogram and to enable the rate of charge to be increased or decreased by regulation. The Bill is closely linked with the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Tobacco Charge Amendment Bill (No. 3) which will apply the rate of charge set under this Bill to Australian tobacco leaf purchased by manufacturers or grown and used by manufacturers. It is proposed that the three Bills be treated as cognate legislation.

At present the rate of charge paid by manufacturers is 2.2c per kilogram. The three principal Acts have, since 1955, established rates of charge to be paid by industry funds for research financed from the Tobacco Industry Trust Account established by the Tobacco Industry Act 1955. In 1965 the latter Act was amended so that part of the charges paid by growers and manufacturers could be appropriated to meet the cost of operation of the Australian Tobacco Board which was then being established. The balance of the amount collected continues to be appropriated to the Tobacco Industry Trust Account. The rates of charge were increased at the time from one halfpenny to three-fifths of a penny per pound. Since then there has been only a minor reduction effected in 1973 to 1.1c per kilogram.

The amount of money thus provided for research has been declining as the costs of operating the Australian Tobacco Board have risen in spite of substantial economies that have been effected. In more recent years there has been a further decline because it has been necessary for marketing quotas under the tobacco stabilisation plan to be reduced. An effect of this has been that research and extension programs in the three producing States have been pruned and rationalised over a period of several years. Even so the cost of basic programs has exceeded annual income and it has been necessary to draw on reserves accumulated in previous years and the proceeds of sales of real estate and assets which were no longer essential to the scaled down programs. The stage has been reached where remaining reserves would quickly be depleted and the current programs could not be maintained unless there were an injection of additional funds.

With the new proposals and at present marketing quota levels the industry will contribute about $250,000 more than it has been doing. The Commonwealth is prepared to continue matching expenditure of industry funds and so will contribute a like amount. Thus it will be possible to continue the current level of research for some years to come, drawing on reserves to some extent. The question of whether the Commonwealth should contribute to tobacco research has been asked before and will no doubt arise again. One of the decisions announced on 19 December 1980 following the Government's consideration of a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was that there would be discussions with the industry on redirection of funding for research into alternative varieties of tobacco leaf which have a less detrimental effect on health. There has been an increasing emphasis on plant breeding and on cultural practices which affect alkaloid levels in leaf. There is also some important work on resistance to insects and plant diseases to lessen dependence on the use of chemicals for control purposes.

It can be expected that there will be further emphasis on these essential aspects of research. With this in mind the Government has sought the agreement of the Australian Agricultural Council to add a representative of the Department of Health to membership of the Central Tobacco Advisory Committee. That is the committee which has the responsibility for examinging research programs and recommending to me the expenditure of moneys from the Tobacco Industry Trust Account. Expenditure approved for this year, 1981-82, is $1,233,155 of which the Commonwealth is committed to contribute $348,000. The whole amount is made available to State departments responsible for agriculture in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. Additional State expenditure on tobacco research in 1981-82 is estimated at $580,000. All of the expenditure is concerned with production and curing of leaf on the farm, not with manufacturing. The increases in the charge rates from the start of the selling season have been sought by the growing and manufacturing sectors. Both are in favour of the starting date of 1 March. As far as any future changes in rates are concerned regulations will be introduced only if changes are sought by both sectors. I commend the Bill to honourable members.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Macphee, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move :

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979 to introduce charges for overseas students who will attend accredited advanced education level courses which are funded by the Commonwealth and offered at educational institutions other than universities and colleges of advanced education, for example, at colleges of technical and further education. At present, charges are imposed only on overseas students attending prescribed courses at universities and colleges of advanced education in Australia. It is intended that the extension of the charges will be applicable at the beginning of 1983. The basis for the imposition of charges on overseas students is to recover part of the costs involved in their education in this country. These costs are being met by the Australian taxpayers.

Honourable members will recall that when the Government first introduced overseas students charges in 1979, it was emphasised that the effect of the policy would be closely monitored and reviewed. Following a review of the overseas students policy by an inter-departmental committee last year, the Government decided to extend the overseas students charges. At the same time, the Government also decided, as part of Australia's special assistance, to meet the costs of overseas students charges from 1982 for nationals of Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific countries from its aid program for the region. The aim is to encourage more students from the area to come and study in Australia.

The extension of this special aid program is consistent wih our special relationship with and obligations towards Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific island countries by virtue of Australia's geographic location, historic ties and relative economic strength in the region. The special assistance in favour of nationals of the South Pacific countries will also cover the new charges when they come into effect.

The main clauses of the Bill are: Clause 2 inserts the definition of 'declared course' into sub-section 4 (1) of the Principal Act and amends the definition of 'prescribed course' for the purposes of the Act. Its effect is that an enrolment in a 'declared course' will be subject to a charge under section 5 of the Act. Clause 3 enables regulations to be made to declare for the purposes of imposing charges, courses offered by special educational institutions other than universities and colleges of advanced education. Clause 4 inserts a new section into the Act to provide for a charge to be imposed in relation to 'declared courses' in the year that follows the year during which the declaration with respect to those courses was made. It also containes transitional provisions to exempt continuing overseas students from the new charges. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Macphee, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move :

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Overseas Students Charge Collection Act 1979 to provide that, where the responsibility for the payment of a charge has been accepted by the Commonwealth in favour of an overseas student, the specified time limits for the payment of that charge would not apply, and a visa and temporary entry permit may be granted to that student. These two minor technical amendments to the principal Act are designed to allow more flexibility for a Commonwealth authority to pay charges on behalf of overseas students from the South Pacific region under Australia's aid programs for this region. The Bill does not affect existing provisions in the Act with respect to special arrangements with a government of an overseas country for the discharge of liability for overseas students charges. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 February, on motion by Mr Nixon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members are aware, I was three-quarters of the way through my remarks on the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill and the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill when the adjournment debate commenced last night. I shall repeat the case being put to the House by the Opposition. The Opposition is opposed to this proposed increase in levy. I think it is very difficult for the Government to argue its case. I do not think it has any facts to its credit. The Government may claim that it is not the fruit grower who will pay but the canneries, but it cannot say that because all the canneries are now co-operatives. The fruit growers will pay whichever way it goes.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for the Opposition's point of view is that in a year when the quotas are to be cut to the lowest levels ever and in a year when prices have been slashed by up to $45 a tonne the Government is expecting the fruit growers to increase their levy payment from 11c to 27c a carton, representing an increase of 150 per cent. The Australian Canned Fruits Corporation, which has not served the industry well, under this legislation will get a 35 per cent increase in its funds. Now is not the time to slug the industry. The levy should be left as it is. If the ACFC needs so much extra money the Government should pay the extra $ 280,000. The Opposition wants to help the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd ), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) and the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), who all have in their electorates growers who are in desperate trouble. I do not know how those honourable members can stand by the Government. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was recently in the Riverina district. Growers supplying the Letona cannery certainly made known to him their anger, their distress and the conditions they will face.

I do not know why the honourable members will not back their State governments. The three State governments concerned have put a lot of pressure on the Federal Government about this. The South Australian Government, for quite a range of reasons, has now had to guarantee the debts of the Riverland cannery. The Government, as I said, is putting this proposal forward as a cost to be borne by the canneries, but we must point out that in fact it will be a cost borne directly by growers because all the canneries are co-operatives: Letona, Ardmona , SPC and RFP. I guess that next week or the week after we will have increased export charges as well for the growers to deal with. That is in an industry in which exports take up to 60 per cent of production.

Quite frankly, the Government has no sympathy for the plight of the canning fruit industry or the fruit growers themselves. The ACFC estimates that the proposed 27c levy will be paid on 4 million basic cartons of canned deciduous fruit. If we do the calculations we find that that will take $1,080,000 from farm incomes in an already depressed income situation. The State governments of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia have made repeated requests for urgent Federal assistance for canning fruit growers. Here we have the Government , a Liberal-National Country Party Government, supporting a reduction in farm income. There are few employment alternatives in the areas where canning deciduous fruit is grown. The dried vine fruits and wine markets are not looking all that good. The citrus growers are awaiting an Industries Assistance Commission report on the level of assistance.

We must recognise that the communities concerned are concentrated in regional areas and the regional implications of a further decline in their incomes are enormous. The small area farms and the large labour content in production tend to concentrate the repercussions of reduced incomes. It might be true that fruit growing represents only a small sector of the national economy-perhaps 5 per cent of the gross value of rural production, or about one per cent of rural export returns-but that is concentrated in the irrigation areas, mainly areas in the Murray basin. Cutting the incomes of canning fruit growers will have an enormous impact on the surrounding areas, on the industries that feed on the canning fruit industry.

This is the conclusion that the Opposition has come to: We now have canned fruit production for which currently there are no profitable markets because this Government has failed to take seriously its responsibility for the industry in overseeing the operations of the ACFC. The Corporation's 1981 quota fixation was disastrous. Growers and State governments in three States have been seeking emergency short term assistance while long term plans are developed. The Federal Government's response, as I said, is to support a 150 per cent increase in the levy for the ACFC, representing a 35 per cent increase in income. I explained earlier in my speech that that organisation's management was part of the reason for the present state of the industry. The Corporation had the relevant information available to it and it should have anticipated the current difficulties. It should have been planning its options long before the present desperate situation was reached.

Some recent comments by members of the Corporation indicate that they are looking to the long term of the industry. That is to be welcomed. But, in terms of their long term look at the industry, they are saying that the number of trees will have to be reduced by one-third. If they are saying that and that there is some agreement with the industry on that, one would think that this Government would not set about to impose on the industry this proposed great increase in levy.

The Opposition cannot support these proposals. It believes that the levy should be retained at its current level and that the resources of the Department of Trade and Resources and the Department of Primary Industry should be used to investigate and promote alternative export markets, such as the Middle East for canned fruit and Asia for fresh fruit. The Government should supply the extra $ 280,000 that the proposed increased levy will collect. The major problem at the moment is caused by oversupply. It is unclear whether the same problems will apply to the 1983 crop. In fact, because of the industry's intake in 1982, carry -over stocks in 1983 may well be back to what the industry considers is an acceptable level, 1.5 million basic cartons. If production is at more normal levels in 1983 and markets such as the Middle East can be given some encouragement, in 1983 canneries and growers may be ready to support the Corporation.

It is unacceptable to the Opposition to ask for more money from an industry at a time when that industry is in desperate need of Federal financial assistance. We propose that the extra marketing initiative which is needed should be provided by the Department of Trade and Resources and the Department of Primary Industry when, first of all, the ACFC has demonstrated its ability effectively to manage the marketing of Australian canned fruit and its interest in the industry by preparing an IAC submission for the next hearing scheduled for May next year. The Opposition then will be pleased to review its position of not supporting an increase in the levy for canned deciduous fruit.

I conclude by pointing out what the Labor Government did for the industry in 1973 when ex-Senator Ken Wriedt was Minister for Primary Industry. In that year the Labor Government provided $1.5m in grants to canners for revaluation assistance. We also gave emergency adjustment assistance to canning fruit growers. That emergency assistance was provided in the form of payments to canning fruit growers and those payments were made on the basis of deliveries of peaches, pears and apricots to canneries for canning in the 1972-73 season. Payments were made at the rate of $12 a tonne on up to 125 tonnes, with a maximum payment of $1,500 to a grower. Also at that time we had a tree pull scheme, which we continued. Funding by the Labor Government to rural reconstruction and rural adjustment was at a high level. The Government has now phased out the tree pull scheme and, on the other measure, funds are being cut back all the time. In 1973 the Labor Government did respond to the needs of the canning fruit industry. The current Government's response to a canning fruit crisis is to raise the levy which funds the Australian Canned Fruit Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party, in its opposition to the proposed increase from 11c to 27c a carton in the levy to finance the promotional and administrative activities of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation, puts itself in a strange and absurd position. If it were to think about the matter a little more I think it would consider its position a very unhappy one because of the ramifications it has for the whole policy in relation to rural areas. For one of two reasons the Labor Party has made the decision to oppose the proposed amendment contained in the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill . The first alternative is that the Labor Party has not been in contact with the fruit industry. The grower organisations and the fruit canners who make up the canning fruit industry are in favour of the proposal. I repeat that quite clearly. They are in favour of the proposal. I checked with them on that again this morning because I was amazed to hear of the Labor Party's position on this proposal yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Canned Fruits Corporation speaks for the industry because it is made up of both the grower organisations and the canners. Therefore, its request to act has come formally from and on behalf of the industry to the Government. The Government is not trying to impose anything on the industry. I checked this again with individual leaders in the fruit growing industry. I know them all personally because most of them are in the Murray electorate. They are very much in favour of the proposed increased levy and are amazed and upset by the Labor Party's action. Either the Labor Party has acted in complete ignorance of what the fruit industry considers to be the best policy for it at the present time or , alternatively, it has contacted the industry, knows the view of the industry on this and has chosen to ignore the position of the industry. In other words, the Labor Party in opposing this legislation is indicating that it considers it knows more about the industry than the industry leaders. That is a very dangerous and arrogant position for the Labor Party to adopt. If I were a member of the Labor Party I would seriously consider my position on this matter. Either it has not bothered to contact the industry and therefore is completely ignorant of what the industry wants or it believes it knows more about the industry than the industry. That is a very dangerous position in principle for the Labor Party to be in because this will reinforce the fears of agricultural industries generally in Australia about the attitude a Labor Party in governmnent would adopt towards them: That is, that the Labor Party would consider and perhaps continue to believe-its track record appears to vindicate this point-that it knows more about the industry than the industry itself.

If the Labor Party is of the view that the work of the Canned Fruits Corporation and its promotional activities are to be reduced, surely it is for the industry which actually pays for these activities, not the Government, to make that decision itself. It is not for the arrogant or ignorant Labor Party to do so by manifesting that it knows better than the industry.

The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) referred in his speech to an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry quite a few years ago into the fruit industry generally. He referred to the recommendation that regional development authorities, composed of drop-outs from universities and other people, should somehow or other go into these fruit growing areas that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I represent and tell these growers how they should grow fruit and generally look after themselves. That was an absurd proposal. It is one of the silliest things the IAC has ever done. I am glad to see that the IAC seems to have a bit more sense these days. But, to the credit of the Government, it did not accept that advice. However, I do support the honourable member for Werriwa in the comment he made about the need for financial assistance for fruit growers through the rural adjustment scheme. I have lobbied the industry and State Ministers for several months on the need for the canning fruit industry to be declared an industry in need of assistance, in need of adjustment, so that it can become once again eligible for rural adjustment assistance. My understanding is that the States themselves must initiate the move for the industry by stating to the Commonwealth that the industry is in that position. To my knowledge, none of the three States involved has made that request to the Commonwealth at this stage. The Commonwealth Government has to make a special allocation of finance for the canning fruit industry through the rural adjustment scheme because all of the funds provided for the scheme in the current financial year have been taken up. Obviously money is required. I hope that the Government will be making the necessary allocation to the rural adjustment scheme so that the industry can get the money it needs.

The honourable member for Werriwa, in his criticism of the Canned Fruits Corporation, referred to promotion and sales in the United Kingdom and the fact that in 1980, in spite of its promotional activities, there was a reduction in sales. When I was in London with a delegation a couple of weeks ago, along with the honourable member for Werriwa and other honourable members, I privately visited the Australian Canned Fruit (IMO) U.K. Ltd, which is responsible for the selling of Australian canned fruit in the United Kingdom, and was advised that as a result of the promotional campaign in 1981 there had been a significant increase in the sales of canned fruit from Australia to the United Kingdom. So I think I can rebut the point made by the honourable member and say that the promotional activities have been worth while in the United Kingdom. It is obvious from the actual scale of overseas markets for Australian canned fruit that the United Kingdom is still the major market and therefore is worth the promotional activity.

The honourable member for Werriwa stated as a Labor principle that somehow or other it should be unacceptable to require more money from farmers in an industry which is suffering the effects of an economic downturn. That is a new principle for the Labor Party to enunciate. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I were members of this place in 1973-74 when in the depths of the wool depression the Labor Party required that the wool growers of Australia contribute 5 per cent of their returns to a revolving fund. In other words, at a time when wool growers were going through a depressed financial period they had to contribute part of their money to support themselves, which was an added burden.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were better off in 1974 than we were in 1970.

—As to the wool price situation in 1970, I would have a bet with the honourable member that the wool growers of Australia were in a better position then than they were in 1974 when the Labor Government imposed on them that 5 per cent levy for a revolving fund. Honourable members may also care to look at the situation in the beef market. What did the Labor Party do when the beef market collapsed? It required that the full export inspection charges for beef be imposed upon the unhappy beef producers of Australia. So much for these new principles of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are debating a proposal to abolish the Australian Canned Fruit Sales Promotion Committee and a proposal to increase the canned fruits levy. The dramatic reduction in the canning fruit intake by the canneries to half of what it was last year, as the honourable member for Werriwa has pointed out, is one of the major reasons why it is necessary to increase the levy to maintain funds of the Corporation and take into account its increased promotional activities. The reduced intake and therefore the increased levy highlight the tragedy that has befallen the canning fruit industry. The incomes of fruit growers this year will be half of last year's income. I quote from a Bureau of Agricultural Economics document which was presented to an IAC hearing in Shepparton a few weeks ago. The document states:
The Goulburn Valley, which is more dependent on income from canning fruit will be hardest hit with FCOS-
That is, farm cash operating surplus-
falling from $26,000 to minus $19,000, due to a combination of reduced intake plus a poor year for fresh apples and pears.

That is a dramatic reduction in income-from $26,000 to minus $19,000. Already one of the three canneries in the Goulburn Valley has closed and with it 121 jobs have gone. As the honourable member for Werriwa has pointed out, canneries in South Australia and New South Wales are basically bankrupt and one-third could be forced to leave the industry. These problems are additional to the earlier dramatic reduction in the industry when the United Kingdom joined the European Economic Community. At that time the industry was reduced by about one- third.

The reasons for the present tragedy are first of all, the very high valuation of the Australian dollar. The industry estimates that last year this cost it $ 10m. This is common to all agricultural exporting industries. They are losing millions and millions of dollars because of the very high valuation of the Australian dollar. The second reason is the EEC policies. In 1978 as part of the balancing act between support under the Common Agricultural Policy for northern and sourthern Europe a subsidy was introduced to encourage Italian pear growers to can their fresh pears instead of selling them on the fresh markets, which they preferred to do and for which they got more money. At the present time that subsidy amounts to almost twice the amount or growers receive in total. That has added to the reduction in the outlook for canned fruit exports. These trends were first of all hidden by the very large intake of the canneries last year and they are now exacerbated by that large intake because of the large carry over. So this season we will have a dramatic reduction. However, the problems to a certain extent have been masked this season by the fact that it is an off year for pears. The canning pear intake in the Goulburn Valley has now been completed . Basically all pears have been taken in in one form or another and in a couple of weeks we will know whether, and to what extent, there will be an excess of peaches, peaches that will not receive a home in any of the canneries.

The IAC presently is inquiring into the short and long term problems of the canning fruit industry. It is to report by 31 March on what may be necessary for short term assistance for the 1982 season and by 31 August in respect of long term assistance. It is a tragedy that the total fruit industry was not able to reach agreement at an earlier stage. It could have been possible, six months earlier, to make the request to the Minister for an IAC hearing. The report could then have been with the Government before the present harvest and measures could have been taken earlier. It is of no use for Australian Labor Party members to be critical of the requirement for an IAC hearing prior to long term assistance being given to an industry. After all, they brought in the legislation themselves.

As the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has pointed out the governments of New South Wales and South Australia have provided some short term cash flow assistance to growers in their areas. Presently, the Victorian Government is considering taking similar action. I hope that an announcement will be made, if not today, in the very near future in that regard. Those State Governments have accepted their responsibility, have accepted that they too have a part to play on behalf of industries which operate in their States, in this case in the provision of short term assistance.

It is important that this Government act as quickly as possible at the end of March once the IAC has made its recommendations so that growers in the industry will know what assistance and policies governments will be pursuing for them in the short term, prior to the necessity to begin preparing for the next season. Those preparations would begin in about May so it is essential that the Government act quickly.

All sectors of the industry, in appearing before the IAC have recommended, among other things, that a tree pull scheme be implemented; they believe that it would be a good idea. I hope that, if such a scheme is accepted by the Government, it will remember some of the lessons of the last occasion and will have a scheme that is far more generous and flexible. It is incorrect to say that that tree pull scheme was a success.

I would also hope that the IAC would recommend some form of short term cash flow boost by government, in this case the Federal Government, to help reduce the dramatic cash flow problems from which growers are suffering, or will be within the next few months.

I hope that there will also be a recommendation for the giving of special rural adjustment assistance, both for those who may be forced to leave the industry and for those to whom the industry offers a viable long term future but will be going through a cash flow and viability crisis in the short term. For the long term it is essential that there be an underwriting scheme for the canning fruit industry, just as there are for a range of other agricultural industries, to offer stability for the future at the new level of activity.

Also, the Government needs to work far harder than it has done so far for the inclusion of canned fruit in the closer economic relations negotiations with New Zealand. Australia is suffering unfair competition from the European Economic Community because of the tremendous subsidies that it provides for its growers and through its high external tariff, which reduces the attractiveness of its market for our canned fruit. There are not many markets for canned fruit available around the world. Contrary to what the honourable member for Werriwa has said, I believe that the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation is doing what it can, together with our trade commissioners, to find those markets. One that is close to us is the New Zealand market.

The New Zealand canning fruit industry is not nearly as efficient as is Australia's. Our canned fruit sells for about two-thirds the price of New Zealand canned fruit but we are not allowed to sell it there because of the very severe restrictions imposed by the government of that country. My point is that New Zealand is applying a double standard in regard to its attitude to achieving closer economic relations. Where its industries are more efficient than ours-and certainly some are-New Zealand want open an early access to our market. Where our industries are more efficient than New Zealand's-canned fruit is a particularly good example, although we have many others also-it is not prepared to provide similar access to its markets. Therefore, one of the other measures that I believe the Government should undertake to assist the canning fruit industry in its present troubled time is to ensure that canned fruit is included in the CER negotiations to a far greater degree than is presently the case. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the penalising effect that the large levy increase, from 15c to 27c per basic carton of canned fruit, will have on fruit growers, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has indicated that the Opposition will oppose the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. Whilst it is true that the fruitgrowers in my electorate, being mainly berry and cherry growers, are not affected by this levy, the basic principles which have led to the proposed heavy increase would undoubtedly cause them concern.

SPEECH.PARA: However, before I go any further I would like to answer some of the points raised by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). The first is that the Australian Labor Party does not believe that the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation's promotional activities should be curtailed. We simply believe that canning fruit growers should not be required to pay 150 per cent extra in levy at this time. We also believe that the government should pick up the $280,000 as a gesture of support for the industry while it awaits the results of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry. I trust that the honourable member for Murray supports that proposition. The 5 per cent revolving fund for the wool industry introduced so much stability to the industry that it no longer requires any government funds to run the buffer stock scheme. The honourable member for Murray, in alluding to the Labor Party's beef policies fails to recognise that this Government still retains inspection fees in the beef industry and will do nothing to help it now that it is again in a bad economic situation.

The problem in the canned fruits industry, as I see it, relates to a misjudgment in regard to marketing arrangements. Sales in 1981, as far as the Corporation was concerned, fell well below the anticipated figure for that year and, as a consequence, there has been a stock carry-over of four million basic cartons, in comparison with a carry-over of 1.9 million basic cartons in the previous year. This high stock level involves high interest rates, which have hit the industry at a time when it faces low-priced competition from the European Economic Community. It has been estimated by the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation that growers will suffer considerable trading losses. I do not accept, however, that growers should bear the burden of what amounts to an error of judgment in relation to the marketing circumstances of 1980. Both fruit processors and canned fruiters are suffering the effects of the heavy subsidisation of European processors and canners by the European Economic Community. In that regard both I and the honourable member for Murray are in full agreement. The EEC on its own admission, has very generously granted specific aid for the production of peaches, pears, d'agen prunes and cherries. The financial support granted these products is sometimes such that it amounts to reimbursing in full the amount paid by the processors to the fruit growers. It is to be hoped that the Industries Assistance Commission will take this unfair subsidisation into account when considering the provision of Government support for the industry. It is important to appreciate that, as opposed to methods used by overseas competitors, the basic principle which applies to fruiterers within Australia is to obtain a price for the grower which will provide a return on his direct costs. Any lesser return would mean that the grower would soon be out of production.

I take this opportunity to emphasise that an important principle which must be taken into account by the IAC is that overseas fruiterers should not be able to use Australia as a convenient dumping ground. The problems which face rural industries frequently require government intervention, although members of the National Country Party and other members, on the Government side of the House, frequently deny that fact. Incidentally, they are all missing from the chamber at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —A point of order. They are not.

—I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy Speaker; the honourable member is sitting at the table. Contrary to misrepresentations frequently levelled at us by National Country Party members, the Australian Labor Party does have a clear understanding of the problems of the rural community. Government support and intervention is necessary to provide a measure of stabilisation in the rural industry but, as the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) pointed out in a recent debate on the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Bill, government intervention is also necessary in the manufacturing industry. Unfortunately, National Country Party members have two-sided Jekyll and Hyde characters. They are socialists when it comes to subsidies and concessions for the rural industry but rabid free marketeers in denying support to the manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that at this rather difficult time for the industry the Government should ensure that fruit growers are not deserted in a climate where most other producing countries are subsidised by their governments. It is clear that the industry must be involved in a restructuring process but this cannot take place overnight. A lead time is required in order to bring trees into production and the cost of expensive irrigation and fruit handling equipment has to be written off. The Government should ensure that financial assistance is provided to avoid any hardships to growers as a result of a planned reduction in bearing trees. It is estimated that the present restructuring of the industry, which has resulted in only two of the three Victorian canners continuing to produce, will mean the loss of at least 100 permanent jobs in Kyabram. There will also be a loss of about 500 jobs for seasonal workers for periods of two to three months. This considerable amount of local unemployment which has resulted from the lack of Government planning does not include the loss of fruit picking jobs for seasonal itinerant workers.

The responsible Ministers who can be blamed for this appalling state of affairs in the fruit industry are all members of the National Country Party. That party professes to represent the rural community but nothing is further from the truth . The National Country Party represents big business and mining interests and, by its enthusiastic support of Government policies, it is causing the impoverishment of small farmers. Victorian country voters are beginning to see the light, however, and the State elections on 3 April will see a further decline in the NCP vote.

Lest it be said that I am only criticising, I would like now to offer some constructive suggestions. Whilst I am not necessarily convinced that a tree pulling program is what the small growers really want, such a program will need the provision of government funds. However, assuming that such funds are provided, it will be vital to ensure that the program causes the least dislocation to the local community. The fairest method will be to allow those who wish to leave the industry to be the first to be compensated. The next step should be a priority aim of retaining the family farm, a concept to which the NCP is constantly paying lip service. Consequently, the biggest orchards should be the next to suffer production cuts. Unlike the small orchardists, they can afford to diversify resources, to absorb cutbacks in production. I would like to quote from a letter from Mr Neil Frankland, a Shepparton resident. The letter was published in the Shepparton News on 3 February.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is also secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Shepparton.
—Yes, and he is also a former secretary of the Victorian Farmers Union . Amongst other things, Mr Frankland says:

SPEECH.PARA: This would be in line with the thinking of most local organisations concerned with employment and of keeping people in the area.
These were the suggestions that I had previously advocated. He went on:

Whether we like it or not, the so-called resources boom has turned Australia from a high-producing food bowl for the world and given priority to the non- labour intensive high profit forms of activities which characterises all exploitation of raw materials.
It is no good blaming wages as Australia is rapidly sliding down the scale as far as wage levels are concerned.
In fact, wages paid in the fruit industry and the existing conditions fall far below the accepted community standards.

In conclusion, one cannot help wondering what the Minister was doing when this grave miscalculation of anticipated sales for 1980 occurred. In normal circumstances one would expect that a responsible government would have produced long term plans in relation to the canning fruit industry. However, it has to be understood that this Government is not one which believes in forward planning. It will rescue rural industries when problems arise because of the importance of the rural vote for its political survival. In the case of the canning industry the Government has no long term plans to guide the industry in its present crisis because the Government worships the false idol of the so-called free market economy. In requiring the growers to meet the financial cost of the overstocking problems arising from the upturn in the value of the Australian dollar and the competition from the European Economic Community, to which I have referred in detail, the Government is evading its own responsibilities. I support the rejection of this Bill accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support this canned fruits legislation; let there be no shadow of doubt about that. May I say right from the word go-I hope I say it kindly-that the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) has missed the point about the structuring of rural industries in Australia. We do not aim in any way to set up a structure in which central governments, whether they be Liberal, National Country Party or Labor, will have a voice in how that industry will conduct its own affairs. Surely that is the very purpose of the statutory bodies we have set up. I do not think it is a fair judgment at all for the honourable member for La Trobe to blame the Government for a commercial error, even though I am forced to agree with the honourable member for Werriwa ( Mr Kerin) and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics when they point to the deficiences in judgment by the Australian Canning Fruit Corporation. That is so, but it is much better to have it that way than have an industry entirely structured, led and controlled by a centralised government.
—The Russian plan would be a good example.

—Let us leave kibbutzim and settlements out of this for the time being. The fact is that this is the way the Government is elected and these industry statutory bodies are elected to try as much as possible to run their own industries with their own expertise. Quite frankly, it is absurd for anyone to say in this Parliament that any of us have more expertise in regard to canned fruit than the Australian Canning Fruit Corporation or, for that matter, than the Australian Wool Testing Authority or the Honey Board have in their respective industries. If we accept that proposition we are saying in effect that we should appoint civil servants to the Department of Primary Industry who in effect have expert knowledge not only of the industry and its makeup but also of all its merchandising judgments. That is equally absurd. Let us put that aside.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry that the honourable member for Werriwa appears to be momentarily leaving the House because I wanted-I hope in a kindly fashion again-to refer to some of the statements he made. I think he is confusing State and Federal responsibilities. The honourable member for Werriwa knows very well the role of the Industries Assistance Commission. It was introduced by the Labor Government. It was supported by the Liberal Party and I think by the National Country Party, with some reservations. So he knows the role of the IAC, he knows the process that flows from IAC inquiries and he knows very well that within that process the Federal Government's hands are tied behind its back with regard to producing subsidies, loans or anything else until such time as the IAC has reported back. Let us carry that one stage further. If there is a role for State governments, surely that role is to pick up the unevenness between one State and another as it affects their industries. Our role as a Federal Government is to produce across the board legislation. If, then, unevenness occurs within State boundaries, State governments-if they are to justify their position in the future-must pick up some of that unevenness. Of course, this is precisely what has happened. I will not repeat the speech of the honourable member for Werriwa but he pointed out that the Leeton Cannery has received $700,000, as I understand it, followed by another $1m from the Wran Government, in two separate areas, to help it.

To cite a case in point from my own State of South Australia, the Tonkin Government has given $560,000 in approximately two halves, half of which is in the way of loans at 6 per cent interest and roughly $230,000 has gone to the growers. That was carried out in a situation where 80 per cent of the canning production is in Victoria, not in either Leeton or South Australia. Probably what the honourable member for Werriwa may have touched on, and I talked to him about this earlier, was far more than that. I have been told that the Tonkin Government has given guarantees to substantiate the future of the Riverland cannery to the tune of $29m. I quote that again because that is the role of State governments-to look at that uneveness and pick up what should be done as they see it. The role of this Government, and the honourable member for Werriwa knows this very well, is to wait until an IAC inquiry comes down shortly and then decide on three different alternatives. We accept the advice of the IAC, we reject it or we make up our own minds as to how the best method of rural adjustment measures, for instance, may be carried out. That is the position, and it is a course that this House knows very well should be followed.

I was very interested in the remarks of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). It was certainly my impression-I say this in answer to the honourable member for Werriwa who attempted to interject a little while ago-that the industry is in favour of the second of these two Bills, that is, the Bill to increase levies on production at the farm level. Actually, the levy is taken off at the factory level, but that is beside the point. That was my impression. I was very glad to hear that somebody has done some checking today and that that is the position of the industry.

The industry requires that the Corporation should be able to continue its functions, one would hope with considerably more effect than it did in the last 12 months. In order for the Corporation to have its finance in place, the industry is posed with two serious problems. Firstly, the intake is down considerably, and that cuts down quantitatively on the collection of the levy; and, secondly, of course, the price, not only on the home market but more particularly on the export market, is down to blazes on that quantity of fruit. So there is a serious depletion of funds to establish the future of the Corporation.

The Labor Party, as I understand it, says that the growers in the industry should not be taxed in the way that it is proposed in this second Bill, by way of levy. If that is so, what it is saying is that the Corporation should not exist. It is saying the Corporation should not function in the fields that the industry hopes that it will function in in the next year. I can only point out again that there is no way that I can seriously consider the Labor Party's rejection of this particular Bill today because it does not make sense if we regard the industry as having any sense of responsibility in this matter. If we take the view of the Labor Party, presumably we take the view that there is no responsibility in the canning fruit industry and it does not know what is best for it. That is a proposition I cannot accept.

I notice the honourable member for Murray said, quite rightly, that the majority of rural organisations and State departments of agriculture, I imagine he meant were pretty solid in their support for a tree pull scheme. What he says is quite so, as is obvious from the report of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. In fact, if one wanted to be critical, one could say perhaps that the Bureau did not carry rural adjustment measures as far as I thought it would. It appeared to me that it concentrated its endeavours purely on tree pull. I want to make the position in my State very clear. The South Australian Department of Agriculture, and, I gather, the industry, are not in favour of tree pull. They are in favour of other methods of rural adjustment. They are not in favour of tree pull for one significant reason, and that is that over a period those who are wisest in the industry and who have had, say, fruit salad blocks, which spread the risk a bit, have tended to take out canning fruit. If the Riverland cannery is to persist, which the Tonkin Government is determined it will-it has guaranteed that it will for another two years-quite frankly we cannot afford a turn down in the amount of fruit for that cannery.

Also, I think can be substantiated much more fully if honourable members look at the statistics-I will not worry about putting them down because the honourable member for Werriwa also has them-that they relate to peaches. I expect other honourable members will disagree with me when I point out that the Riverland cannery in South Australia was primarily established for peach processing. I maintain that that area produces the best coloured and best quality peaches in Australia. It is by no means certain that in years to come peach production will not have some future. For that reason I support the South Australian Government very fully in its efforts to spend a lot of money on this cannery. Maybe some money may have to be found elsewhere eventually. Approximately $29m of Government guarantees have been given to that cannery. We in South Australia believe that there can be a future for peach production in particular, and only time will tell. Honourable members will remember very well the gloom and despondency only five or six years ago, which affected the Australian dried fruit industry. There were IAC reports, there were moves to rationalise the industry downwards and virtually to tear it apart. Of course, the Australian dried fruit industry has taken off. It has been one of the most profitable industries in the horticultural area. I point that out because none of us can be quite sure about the future of the canning fruit industry and in particular, I maintain, the peach section of it.

During my time in Parliament, if not in the time of some members of the Opposition, this Government made massive loans that became grants to co- operative canneries as a significant donation to a difficulty experienced some years ago. That difficulty, of course, was the advent of the European Economic Community. Those loans were made in an effort to meet adjustments and cash losses in that one year due to the highly protective attitude of the EEC to the canning fruit industry which historically sold its production to England and Germany-in other words, in part of Europe. So the adjustment was made. The Government's donation to help adjust really was made then but the dried fruit industry and the canned fruit industry, more than other industries in this nation, I think, have had access to some portion of the EEC market and have therefore continued to produce at a lower level; but they have continued to produce. There has not been quite the pressure on those industries to seek alternative markets.

Talking about alternative markets, the honourable member for Werriwa gave great hope for the Arab nations generally. If we look at some of those countries we will see the point I am trying to establish in my argument.There is some sign that in some countries there is an increase in sales, particularly of peaches. Time will tell whether the gloomy forecasts of the future of the fruit canning industry are correct or whether, like the dried fruit industry, they will prove to be incorrect. None of us really know.

I will finish on this note. I admire the industry leadership of the canning fruit industry which has agreed with the Government that it must continue to finance the Corporation; that without that there would not be the capacity to promote fruit for home markets or for export in future. They are hanging, with all their faith in their own industry, on to that fact. I am sorry that the Labor Party has to take this rather negative attitude to the faith that those people have in their own industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to support the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill. It is probably two years too late and I think any reasonable survey would show that its marketing expertise has been very poor. There must, however, be some benefits from integration of marketing and management, for what is basically needed is new initiatives, not the sort of initiatives suggested by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) . He wants to attack the minuscule New Zealand market, a country with which we already have a massive trade surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of the ideological hang-ups of the Government and I am very aware that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) would not sell wheat to China because he would not transgress his principles. But I do think there is an opportunity for us to look at some markets at the moment. Given the relatively short storage of canned fruit-in fact, canned anything-we are looking at a situation in which we will have a large carry-over of canned fruit. It will cost us a lot of money to store it. It may be to our advantage to look at doing a deal whereby we supply canned fruit to a market such as Poland on long term credit. I know the Government's position in relation to dealing with Poland but it could perhaps overcome its hang-ups by doing a deal with the Let Poland Live Committee being run through the auspices of the Church. It could supply the fruit to the Church, where it could be sure of distribution. In all possibility the credit of the Church is better than that of Poland.

I turn to the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill, which I strongly oppose. I think the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) set out the case for the Labor Party extremely well. The honourable member for Murray says that he has massive growers' support for the scheme. That is strange. Growers in the Riverland have been contacting us continuously complaining that they cannot get their industry leaders to convene a meeting with them so that they can express their concern. Then we turn and look at the independent leadership of the Australian Canned Fruit Corporation. The Chairman is a heavy in the Liberal Party-the Treasurer of the Victorian Liberal Party. That is the sort of independent leadership that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) was describing! The honourable member for Murray, in truth, does not talk to the industry; he talks to the hacks that form the leadership of the industry. In the House the other day, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) was criticising qangos and making snide remarks about them. Despite the obvious problems that the Common Market would be presenting, acreages in canning fruit rose quite dramatically. It is true that towards the end they tapered off, but at the end of the decade we ended up with more trees than we had at the beginning, and in some areas, such as Goulburn, the growth in acreage was quite dramatic.

TALK.START.PARA: —With no forward planning.

—This was done, as my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe says, without any forward planning. These were the great days of the great protectionist, Black Jack McEwen. This is the sort of thing we have come to expect from the National Country Party.
