SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading of the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982 and the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill 1982 comes at a time when the canned fruit industry finds itself facing extremely difficult times. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon ) has stated in the second reading speech, the Australian Canned Fruit Corporation has decided to reduce canned fruit production in the 1982 season to approximately one-half of the level achieved last year. This decision is being made because of the drastic downturn in export market outlets last year and the build-up of unsold stock to record high levels. This decision was made by the Australian Canned Fruit Corporation in close consultation with grower and canning interests. That is why I was surprised to hear the Opposition speaking about how terrible it was that the Canned Fruit Corporation is making this decision, but, as I have said, it did that in close co-operation and consultation with the growers.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the reasons for a build-up in stock include the strong value of the Australian dollar and the excessively protectionist policies of the European Economic Community towards canned fruit imports, combined with generous production subsidies received by EEC canners. I know that the Minister for Primary Industry has been untiring in his efforts with the EEC on the matters relating to trade barriers, and it is imperative that these efforts continue in working towards having the EEC subsidies on their canned fruits substantially reduced. Of course, on top of the EEC and other international problems, we have the increased price of production brought about by the increased cost of labour, sugar, tinplate, labels and transport. The canned fruit industry depends heavily upon exports, and in 1979 approximately 66 per cent of sales were in export markets, but this percentage has declined markedly in the last two years. This decline in sales has in turn caused great concern not only to canneries but also to growers, some of whom are totally reliant on growing fruit for the cannery in their area.

In the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area the Letona Co-operative Cannery situated at Leeton has been placed in the hands of an administrator, because it has been affected by the problems mentioned earlier, and canneries in other areas of Australia are in similar situations. The Riverland Fruit Producers Co-operative Cannery in South Australia is in the hands of a receiver and Ardmona Fruit Products Co-operative Ltd has announced a meagre profit of $50,000, indicating that the fruit trading portion of its operation has resulted in losses. It was therefore with a great deal of hope that growers heard of the Minister's intention to hold an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into the canning fruit industry, with an interim report for short-term assistance being ready by 31 March and the final report being presented by 31 August. The Minister is to be complimented for the expeditious way in which the report was got under way after the industry indicated its desire to have the report undertaken. It is indicative of the Government's real concern in this matter.

Recent experience in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area has been that even where a farmer has diversified his crops, for example, by growing wine grapes, citrus or vegetables, along with canning fruits, he or she is running into difficulties . This season it has been estimated that only 73 per cent of the grapes available for wine making will be harvested because of a reduction in intake by the wineries, which have their own problems to overcome. At first 73 per cent sounds a reasonable figure, until one realises that this could mean 100 per cent of one grower's crop and none, or very little, of another's, dependent on the variety of grape required by the wine makers. For those combining the growing of canning fruits and wine grapes, the picture is grim. A similar problem is faced by those growing vegetables, where the markets at present are realising poor prices. To diversify to citrus is difficult because of the time a tree takes to mature, and the citrus industry itself is also presently subject to an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry on tariffs.

Following the announcement of the prices for peaches and pears by the Fruit Industry Sugar Concession Committee earlier this year, where there was a reduction for peaches of $45 a tonne and pears of $40 a tonne over last season's figures, the Secretary of the Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association, Mr Phillip Marshall, said that the reduction had not only disappointed growers but also had added weight to the argument that the Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association had been putting to the State and Federal governments since early 1981-that the industry was in a very serious situation and required urgent assistance. Mr Marshall highlighted the fact that the canning fruit industry was one of the few agricultural export industries remaining that had not received any direct assistance to support export returns, and it was an industry that had already recognised the need for adjustment downward. If the National Country Party is associated with trends in that direction, I think it is to be complimented and not derided, as the Opposition seems to do.

Although the MIA is facing a difficult financial period because of those factors I have mentioned, and also because of the low prices expected for this year's rice crop, the resiliency of the growers will ensure that the area will survive. It was interesting to read the comments of Councillor Bill Barnhill, President of the Leeton Shire Council, who stated that he had every confidence in the town of Leeton for a number of reasons, among those being its geographical location and its high quality work force. I am sure all of the peope of the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area would join with me in applying councillor Barnhill's comments to the total Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area.

There have been representatives of the New South Wales Government who have been hypercritical of the Federal Government's role in the problems of the canning fruit industry. The criticism is unwarranted because we all know of this Government's concern for the industry which, as I said before, was highlighted by the swift action of the Minister for Primary Industry in having an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry take place. It can only be detrimental to the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area if these people use the problems facing the industry as another irrational and illogical means of attacking the Federal Government, as has been done recently in nearly every sphere of New South Wales and Federal government relationships. The Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area is too important for that.

It is pleasing to see that the New South Wales Government has assisted the ailing canning fruit industry in New South Wales by injecting over the last 12 months an amount of $1.7m into the system. This is an admirable start and it is imperative that close State-Federal ties be maintained not only in the immediate future but also in the long term. This is essential if stable development is to persist in the MIA. I am pleased to say that due to the campaign launched by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the initiative of the growers many have been able to dispose of much of their fruit on the fresh fruit markets. Although this demands a great deal of extra work it will allow many growers to overcome partly their liquidity problems, keeping in mind that a large number of growers are still owed substantial sums from previous seasons. I support these Bills because they will enable the Canned Fruits Corporation to continue to promote the sale of canned fruits and carry out those administrative operations which are so essential to the future well-being of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Firstly, I thank the House for understanding my absence today during the debate. I understand that the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, made very solid contributions to the debate. I have been advised of that by my colleague the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) who had the pleasure of hearing those good speeches. As I understand it, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has a plain, simple misunderstanding of what one of these Bills is about and who supports the Bill. The Australian Labor Party apparently is opposing the increase in the levy. I am not sure on what grounds it is doing this because it is normal for industries to make up their own minds about levies of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case the fact is that the recommendation came to the Government from the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation and it is supported by the Australian Canners Association and the Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association. If the Canning Fruitgrowers Association wants an increase in the growers' levy to help to promote this industry when it is in difficulty I would have thought that it is common sense for the Government to agree to that. That is simply what the Government has agreed to. The Labor Party, in its usual way, failed to understand that and failed to understand the industry. It is typical of its approach in respect of rural industry as a whole.

Also I understand there has been some criticism about a lack of a long term plan for the industry. The fact of the matter in this respect is that it was in about December 1980 that I first warned the industry that it would need to get an Industries Assistance Commission hearing of its problems to face up to the 1981 and 1982 problems. Unfortunately, the industry could not agree to approach the IAC and it did not agree until October last year. I kept harping on the industry at the instigation of my colleagues who came to see me. The honourable member for Murray in particular brought deputation after deputation. I kept saying: 'Get your act together and get before the IAC so that we can find out what its recommendations are and assistance can be given'. Unfortunately, they could not agree until October.

Immediately on the industry's acceptance of the proposition we went to the IAC. A hearing is now in progress. As honourable members know, an interim report is to be brought down before the end of March, providing perhaps some initial assistance, and a final long term report is to be brought down by October this year so that the long term problems can be dealt with. For the Labor Party to strut around the place and pretend that it knows something about this industry shows the complete humbug with which it tackles all rural industries. Its lack of knowledge, lack of understanding and lack of sympathy for these industries is legion throughout the countryside. People in the countryside will never forget what it was like with the Labor Party in the years 1972 to 1975. They know that the Labor party will never be any different if it gets back into government again. The Opposition's approach on these Bills is typically the same. Having made just those two points that I thought needed making very firmly, I thank those honourable members who have made sensible contributions to the debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RETAIL MARKETING FRANCHISE AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Amendment Bill 1982 is the first of two Bills I will be introducing tonight to amend the petroleum retail marketing legislation enacted in 1980. The amendments are designed to ensure that the legislation gives effect to the Government's policies in a precise and unambiguous manner. Some questions of interpretation of the legislation have been raised. These amendments are intended to remove doubts and to clarify the application of the legislation. The Government proposes that debate on the Bills be deferred until later in this parliamentary session. As with other commercial legislation introduced by the Government, this course of action is being adopted to give honourable members, interested parties and the public, the opportunity to comment on the amending Bills.

I recall for honourable members the Government's policy in introducing the petroleum retail marketing legislation in September 1980. The Government is opposed to any unnecessary regulation of the business sector. However, the Government considered intervention in the petroleum retailing industry was necessary to correct certain marketing practices; to maintain a vigorous and effective small business sector; and to promote and maintain fair competition and the long term competitiveness of the industry. Experience since the legislation was passed has vindicated the Government's actions, and confirmed its belief in the need for the legislation.

This Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act form part of a package of measures. These measures are inter-related and finely balanced to limit undesirable practices, without hindering competition, and without entrenching current market structures or preventing rationalisation. These Acts do, of necessity, raise a number of complex legal and technical issues-to an extent that has perhaps not been fully appreciated by all sectors of the industry.

Whilst the full impact of both Acts will, partly for constitutional reasons, only be fully felt over a two to three-year period, the legislation appears in general to be achieving its objectives. Security of dealers' tenure has been enhanced; the position of dealers vis-a-vis oil companies has been improved; franchisees are better able to obtain fair recompense for their investment; disclosure of relevant information to prospective franchisees has been greatly improved; franchisees have been able to take advantage of the remedies provided by the legislation; companies have adjusted their marketing strategies to comply with the legislation without significant difficulty; while competition in the industry appears not to have been impaired. The Government is convinced that the legislation is leading, and will continue to lead, to overall better relationships between franchisors and their franchisees and contribute to the maintenance of a healthy, competitive industry.

The only major practical issue that has arisen since enactment of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act is the complex question of the Act's application to multi-function sites-that is, sites where the operator makes some sales as a principal, and some as an agent, of an oil company, or where some sales are bulk sales, and some sales are made direct into the supply tanks of vehicles; that is , service station type sales. Depots are the most obvious example of multiple functions being carried on at the one site, but it also occurs to a significant degree with ordinary service stations-for example, a franchisee dealer who services some national account customers on behalf of his franchisor oil company .

I wish to emphasise that it was intended, and is intended, that the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act apply to those sites where a typical service station business-the supply of motor fuel into the supply tanks of motor vehicles-is carried on by a lessee or licensee operator on his own behalf. In the case of multi-function fuel supply businesses it was, and is, intended that the Act apply if a significant part of the business consists of the kind of typical service station sales I have referred to. A franchise agreement can be subject to the Act even though the franchisee may sell some fuel as agent for the franchisor, or may make some bulk sales. However, where on-site sales into supply tanks of vehicles, made by the operator on his own behalf, form only a very minor and incidental part of total sales, it is not appropriate that the Act should apply.

It was seen that the Act needed a test to distinguish situations where service stations sales constituted a significant proportion of the total business-such that the Act would apply, from situations where such sales are insignificant-so that the Act should not apply. However, the provisions now in the Act are not as effective as was first thought, due to the variety and multiplicity of functions that are carried out by operators. The result is that the Act can apply to some businesses with quite minimal service station type sales.

The amendments I am introducing tonight are directed at distinguishing between fuel outlets on the basis of the significance of any service station type sales made at the site. The amendments are also intended to provide that in any borderline cases, the Act will apply and the rights of the franchisee protected. This point has added to the complexity of the drafting. A more refined test based on the ratio of service station type sales to total sales of petrol and diesel fuel is proposed to determine the application of the Act and certain ambiguities in the current section are to be removed.

The basic test proposed is that the Act not apply to sites where more than 85 per cent of the total amount of petrol or diesel fuel supplied by the franchisor to the operator of the site is sold, by that operator, through the site either in bulk, at wholesale or as an agent of the franchisor. However, the amending Bill provides, in effect, a presumption that the Act is to apply to all agreements containing all three elements of the definition of franchise agreement under the Act-that is, right to occupation of premises, right to use a trade mark, and supply of fuel. Positive action must be taken by an oil company franchisor for the Act not to apply by reason of this 85 per cent test. In addition, an agreement may be excluded from the operation of the Act by the 85 per cent test only for so long as service station type sales by the franchisee do not attain 15 per cent of total sales. Once that figure is reached, the Act applies, and will continue to apply throughout the whole term of the agreement and of any renewals to which the franchisee may be entitled.

This new approach has required complex legislative drafting. In addition to devising a more appropriate base for the application of the Act, it is necessary to deal with a number of factual situations. The rights of parties in these different situations have to be clearly spelt out-for example, the legislation has to cater for agreements entered into before the 1980 Act and still in force; agreements entered into under the 1980 Act; and agreements entered into after the amending legislation.

A further area in which there has been some uncertainty is section 20 of the Act-the price discrimination provision. This section is considered by the Government to be of major importance. It was drafted to implement the Government 's intention to limit price discrimination between the lessee and licensee dealers of a franchisor. Whilst the Government considers the present section does achieve this intention, we think it is preferable to remove any doubts about the section's application.

I turn now to the important provisions of the amending Bill. Section 6 is the focal point of the Act. It specifies those agreements to which the Act applies. Clause 4 of the Bill amends section 6. The basic premise of the Bill is that the Act applies to all agreements which contain the three elements of the definition of 'franchise agreement'-the right to occupy premises, the right to use a trade mark and the supply of fuel. However, the Act will not apply if one of the two grounds provided in proposed new sub-sections 6 (1B) and 6 (1E) is available and the franchisor elects to exercise rights under those sub-sections.

First, sub-section 6 (1E) applies to new agreements entered into after commencement of the amending provisions. If the franchisor expects on reasonable grounds that more than 85 per cent of total sales will not be typical 'service station' sales, made by the franchisee on his behalf, and if he serves the requisite notice on the franchisee, the Act does not apply to the franchise agreement during the following 12 months. However, to ensure that this sub- section cannot be used to circumvent the operation of the Act, sub-section 6 (1F ) deems the Act to have applied from the commencement of the agreement if in fact this 85 per cent test is not met in the first six months after entering into the agreement.

Secondly, sub-section 6 (1B) deals with agreements already in existence at the commencement of the amending legislation. It also covers subsequent agreements to which sub-section 6 (1E) was applied in the first instance. If a franchisor so elects, a franchise agreement may be taken outside the Act when, over the previous 12 months, more than 85 per cent of total sales by the franchisee have not been 'service station' type sales made on his own behalf. This exclusion from the Act operates for a period of 12 months only. At the end of this period the test in sub-section 6 (1B) can again be applied to determine the future status of the agreement.

Sub-section 6 (1G) provides that once the Act applies to an agreement it continues to do so for the whole term of the agreement, and of all renewals the franchisee may be entitled to under section 17 of the principal Act. By sub- section 6 (1A) operation of the amending legislation is to be delayed for 30 days except for section 10, supply of motor fuel, and section 15, disclosure of information by the franchisor. This delay is to enable parties to assess their position and to avail themselves of the new provisions and of the transitional measures I have mentioned.

Section 20 of the principal Act-the price discrimination provision-is amended by clause 7 to clarify that it only applies to sales to franchisees under agreements to which the Act applies; that a franchisor is not liable for compensation where he has reasonable grounds for believing motor fuel was acquired for purposes other than retail sale for use in road vehicles; and that the onus for establishing these reasonable grounds is on the person asserting that fact.

Clause 5 amends section 15 of the principal Act to clarify its operation and to clarify that details of the information to be supplied and the manner of providing the information to the franchisee can be specified in the Regulations. Clause 6 amends section 17 of the principal Act to enable a franchisor, on renewal of an agreement, to vary a term relating to the manner of assessing amounts payable for motor fuel or other stock. Clause 6 also clarifies the provisions which protect a franchisee from unreasonable rent increases.

The Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act Amendment Bill and the companion Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill are being introduced at this stage to allow further study of the provisions of both Bills by honourable members and the public. Any submissions that are received will be carefully examined. It would assist if submissions could reach me, or my Department, by 26 March 1982. I commend the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Amendment Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RETAIL MARKETING SITES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to clarify the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980 to ensure that the Government's original policy intention is implemented. The Government proposes that, as with the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Amendment Bill, debate on this Bill be deferred until later in this session to enable honourable members, all sectors of the industry, and the general public time to consider, and comment on, the legislation.

In my speech to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Amendment Bill, I reaffirmed the Government's belief in the equity of the petroleum marketing legislation and advised that the amendments do not represent a change of policy. The Government has been monitoring the operation of the legislation since its enactment. We are satisfied that in general the legislation is achieving its policy objectives. The Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill seeks to amend the principal Act to clarify the extent of its application to retail petroleum outlets. The Bill also alters the technical basis by which the rules on site operation are applied-from a basis of sales made on a 'particular day' to a basis of sales made 'during a month'.

The Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act was intended to apply to outlets, including depots, at which the major oil companies engaged in substantial direct retail sales to the public-broadly speaking, those outlets that conduct a ' service station' business. It was not intended, and is not intended, that the Act apply to sites where the direct sale of motor fuel by the company is only a very minor or incidental part of the company's operation at that site. To give effect to this intention, provision was made in the Act for it not to apply to sites where on-site sales into the supply tanks of motor vehicles did not exceed 25 per cent of total on-site sales. When the 25 per cent level was exceeded, that site would be subject to the Act.

Experience over the past 18 months has made it apparent that this formula is not appropriate to give effect to the Government's intention. The sites Act has a wider application than intended. The Act and its prohibitions apply to a number of outlets which engage in direct retail selling of motor fuel to only a very minor extent and in some cases not to the general public. The amending Bill is intended to rectify this situation. It provides that the Act not apply when less than 15 per cent of the total retail sales of petrol and diesel fuel effected through a site was motor fuel, as defined, sold by retail; that is, broadly, when 'service station' sales made by or on behalf of an oil company constitute less than 15 per cent of the total retail sales of the site.

A second problem area which has emerged is not one which requires amendment of the legislation. There was an erroneous belief on the part of some companies that depots and country distributor sites would be totally exempt from the Act, irrespective of the activities engaged in at that site. Due to this misconception, some companies failed to disclose depot and company distributor sites when notifying numbers of direct sales sites in 1980 prior to the enactment of the Act. Therefore, no account was taken of these sites in the allocation of sites to companies, or in arriving at the level of divorcement to be ultimately achieved. Subsequently, some companies did not include these sites in their early returns under the Act and did not take steps to bring these sites within the quota they were entitled to operate.

The result of this misconception, and inaction, would have been disruption of the distribution network, particularly in country areas, and inconvenience to customers when sites quotas came into operation on 19 September 1981. In order to ensure that disruption, and inconvenience to consumers, did not occur-and not as has been alleged in some quarters to ease the divorcement burden faced by companies-the number of permitted retail sites companies can operate in the 12 months commencing 19 September 1981 was increased by regulation. I emphasise that this was a temporary increase. Additional sites were allocated only after each company had demonstrated a need for that number of additional sites if its distribution network was not to be severely disrupted. The Government still intends to achieve a 50 per cent reduction in the number of outlets which conduct typical service station sale functions by September 1982. The purpose of the amendments to be effected by the Bill is to restore precision and to give effect to the Government's original intention.

I now wish to outline briefly the specific provisions of the Bill. Clause 4- Operation of retail sites-amends section 6 of the principal Act. Firstly, it alters the relevant period for determining the application of the Act from a ' particular day' to 'during a month'. This change facilitates ease of administration and compliance with the Act as the unamended formulation could in marginal cases have required a daily analysis of sales. Clause 4 also amends the exemption test. The Act when amended will not apply during a particular month if the quantity of motor fuel sold during that month, by or on behalf of the corporation, at that site for road vehicles amounts to less than 15 per cent of the total retail petrol and diesel fuel sales effected through the site. This includes all categories of retail sales-bulk on-site, bulk off-site and pump sales made at the site or at other premises where the sale has the requisite connection with the site. Clause 3 amends the definitions of 'market research site' and 'training site'. Under the Act oil companies are entitled to a small number of training sites and market research sites outside their allocated quota . The present definitions require that the 'principal use' of the site be as a market research site or a training site. However, in practice, such sites may be used for these purposes concurrently with other uses, or intermittently. The definition is being amended to require only that there be 'substantial use' of the site as a training site or market research site. Because of the strict limits on the number of these sites permitted off-quota, the effect of this amendment will be very limited.

Clauses 5 to 8 and clause 10 effect amendments required by the change to applying the Act on a monthly basis. Clause 7 also amends section 11 of the principal Act to provide for extending by regulation the information required to be supplied by companies in returns. Additional powers dealing with the production of books are conferred by clause 9. The current section 14 provisions are extended, using a similar approach to that adopted with the Companies Act- but the provisions have been tailored to the requirements of the amended Act. Clause 11 preserves any rights which may have accrued to certain commission agents under the Act as originally enacted.

Finally, I repeat the undertaking given in my second reading speech to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Amendment Bill that any submissions received on that Bill or the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill, will be carefully considered. It would assist if submissions could reach me or my Department by 26 March 1982. I commend the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bounty (Drilling Bits) Act 1980 and the Bounty (Non-Adjustable Wrenches) Act 1981 to extend the bounty assistance under those Acts until 31 December 1982 but at half the rates of bounty and half the annual limits on the amount of available bounty as specified in the principal Acts. The bounty schemes, which terminated on 31 December 1981, provided short term assistance to Australian producers and manufacturers of cemented carbide drilling bits and non-adjustable wrenches pending further inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission. Bounty assistance on non-adjustable wrenches was payable at 11c for each bountiable implement and the total bounty payment was limited to a maximum of $620,000 during the bounty period. Bounty assistance on cemented carbide drilling bits was scaled on the basis of bit size and the total bounty payments were limited to a maximum of $150,000 in any one year. The extension of the bounty assistance to these industries follows the Government's acceptance of the recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission contained in its report of 30 June 1981 on Cutlery, Industrial Knives and Handtools.

In respect of non-adjustable wrenches the Industries Assistance Commission found that the major local manufacturer, Siddons Industries Ltd, improved its market performance since receiving the bounty and was rationalising its operation. The Commission considered this industry to be relatively economically efficient at moderate levels of assistance but was concerned that the sudden withdrawal of the additional assistance might cause resources to move out of this activity. It therefore recommended bounty assistance at half the previous rate for a further 12 months. In respect of the drilling bits, the Commission found that the greater part of the local industry producing rock drills is, with moderate levels of tariff assistance, relatively economically efficient and that its further development is consistent with the Government's broad objective of promoting a more efficient manufacturing sector. The Commission recommended that , in order to provide the local producer with the opportunity to improve its market performance further, short term bounty assistance for drilling bits should be extended for a further 12 month period but at half the rate of those previously payable. After 31 December 1982, the manufacture of non-adjustable wrenches will be assisted by a long term general tariff of 25 per cent and the production of drilling bits will be assisted by a long term general tariff of 15 per cent. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kerin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present interim report No. 3 of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members are aware, the Commonwealth and Victorian governments in September 1980 jointly commissioned Mr F. X. Costigan, Q.C., to inquire into and report upon the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. To date, Mr Costigan has provided to both governments three interim reports. In line with Mr Costigan's recommendations, it is intended that the first two reports should remain confidential for the time being. However, Mr Costigan has indicated that, in his view, there is no good reason why interim report No. 3 should not be made public. The Commonwealth Government concurs with Mr Costigan on this point and interim report No. 3 has been tabled accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: While Interim Report No. 3 is concerned primarily with the question of tax avoidance activities involving painters and dockers, the report indicates other areas, namely, social security and workers' compensation frauds where, in the words of the Royal Commission, 'The community has suffered considerable loss'.

At this point I do not propose to comment on the substance of the report. However, the report itself is reasonably short and members will quickly be able to glean the extent of the malpractices reported on by the Commissioner. I mention, however, the two substantive recommendations contained in the report. First, the Commission recommends that the secrecy provisions of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 be amended so as to enable Royal Commissions to have access to tax information where the terms of reference authorise such access. Secondly, the Royal Commission has recommended that its own terms of reference be varied to take advantage of the suggested amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Mr Speaker, the Government recognises that the recommendations of the Commission raise very serious issues on which there will clearly be substantial differences of view. The Government is therefore giving careful consideration to the report and will announce its decision in this regard at an early date.

I would mention that Mr Justice Stewart, who is currently conducting a Royal Commission into the activities of the Clark drug syndicate, has also recently written seeking access by his Royal Commission to taxation records. Additionally , members will be aware that the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs recommended that information held by the Commissioner of Taxation should be accessible for the purpose of drug law enforcement. The recommendations of these other Royal Commissions will, of course, be taken into consideration in determining the Government's attitude to this important question.

Finally, I note that passages in the Commission's report comment on the operations of the Australian Taxation Office. A statement by the Commissioner of Taxation dealing with these matters has been prepared and, as sought by him, I table the statement and also seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
ROYAL COMMISSION INTO FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNIONSTATEMENT BY COMMISSIONER OF TAXATION

Neither I nor any of my officers gave evidence to the Royal Commission. Contrary to what might be assumed from the report I was not told in advance of the nature of the disclosures to be made about the people mentioned in the report as having false bank accounts nor was I told the names of these people. In this connection I point out too that I am only able to act according to law in taking action to ''secure'' moneys in bank accounts. The fact that moneys are withdrawn from an account before a tax liability is determined obviously does not mean that the liability will not be discharged.

In informal conversation with the Royal Commissioner and counsel assisting him I made a number of points about my administrative policies. I stressed that tax evasion or avoidance is itself not a criminal offence in Australia and that my officers operate in a financial context using special statutory powers. I said I did not unnecessarily expose my officers to danger or risk. But I challenge most strongly the Royal Commissioner's conclusion that tax officers failed to attend hearings either on any specific day or generally because of a fear of physical danger to them. I entirely disagree with that finding. In fact, tax officers have been present at hearings of the Commission and from time to time carry out investigations involving the criminal element.

I point out that there is an almost bottomless pool of work in the tax enforcement area. It is a matter of judgment how available investigation resources are employed from time to time. It is my task to sheet home tax liabilities, not to find evidence of non-tax criminal or civil offences. I was, of course, well aware of the schemes that the Royal Commission has referred to and, indeed, was the source of the information on these that led to the Government being advised to enact the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. The identity of directors of stripped companies-or the equivalent where a trust is stripped-is not an essential matter from the point of view of taxation administration, particularly if they are men of straw. Painters and dockers were , of course, not the only people who participated in the schemes in these ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I do not propose to comment on the matters that have been raised by the Royal Commission or the Commissioner of Taxation until they have been fully considered by the Government. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, in accordance with the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908 authorises the publication of:
(a) The third interim report of the Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union; and
(b) The statement of the Commissioner of Taxation on the Royal Commission's report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Newman) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This third interim report of the Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, this slim document, is potentially one of the most explosive papers to be tabled in this House. The Government did not intend it, but it has indeed set a sprat to catch a mackerel and what a mackerel it has turned up. The Royal Commissioner has some very important things to say about the reprehensible and criminal activities of some painters and dockers and the way in which they have defrauded the public purse in the areas of social security and workers compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make it absolutely clear at the outset of what I have to say on behalf of the Opposition that the Opposition joins with all reasonable people in deploring these activities, as they are properly established, and believes it appropriate that the course of justice should be fully pursued by the processes of law in respect of those activities. Having made that unequivocally clear, so that there is no possibility of misrepresentation in any quarter as to our position on what has been disclosed by the Royal Commissioner in regard to certain activities of some painters and dockers, let us see what the Royal Commissioner has in fact to say.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention and that of the House to paragraph 1. 05 which appears at page 3 of the report. Having referred to those activities of certain painters and dockers in defrauding the public purse in regard to social security and workers compensation, matters, and having dealt relatively briefly with them, the Royal Commissioner had this to say:

But the figures I have mentioned above pale into insignificance compared with the figures involved in the tax avoidance industry which is the subject of this report. By way of example, four specific cases considered by the Commission involve a non-payment of tax in excess of $2,000,000. There are hundreds of such cases. The amounts to be identified and recovered by Government are enormous. It is for this reason that I have limited this report in essence to this particular problem.
He adds in paragraph 1.06:

The matters referred to in this report form the basis for my recommendation that the Income Tax Assessment Act should be amended. The amendment is directed to the enhancement of the investigative capabilities of the Commission. Bearing in mind that the Commission has a limited life, such amendment, if approved by Government, would require early legislation if it is to be of use to the Commission.
Before I conclude my remarks I will make some preliminary comments in regard to those recommendations.

I ask the House now to take particular notice of what the Royal Commissioner goes on to say under the rather illuminating heading of chapter 2, 'Slutzkin Rides Again'. Just in case any honourable member should be in any doubt as to the implication of that rather graphic chapter heading, I would mention that it is of course a reference to the Slutzkin case which was decided by the High Court in earlier days and was to form the basis of subsequent tax avoidance schemes. I venture to suggest that few more important paragraphs have come before this House for its consideration than this first paragraph, 2.01, of chapter 2, headed 'Slutzkin Rides Again'. The Royal Commissioner goes on to say:

2.01 The Commission's investigations into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers' Union has led it, to the surprise of many, to the tax avoidance industry. This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last five years, at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. Unfortunately this industry carried with it a serious detriment to the interests of government and the Australian community. The detriment was twofold: In the first place it diverted from the Treasury tax which would prima facie be payable on income of taxpayers; in the second place it diverted the tax payable by those engaged in that industry. The amounts involved are very large indeed, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars per year or more. The impact on the community has been very serious. It has introduced into the community a class of people, almost invariably the highest earners, who pay little or no tax and make no contribution in that way as citizens to their fair share of community costs.
The Royal Commissioner concluded:
In addition it has made more difficult for government the task of providing for the community as a whole a more equitable and reduced taxation burden.

I think honourable members will see the justification I have for pointing up the paramount importance of this opening paragraph of chapter 2 of the third interim report of the Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the justification for my initial observation that the Government, without intending to, has indeed set a sprat to catch a mackerel.

What we have revealed here is out of the investigations of this Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. We have the opening up in very much more detail of this issue and of this fastest growing industry in the country-says the Royal Commissioner-the tax avoidance industry. He points out that this industry is concentrated in the area of the very wealthy section of the community and that the existence of this industry is not only imposing a situation in which people with the greatest capacity to pay and to meet their taxation requirements are avoiding it but also necessarily, by way of implication from that, it is imposing upon the whole community a situation where it is more difficult for government to provide for that whole community a more equitable and reduced taxation burden.

I go on, then, to what the Commissioner has to say as he comes towards the concluding sections of his report before he goes on to make the recommendations to the Government as to what course of action he believes is necessary to deal with this situation which his investigations have so unexpectedly exposed. After he has described the way in which the schemes are operated and the way in which some painters and dockers have been involved in the scheme, at paragraph 4.05 on page 16 he says:

The situation has now been reached by the Commission in this area of its investigation where firstly access is essential to the records of the Commissioner of Taxation and secondly there is a need for the closest co- operation between this Commission and the Taxation Office in the furtherance of its investigation. The Commission requires the active assistance of Taxation Investigation officers. I require access to taxation records.
That is what the Commissioner says: 'I require access to taxation records.' He continues:

Joint action of this kind is as necessary in this area as it has proved to be where the Commonwealth and the States have set up joint task forces to investigate criminal organisations whose activities cross State borders.
The Royal Commissioner then concluded this paragraph by stating:

Provided there is this joint co-operation, there is good reason for believing that the Commonwealth will be able to take concerted action in this area of tax avoidance with the countless financial benefits not only in respect of past schemes but also in the deterrence of future frauds.

It is obviously important to relate paragraph 4.05, where he says what can be achieved if this is done, back to that earlier paragraph that I read. He talked about the inequities of the tax avoidance industry, Australia's fastest growing industry. I repeat the last sentence:
In addition it has made more difficult for government the task of providing for the community as a whole a more equi- table and reduced taxation burden.

So let us have no doubt about the great implications of what this Royal Commission is saying in respect of basic areas of discussion which are properly before this Parliament and are foremost in the minds of the community at the moment-what can we do about creating a more equitable and reduced taxation burden? This is an issue which is at the forefront of the political and social discussion in this community today and the Commissioner is saying that if he is given the powers which he asks for then, with the joint co-operation to which he refers, there is good reason for believing that the Commonwealth will be able to take concerted action in this area of tax avoidance with countless financial benefits not only in respect of past schemes but also in the deterrence of future frauds. He was saying that if what he asks for is granted we will be able to move towards that situation where we can more sensibly and with a greater degree of realistic anticipation talk about the possibility of having a more equitable and reduced taxation burden in the community simply because we will have the situation that those with the greatest capacity to pay tax who have been avoiding it will be brought into a situation where they pay their share in this community and enable, for the rest of the community, this more equitable situation.

Having said those things, the Royal Commissioner goes on to make his recommendations. Without going into the technicalities of his recommendations, he is asking that section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act be amended in two ways. He asks firstly that sub-section 16 (1) be amended. It relates to the purpose of requiring officers to observe secrecy. So that it will be well within the understanding of honourable members, that sub-section provides:

For the purposes of this section, 'officer' means a person who is or has been appointed or employed by the Commonwealth or by a State, and who by reason of that appointment or employment, or in the course of that employment, may acquire or has acquired information respecting the affairs of any other person, disclosed or obtained under the provisions of this Act or of any previous law of the Commonwealth relating to income tax.

The first proposal of the Commissioner, therefore, is that there be inserted after the words, 'employed by the Commonwealth or by a State', the words, 'not being a person appointed pursuant to the Royal Commissions Act'. The second and related proposal of the Royal Commissioner is that section 16 (4) of the Income Tax Assessment Act be amended to add to the list of authorised recipients of information. At the moment sub-section 16 (4) provides:
Nothing in the section shall be deemed to prohibit the Commissioner, a Second Commissioner or a Deputy Commissioner, or any person thereto authorised by him, from communicating any information to--
There is then listed a number of categories. The Royal Commissioner is seeking in his second proposal that there be added sub-section (j), which is to read:

any person to whom a Commission has been issued by the Governor-General pursuant to the Royal Commissions Act where the Terms of Reference of that Commission include a reference in specific terms to this Act.

His third proposal, which completes his desire to put himself in a position where he can be of assistance conjointly with the Commonwealth in bringing this industry to a halt, is referred to in paragraph 4.08, where he says:

If such amendment is made it will be necessary to amend the terms of my Commonwealth Commission by adding at the end of the first paragraph after the words 'Naval Defence Act 1910' 'or has engaged in illegal activities in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Act.'

The Opposition regards the secrecy provisions of the Act as of fundamental importance. We support those provisions; we are committed to them. But we appreciate the very careful way in which the Commissioner has asked for very limited and careful amendments so that he will be able to achieve the noble purpose that he has outlined in his reports. We appreciate that the Government is going to look at this, but on behalf of the Opposition we flag that we will be considering it, of course, We indicate that, for the reasons so cogently outlined by the Royal Commissioner, these proposals which he brings forward so responsibly, so carefully and so circumspectly, should meet with the unanimous approval of a House which is concerned with trying to create a more equitable and fair burden of taxation in this community.
Debate (on motion by Mr Falconer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.
Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Nixon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill, the Edible Oils (Export Inspection Charge) Bill and the Edible Oils (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a cognate debate on these Bills? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) for breaking up the debate on this series of Bills into two cognate debates. We are dealing with the dairy industry, the edible oil industry, the egg industry and the honey industry. I think it is a bit much to try to speak to eight Bills, even though the measures they deal with are all related, in 20 minutes. I suppose we are in the land of milk and honey tonight, or if we look at the next debate, perhaps we are talking about the birds and the bees.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these Bills are related. They all relate to export charges on the idustries concerned and the Government's decision now to get from the industries some 50 per cent of the export inspection charges. I guess this shows the hypocrisy of the Government because I well recall when the Labor Government imposed beef inspection charges the great hoo-ha that the then Opposition made at that time. Of course, the worm has turned now and the beef industry, for example, still pays those charges. The Government seems to have no intention of lifting them, even though the cattle industry is now heading for another low. I guess it is no surprise that the Cattlemen's Union of Australia recently passed a nearly unanimous vote of no confidence in the Government.

We heard earlier today in the debate on the canned fruits legislation which increased the levy imposed on that industry the National Country Party say that the growers are quite happy. I guess we will hear the same line again-that the growers will be quite happy with the levying of all these export charges. The Country Party would have us believe that the shires are happy with road funding, that all is well in the country, that it is all right to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority, or whatever was done to it, and that it is all right to get out of soil conservation. I guess in all these things the Opposition just talks to different farmers. It must be different people who write to me and telephone me. I guess all the newspaper stories must be nonsense. In other words , as Dr Pangloss once said: 'All is for the best in the best of possible worlds' .

But whichever way the National Country Party or the Government tries to rationalise it, these charges are simply going to cost the industries concerned more money-something like $307,000 from the dairy industry and $7,000 from the edible oils industry. The edible oil export part of the oil industry-the oil seeds industry-of course is only a very small part of it.

For all these four industries-I shall contain my remarks to dairy products and edible oils for the moment-I guess what has happened is that the Government or the Department of Primary Industry obtained an estimate from the finance section for the cost of inspecting these industries. As I understand it, the same inspectors inspect all four industries. Taking into account the cost of salaries , travel and accommodation, a division was made. The Government required that 50 per cent of the inspection fee cost be recouped, and it was divided in terms of the amount of wage labour on travel and accommodation rather than in terms of the value of the product.

When we look at the range of dairy products, whichever way we go, we see that it would be a very complicated calculation indeed. I guess the Opposition cannot really object too strongly to the way these charges have been calculated, given the Government's requirement. An amount of $307,000 is to be taken from the Australian dairy industry by the Government in accordance with its razor gang recommendations of 30 April 1981. I am not so sure that this really was a specific razor gang measure when we consider that the Government had already decided to place levies on the meat industry, the grain industry and the wool industry for like services in 1979. Although the charge on the dairy industry will be levied on a person who furnishes an export notice for inspection purposes, the cost of this and all other measures will be passed back to the farmers and will eventually be reflected in proportionately lower returns. The maximum rate of $5 per tonne is specified, although the rates for 1981-82 will be a maximum of $2.50 per tonne.

At a time when the dairy industry wants confidence boosting signals from the Government, this Government decides to clobber it, again due, I guess, to the ideological obsession of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of trying to save money by handing functions back to the States, cutting out functions regardless of their intrinsic worth or by charging producers and consumers for public services. The dairy industry is not now a major exporter and due to this returns have risen in recent years; so the imposition is not large in overall terms, given the dairy industry's total returns. But I think we need to recognise that the point has been reached at which real concern for future production levels is justified.

In 1980-81 the industry produced 5.18 billion litres of milk. That figure was down by about 4.2 per cent on the previous year. It is estimated that for the current year ending June 1982 production will be about 5 billion litres, perhaps a little more with better weather. That estimate again is down by 3.6 per cent. People are saying that the downturn in milk production is bottoming out and levelling off, but the statistics still do not show that. So there is a real reason for the concern. Seven thousand tonnes of some 68,000 tonnes of butter will be exported in this current year. Of course, we will also be importing some 4,000 tonnes for re-export repacking.

We are still exporting large amounts of other products-for example, about 9,000 tonnes of casein, 42,000 tonnes of whole milk powder, 40,000 tonnes of skim milk powder and about 49,000 tonnes of cheese. These are estimates for the current year. There are now some complaints by some of our more traditional cheese markets that we cannot supply all that they would like, and although export prices are still not stable, export markets are certainly paying at the present time. Even if they were not, with the production levels we now have, the proportion of production now being consumed domestically is sufficient to cushion the local industry against any quick downturns in the export market. But the industry is on the horns of a dilemma to a large degree. The level of production has allowed a measure of prosperity but the industry really needs to know where to go from here. What sort of signal should it get to produce more, or where do they take it?

One of the other concerns of many people in the industry-these are people who talk to me; perhaps they are not the ones who talk to the Government or the Country Party-is the future of the Australian Dairy Corporation. The Corporation is now becoming more and more concerned with the domestic market. Producers are querying its role. While the Corporation has a charter to promote milk products domestically, it does not have powers over the liquid markets or the direction of milk and, of course, there are large private processors of milk as well as the co-operatives. The relationship between the Corporation, the co-operatives, the producers and the private processors of milk are becoming more and more blurred.

I think we can say quite clearly that the Government has abdicated its role for policy direction in the industry. I know there is a lot of talking going on behind the scenes. But the Government seems to be happy to see policy control carried out by the States and the Corporation, with producers being represented on a range of industry bodies. When everyone agrees in that great mass of conflicting interests, the Government will move. I think there are club-like aspects in this form of organisation, the sort of rural politics of the industries and I guess the Asia Dairy Industries case showed up some of the deficiencies and the fact that rocking the boat is frowned upon. But I do not think it should be beyond the Commonwealth Government really to say what strategy it is following from an Australian national dairy industry point of view.

A bit of jawboning about the level of underwriting that went on last year is hardly a policy or a national strategy. Industry rationalisation has taken place and the stage 2 recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry of 1976 have been reached de facto due the levels of production. The whole system of levies is not now dealing with an industry it was intended to deal with. The legislation needs to be reviewed. Similarly, the dairy produce legislation, which goes back to 1924, still governs in large degree the operations of the Australian Dairy Corporation as primarily an export-orientated body.

What, if anything, is the Government or the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) going to do about these matters to give the industry some idea of where it is going or what strategy the Government would like to see? At the recent National Agricultural Outlook Conference, Mr Vawser, the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, summed up some of the essential elements or the circumstances of the industry of today. He said that the industry has rationalised itself to the point where further contraction will almost certainly damage its viability, and that this would not be in the interests of the Australian consumer or the economy generally. He said that the current economic climate is taking its toll among the dairy farming industry in that many farmers are leaving the industry to capitalise on the high land or stock values of their properties. This same factor is hindering new entrants to dairying because of the very large investment required in relation to achievable returns. The industry currently produces an exportable surplus which barely ensures that the needs of the domestic market are met.

Of course, the industry is vulnerable to imports because of the distortions and imperfections of the international market and the low level of protection provided by the Government. As we all know the international market is a corrupt market, due mainly to the policies of the European Economic Community. The marketing structure of the industry is very fragmented and usually follows State borders. Consequently, it is not in a position to defend the domestic market against any concerted effort by importers to gain a market share. State governments and their dairy marketing authorities have considerable influence over the direction of Australian dairying yet their policies can be divergent with respect to a national approach to dairying.

The industry, as we all well know-I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have a very close interest in the dairy industry-is made up of three interdependent sectors, namely producers, processors and marketers. As I have said, some of those processors in Victoria particularly, are large private processors. These sectors come together on a national basis through the Australian Dairy Industry Conference. The Conference is mainly a political lobbying force with its main interest in Federal Government policies. While the Australian Dairy Corporation may believe that that Conference is the best vehicle for the adoption of a national approach to dairying, I believe that the Government has to take a clearer role, give some direction and make some statements on where it would like to see the dairy industry head. The essential elements of a national strategy must include a review of the Corporation's activities and its legislation. It should include some requirement for adequate supplies of milk to be supplied to Australian consumers. It should contain something about the fact that returns have to be optimised and that prices for manufacturing and marketing milk have to be more closely matched to real relative costs of production. There needs to be stability for the industry to plan with confidence , and means must be found for improving productivity by way of technological advance, and of course the industry, on its own bat, is certainly doing a lot of that at this time.

One of the matters most concerning the Australian dairy industry at present is the problem of closer economic relations with New Zealand. The Opposition is pleased, on behalf of the dairy industry, to see that the Minister is taking a reasonably firm stand with the ebullient Mr Muldoon on some of his statements and is giving as good as he is given. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has recently published a paper on that matter. While I am not 100 per cent convinced of what the BAE found on that, what it was setting out to do was to try to make a valid comparison between two industries, so that if there is to be trade between the two countries, the Australian dairy industry can get some accurate idea of to what extent the New Zealand dairy industry is more favoured than the Australian industry.

The points which I do not think the BAE touched on enough was the fact that the taxation regime for New Zealand dairy farmers is far different and more beneficial to New Zealand farmers than it is to Australians; that interest rates , particularly interest rates for their equivalent of the Australian Dairy Corporation, are highly subsidised; and that access to credit for the dairy industry and dairy farmers generally in New Zealand is far better than it is in Australia.

The BAE report was rather lengthy. Perhaps the House will allow me to summarise some of it, because I think that this matter is one of the major concerns of the dairy industry. I have been trying to stress that we need to have a national strategy for the dairy industry and that the industry needs to know where it is going. There is simply no way that we can have any sort of stability or planning if we have a situation in which imports may or may not be allowed into this country. What the BAE paper said was that it is generally believed-I share this belief-that dairying is likely to be more affected by differing levels of economic integration than other major primary products, such as beef, wool and wheat.

From a purely economic point of view, comparing the two countries, the New Zealand dairy industry is more important to that country than dairying is to Australia. In New Zealand dairying constitutes 15 per cent of rural production, but it constitutes only 6 per cent to 7 per cent in Australia. There is not that much difference between the two countries' production of milk, but New Zealand being a smaller country, it means a lot more to that country. About 16 per cent of the New Zealand total 1980 export earnings, for example, came from dairy products, by comparison with Australian dairy products, which account for less than about 2 per cent of total Australian exports. Dairy cattle numbers have been declining in both countries, but at a faster rate in Australia. Making a comparison of the two sectors, and looking at the market milk sector first, we find that in Australia the market milk price has exceeded the price of milk manufacturing by more than 50 per cent. The market milk sector accounts for around 30 per cent of total milk production but some 50 per cent to 55 per cent of returns, and the supplies and prices are regulated by the State authorities. This sector is also highly regulated in New Zealand, but along different lines, and the supply of milk is organised independently of manufacturing milk. Produce prices tend to move in line with returns for manufacturing milk.

In the manufacturing milk sector, where all the concern is-it is of particular concern to Victoria-in Australia the market for manufacturing milk can be divided into the domestic and the export markets for dairy products. New Zealand does not have a policy of high domestic prices for manufactured dairy products. In Australia the domestic market for manufactured dairy products utilises about 45 per cent of total milk production. Domestic prices are maintained at a higher level than exports by a levy system, but not to any marked degree. The export market absorbs around 20 per cent to 30 per cent of the total milk production. In general, returns from this market for Australia have tended to be below those on domestic markets. In New Zealand the manufacture of dairy products is under the overall supervision of the New Zealand Dairy Board, which also pools returns from domestic and export markets. The New Zealand Dairy Board has wider powers than the Australian Dairy Corporation. Although New Zealand does not have a policy of high domestic prices for manufactured dairy products, New Zealand producer returns are influenced by the high returns for butter sold on the United Kingdom market under special EEC access arrangements. As I have said, the New Zealand Dairy Board not only has wider powers than the ADC, but also it has special access to credit on very low terms-down to as low as 1 1/2 per cent.

Looking at market prospects, in Australia the dominant market for milk and manufactured dairy products is the domestic market, which takes about 75 per cent to 80 per cent of total milk output, whereas in New Zealand the situation is reversed. Further contraction of dairying in New Zealand is likely to result in diminished ability to supply exports. The sudden emergence of new export prospects for Australian dairy products is regarded as unlikely in the foreseeable future because attempted inroads into new markets in third countries are likely to meet with strong competition from New Zealand and the EEC. Domestic markets in Australia seem to be stabilising at a time when milk production is falling. Australia and New Zealand produce similar ranges of dairy products and compete on world markets, especially the markets of Japan, South East Asia and the Middle East. New Zealand continues to rely on the United Kingdom market for about 60 per cent of its butter exports. Loss of this access for New Zealand dairy products will have serious implications for Australian exports; similarly with future levels of EEC exports and the level of protection in the EEC.

Let us look now at Australian imports of dairy products. The trade relationships at present between Australia and New Zealand are determined more by informal agreements than by formal barriers or tariffs-that is, they are gentlemen's agreements, and with people such as Mr Muldoon and our Minister for Primary Industry I am sure that they are indeed gentlemen's agreements. Cheese has been the only product to be imported into Australia in significant quantities. Cheese imports from New Zealand were 37 per cent of total imports and account for about 5 per cent of domestic consumption. Net imports of butter were about zero, but in the last year about 4,000 tonnes were imported. However, it has been mainly for re-export. It is generally true to say that imports of dairy products into Australia are at very low levels. But the question is whether imports of dairy products will be needed to meet shortages on the Australian domestic market in the future. I say, and I am sure the Australian dairy industry says, that that situation should not be reached.

The BAE then set about analysing the trans-Tasman trade generally. We should really be trying to say what our policy is in this area. I guess the Minister for Primary Industry is grappling with that. The relationship at present is informal. Such tariff barriers which do exist could be removed with little or no direct effect on trade. Mutual agreement has been reached to limit imports of cheddar cheese from New Zealand. We have also agreed to have inter-industry consultation for all other cheeses. As I have said, cheese is the only significant item of dairy imports into Australia and imports from New Zealand account for about 5 per cent of our cheese consumption. So we can say that generally the current level of dairy product imports from New Zealand is low and supplants an insignificant proportion of milk production in Australia. The BAE made a calculation of about one per cent.

When the BAE looked at some of the costs, it found that the production costs per kilogram butterfat of manufacturing milk is 22 per cent higher in Australia than in New Zealand. This accounts for the 3 per cent consumer subsidy which applies in New Zealand. I would say that there are many in the dairy industry in Australia who would debate this 22 per cent higher figure and believe that the BAE has not taken some of the aspects I have pointed to earlier into account. To get some measure of import competition that New Zealand could cause to the Australian market, the BAE did two evaluations. It evaluated the impact on dairying in Australia at two different stages with the prices in being at the time. In other words, it did a simulation study. The years it picked were 1977- 78 and 1979-80.

In 1977-78 the landed prices of New Zealand imports into Australia would have been 9 per cent lower than the ruling domestic price in Australia, based on the actual prices received by New Zealand farmers. The effect of this would have been to place at risk an additional 6 per cent of farms and milk production in Australia. That was the least destructive possibility for Australia in the 1977- 78 circumstances. In other words, calculations could have been made that that would have disadvantaged the Australian industry even more. In the 1979-80 circumstances, when world market prices for dairy products and farm profitability in Australia were higher than they were in 1977-78, the extent of New Zealand competitiveness, its competitive potential and the possible contractionary pressures on the Australian dairy industry were considerably reduced. The landed price on that calculation for New Zealand imports in Australia, based on average prices received by New Zealand farmers from all markets, was estimated to exceed the Australian domestic price by only a small amount. The point that needs to be made about these simulations in the BAE's study is that they are very sensitive to exchange rate movements. These in the future are likely to favour New Zealand and again enhance its competitive potential on the Australian market.

If we look at New Zealand's export capacity we can see that New Zealand, due to its smaller size and the great amount available for export, exports over six times as much milk as would be required to supply the Australian market in the most competitive situation, with about half of this quantity going to less profitable markets outside the EEC. Therefore, it is within New Zealand's capacity to meet the requirements of the Australian market under liberalised conditions. As New Zealand's exports to lower priced markets outside the EEC amount to almost three times the amount of milk required to supply the Australian market, even under the most competitive circumstances considered, New Zealand is quite capable of simply diverting dairy products to the Australian market without undergoing any major productive expansion. If we look at the government protection-this is of key interest to the dairy farmers-we can see that the level of protection to manufacturing milk production in Victoria was not significantly different from that in New Zealand when the consumer transfer on market milk was excluded for Victoria and the EEC access benefit was excluded for New Zealand. When the EEC access benefit was included the level of protection in New Zealand exceeded that in Victoria by about 19c per kilogram of butterfat in 1979-80.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lot.

—If the higher levels of government protection for production and marketing in New Zealand were reduced to comparable Australian levels the resulting increase in cost based on landed prices of between 12 per cent and 15 per cent would have meant that some 3 per cent fewer farms would have been at risk. The BAE concluded that the economic significance of the higher levels of protection given to dairying in New Zealand is small when placed in the perspective of other pressures that are likely to influence the prospects of the Australian dairy industry. The higher figure for damage that the BAE study came up with with was 6 per cent but, as the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has interjected, 19c a kilogram butterfat is not a small amount. I do not quite know how the BAE arrived at the figure of only 6 per cent of farms being prejudiced. Even though I do not quite go along with the BAE report, I think we do have a situation in which the fears of the industry are real. I think we have a situation in which the Minister is quite right to say that any quick agreement on this product and other agricultural products will not be too easy to reach. He at least said-the Opposition joins with him in saying this-that the Australian industry should not be subject to unfair competition and that we need to have a viable dairy industry. A viable dairy industry is one that has a capacity to export, otherwise it will not meet the other aim of supplying our consumers. The Australian Dairy Farmers Federation has a firm view on that. It says that there should not be any imports of dairy products from New Zealand unless there is mutual agreement between the industries of both countries, as one would expect.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole question of dairy imports has become an important part of the discussions on closer economic relations. I trust that the Government-I am sure the Opposition will-will take a very keen interest in these negotiations. I think the Government has demonstrated sufficient interest in this issue to dispel some of the fears expressed by dairy farmers in Australia about a year ago when they thought that they may go down the drain due to the trading imbalance between Australia and New Zealand. All people, including dairy farmers , are very much aware of the realities of that trade imbalance and the vulnerability or otherwise of the New Zealand economy.
