But if there is to be any trading between these two countries in agricultural products it has to be a very fair deal and there has to be a lot of thought and consultation going into it.

I will not spend much time on oilseeds. As I said at the outset, I guess it would not hurt to have a wide-ranging debate on the whole oilseeds industry because it is one of real potential. We still import a lot of our oilseeds needs . The broiler industry takes a lot of this product by way of vegetable protein. If we can improve our varieties and techniques, particularly for soya bean, this industry will be a growing industry in Australia for quite a long time to come. The amount of edibile oils we export is only small. There is the potential to export a lot more.

In terms of oilseeds prospects overall, as we all know oilseeds are traded with the futures market very much in mind. In other words the price is set for us by overseas futures markets. There are lower projections for those markets for oilseeds in Australia for 1982 for both the summer and winter crops. But to a large degree most of the operators in the industry in Australia took out guaranteed minimum price contracts and they have been protected against some of the fluctuations on the futures markets. In January of this year-last month-soya bean and grain prices were being quoted at life of contract lows, following a year of steadily declining prices. The situation in Poland hovered over that market for about 18 months and is still a factor to be considered by all operators in the market, particularly speculators.

There was a huge shakeout of speculators in December 1980, followed by a dramatic increase in United States of America interest rates, which left the Chicago futures market with a reduced level of speculative involvement. I will not go into those aspects except to point out that even the oilseeds industry is affected by currency rates, by operations on the futures markets and by the interest rates in the United States and it is very much aware of international trading conditions. It is a relatively healthy industry but, of course, as with all primary industries, it is not without problems. The Opposition supports the measures before the House but feels that these penny pinching operations to obtain inspection fees from these industries really are just that-a bit of penny pinching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to a very interesting speech by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) on the dairy industry. I would not necessarily agree with all of the comments he makes but he has made a very valuable and interesting contribution to the present dairy debate. As he mentioned, the purpose of the Bills is basically to implement an export inspection charge of about 50 per cent of the actual cost of inspection. Whilst supporting the Government on this measure, I make one comment. That is that, while the total cost of that charge is met by the Government, there is possibly no requirement for the dairy industry, or for that matter any other industry so involved, to require accountability of the efficiency of that inspection. Once the industry is required to pay a part of that charge, or even the total charge, I believe that industry has a right to require some statement or accountability that the money that is being contributed by the growers is being efficiently spent.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that that is easier to say than to implement but I believe it is something to which we as a government should work. I believe that it is correct and proper that growers who are so charged should have some sort of audit of how their money is being spent. The position of the dairy industry is quite contrary to that of the canned fruit industry which was the subject of the previous debate. In the short term, the outlook for the dairy industry is very good, in contrast with not only the canned fruit industry but also the depressed beef industry, and possibly also the sugar industry. Over the last couple of years the economic position of the dairy industry has been very good and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, in its Outlook paper for this year's Agricultural Outlook Conference documents this quite well.

This position internationally has resulted basically from the failure of communist agriculture. The dramatic failure of the Eastern European countries to produce food for their large populations has required very large purchases of dairy products and other products from the European Economic Community. They have also had to purchase from New Zealand and now even indirectly from the United States of America via New Zealand. The 100,000 tonne purchase of United States butter via New Zealand is being laundered, if honourable members like, or turned into butter oil and some is being sold indirectly to the Eastern bloc countries. I am not saying that as a criticism because, obviously, such an amount of a dairy product in the United States was a threat to the stability of the international dairy market. I think both the United States and New Zealand have acted responsibly-I hope it will be responsibly-in the disposal of this product.

Of course, in addition to the short term position being good, basically caused by the failure of Eastern European agriculture, there has also been reduced production and exports by Australia and slower than anticipated growth in dairy production in the EEC. But it would be wrong to say, as some countries are now saying, that there is actually a growing international commercial market for dairy products. Countries, in particular those of the EEC and New Zealand, are making optimistic noises about the medium and long term international outlook for dairy products. I am glad that the BAE also challenges this point in its document. Last week I was in Brussels and Strasbourg talking to EEC people. It is disappointing to hear them talk of what they consider to be long term export prospects for their dairy surplus. Of course, anything that they sell on the international market in dairy products would be on a subsidised basis--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like sugar.

—Like sugar-good point. It is also true that in the long term the projections for EEC production are of a 1 1/2 per cent increase each year against a 0.5 per cent increase in consumption. Therefore, the trend is for increased dairy surpluses from the EEC. If one looks at the price proposals for this year, with a 9 1/2 per cent increase, one has to say that the EEC is not trying very hard to do anything to correct this growing imbalance in its dairy market and dairy production. New Zealand is very enthusiastically encouraging increased production. It is doing so through its livestock incentive scheme, through very generous export arrangements and through the tremendous stability mechanism it has in the supplementary minimum price scheme introduced by its government.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told that the scheme could cost the government, for the whole range of agricultural products which it covers, about $200m this year. In the last two days it has led to a row in New Zealand as the New Zealand Government has tried to reduce its financial commitment by trying to force its Wool Board to reduce the reserve price for its wool. I believe it is a program or a policy which the New Zealand Government, in the long run, cannot afford. From our point of view, with closer economic relations, it cannot be allowed to continue. In the United States there are still very large stocks of butter, powder and cheese and presumably more of these products will be placed on the international market through New Zealand if the present arrangement works out. There is at least some encouragement in that the support price for dairying in the 1981 farm bill has been reduced a little from what it previously was.

However, sooner or later, Eastern Europe must have a better grain harvest because it has had two very bad ones in the last two years. This, in turn, will mean that it will have more feed for livestock which will produce more dairy products, among other things. Sooner or later it must wake up and provide the right sorts of incentives for its dairy farmers to produce more towards the capability that their livestock obviously has to produce. When that happens I shudder for the international dairy market. It is obvious that the Eastern European countries will continue to give high priority to the importation of foodstuffs from the West because, if they do not, they will have revolution on their hands. But it is important that the EEC, the United States of America and New Zealand realise that there is not the growing international commercial market for dairy products that they seem to think there is. They should take their share of adjustment, as we in Australia have had to adjust our agricultural and dairy production to the realities of the international market.

There is less support for the dairy industry in this country than in any other country in the world. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa, in quoting the BAE comparison, gave evidence of that in relation to these two countries which together have the lowest forms of government support for all agriculture. We are the second most efficient dairy producer in the world. I cannot think of any secondary industry in Australia that can make a similar claim. Other industries would be well down on any international comparison. But the EEC causes particular concern because, even in the reform proposals of the Common Agricultural Policy which were released last year, the EEC talked of long term export contracts, including markets such as Japan which we consider to be our traditional and correct markets. We were forced by Europe out of their market for our sales of dairy products and other products such as sugar and meat . We created new markets in other countries and now the Europeans, through the generous price support schemes of the Common Agricultural Policy, have developed surpluses and are now seeking through their subsidised exports, to take away from us the markets which we have developed on a commercial basis.

In a recent speech, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) outlined seven points which he considers are essential for negotiation between Australia and New Zealand, or more particularly the dairy industries of the two countries, in relation to the inclusion of the dairy industry in the closer economic relations discussions. I agree with the honourable member for Werriwa that CER is probably the single most important issue in the minds of Australian dairy farmers at the present time.

I would like to congratulate the Minister for Primary Industry for putting forward these points. I believe they are a very sensible basis for discussion between industries. I say to him: 'Good work and stick to your position in this matter'. I believe it is correct for New Zealand to be the first supplier for any shortfall of dairy product in Australia which is mutually agreed to by the industries of both countries. That should be the basis of dairy trade between the two countries. In any other situation, as a minimum, support for the dairy industry in New Zealand would have to be equalised with that of Australia and questions of difference in currency levels would have to be taken into account. As the honourable member for Werriwa pointed out there are taxation, credit, export incentives, livestock incentive schemes, supplementary minimum price schemes, and a whole range of other arrangements which the New Zealand dairy farmer has but the Australian dairy farmer does not. Since that BAE report was made I believe the difference in the degree of government support between the two countries has widened. Probably at the moment in Australia on international comparison terms it would be at a negative level.

I also believe that New Zealand-I have said this in the debate on the canned fruits legislation-is operating on a double standard in relation to CER. New Zealand is claiming that it should have greater access to the Australian dairy market. But New Zealand itself operates and is determined to continue to operate the policy of supplying only in a shortfall situation for a whole range of its own agricultural commodities. I can think of about five or six agricultural industries in Australia which would love to be able to sell their products to New Zealand but they are restricted to the provision of shortfall. If that principle is right for New Zealand producers when it suits them, then it is a principle that had better be right when it comes to the dairy industries of the two countries. So I say once again to the Minister: 'Stick to your position because it is a very correct position in regard to the dairy industry in CER'. I would also say to the Minister that if the EEC continues to look for every possible opportunity to take action against imports from Australia-that seems to be its intent at the moment-then we should have a very hard look at taking anti- dumping action against the increasing imports of cheese from Europe. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address my remarks in this debate just to the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Bill. As indicated by my colleague the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), we on this side of the House do not intend to oppose the measure itself although we do have some misgivings regarding the necessity of opposing the charges. I would like to make some comment on the address given by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). I think it is very heartening to be present at a debate in which there is such a bipartisan approach to a measure such as this, given our general concern for the future of the dairying industry. As honourable members are aware there has been a long term policy of reconstruction in the dairying industry that goes back over many years. This process began as a result of pressures from the market and other economic forces which gradually imposed themselves upon the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: With assistance, or at least encouragement, from government the national dairy herd was reduced to 1.83 million head in March 1981. No doubt the figure may well be a little lower today. These figures have been given by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The size of the herd has been reduced from in excess of 3,263,289 in 1962-63 which is the first year for which complete figures were compiled. I think I ought to indicate that this process has been very long term and very dramatic and traumatic in terms of its effect upon the industry. In 1956-57 the figure was not far short of 3.5 million head. That is a lot of dairy cattle. The statistic for that year was 3,451,450.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not a lot of bull.

—There were a fair number of them as well because that was before aritifical insemination. From that time there has been a decline by, as was indicated, a process of attrition and a process of consolidation et cetera in the industry. But that process was not necessarily as well co-ordinated as it might have been in the early stage. The fall-out in the industry has seen many thousands of dairy farmers leave the industry largely from areas considered to be uneconomical or in conditions which were considered to be uneconomical. In my previous occupation I had quite a number of dairy farmers who had left the industry come into the College of Advanced Education as adult entries to undertake training as prospective teachers. I might suggest too that they came with a tremendous desire to succeed. They were marvellous students. The process of the decline will reach a point where we must recognise that any further reduction in the size of the national herd could well result in a threat to the viability of the industry itself. I think that this point has already been alluded to by the honourable member for Murray and the honourable member for Werriwa. I do not wish to give any further detail on that. However, I think the problem should be seen in conjunction with the need to maintain an export industry. Perhaps it would be more advisable for the Government to look to a restructuring of the administration of the industry with a review of the roles of the various bodies involved. This might have been more valuable than perhaps reclaiming some of the costs of inspection as we feel that this is perhaps rather a petty measure.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members would be aware, the industry is already subject to a series of imposts which result in considerable threats to the returns in the industry. Manufacturers with export potential will attempt to recoup the costs of this added charge by whatever means they can. In this case they tend to pass it back to the producer, thus reducing his or her profit margin. Currently allowing for the normal tensions that beset any complex industry, the dairying industry is in a fairly stable state and this impost will certainly not help because it is one of those imposts which tends to cause a shake-out down the line.

The production levels are now down to five billion litres. Care must be taken to maintain this level if we are to avoid the need to increase imports. Tonight we have already heard from both the honourable member for Murray and the honourable member for Werriwa about just what dangers lie in the increase of imports, especially from across the Tasman. I am quite sure that few dairy farmers look forward to a time when Australia is forced to import butter for its own use. With good management right across the industry this should not happen. What is obviously required is a national dairy strategy. As I have indicated earlier, there has been a major restructuring of the industry already in recent times. What we now need is to review the significance of these changes. Accompanying these changes has been the necessity to review the role and functions of the Australian Dairy Corporation.

I think the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) will agree that there is a need for an ongoing revision of the capacity of the Corporation to meet the needs of the industry as it is undergoing this change. At the moment there is little evidence that the Government has this awareness. The relationship of the ADC with the industry has changed considerably since its formation many years ago. I am sure that the Minister is aware of the fact that the ADC's early brief was heavily orientated towards the export of dairy products. Again, that was mentioned. At that time, when much of our dairy produce was exported, the ADC certainly was of vital importance, but its role has altered in a somewhat ad hoc way. Nowadays both the Government and the dairy industry have come to depend on the ADC to perform tasks related to the home or domestic market; in other words, the ADC is now expected to service the domestic requirements, a role which previously was performed by other bodies. If it is to perform its task adequately it must have adequate legislative authority.

Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask the Minister to give consideration to these changed circumstances with a view to bringing legislation into line with the needs. I am sure that the various State authorities, both those directly concerned with marketing and those representing producers and manufacturers, have found that the changed emphasis of the role of the Corporation has tended to bring some confusion into the industry. Already in debates within the industry it has been noted that the marketing structure of the industry is very fragmented and usually follows State borders. The effect is that, should there be a relaxation of the arrangements with, for instance, New Zealand-I know that the Minister and other honourable members are very much aware of this-our domestic market will surely suffer. If we are to exercise adequate control over the direction of the Australian dairy industry there is an urgent need for all groups responsible, such as State governments, the dairy marketing authorities and the ADC, to make their activities more convergent.

There appears to be a shortfall in interest in the future of the ADC by the Government, as I said. We on this side of the House request the Minister to take it upon himself to ensure that the ADC's future is clarified. Both the Minister and I, coming as we do from the leading State in dairy production, processing and manufacture, are aware of the disquiet that exists in the industry. I think you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be aware that under the rudderless, directionless and somewhat leaderless Liberal Government in Victoria, industry and business in that State are in the doldrums. We do not wish that state to extend to primary industry as well. I suggest that the Minister might address himself to the need for co-ordinating the industry. In that way he might assist not only the industry in Australia but also the economy of his State. I do not want to use the record of the Minister to bring pessimism to people in the industry, but I must say that in all honesty his record with respect to the Asia Dairy Industries scandal gives no one grounds for optimism. Nevertheless, we on this side of the House do not oppose the Bill. But we exhort the Government to take more positive steps to ensure an optimistic and sound future for the dairy industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill and the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill as they are associated measures? Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these four measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated earlier, the Opposition will not oppose the charges embodied in the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, the Eggs ( Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill, the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill and the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Bill. We just take our basic position: This is a rather penny pinching set of measures. For example, we just passed a measure to collect $7,000. It seemed hardly worth while. That amount is to be collected from the edible oils industry. The purpose of the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Bill is to impose charges from 1 July 1982 for the export inspection of eggs, the maximum rate of charge not to go above $22 for a thousand dozen eggs in shell and $16 a tonne for other egg products. The actual rate of charge will be specified in regulations. On the basis of current estimates of export production those charges will yield approximately $145,000 in a full year.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess this provides an opportunity for me to say a few things about the state of the egg industry. As all honourable members are aware, an inquiry into the egg industry has been conducted in Victoria. The former Minister for Primary Industry there, Mr Smith, made some suggestions about ending the existing arrangements and there was a lot of debate about that. Currently the New South Wales Government is conducting an inquiry into the egg industry. I think the inquiry is chaired by Mr Gilchrist. To my knowledge the Government either does not have a copy of the report of that inquiry or has not acted on it. But certainly changes are being mooted there.

What we can say is that again the egg industry is in surplus despite all the mechanisms of the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia Act and the various requirements in the States on the upper levels of the number of hens people can keep. In the latest year for which we have figures, 1980-81, we exported 1.6 million dozen eggs and we also exported 8.9 kilotonnes of egg pulp. Of course, the industry faces the constant problem of feed costs. There is nothing new in that. Ever since I have been in the egg industry-my father also was in the egg industry and I think that would go back to about 1935-there have been complaints about the price of feed going up. But really over the past year or so in both New South Wales and Victoria the price of feed has risen faster than the price of eggs has risen. That has led to a problem in, if I may put it in these terms, the egg to feed price ratio.

Also, despite relatively constant hen numbers, production rose by 4.6 per cent- from 188 million dozen to 196.7 million dozen-in that last year. Of course, there are widespread allegations in the industry that someone is not counting all the hens in a proper way. It is an industry with problems. Of course, with that increase in the number of eggs produced, the percentage of commercial production being sold on the export market rose from 8.7 per cent, I think the figure was, to 13.1 per cent in the last year. Although the export market takes about 13 1/2 per cent of the production it contributes only 7.2 per cent of the gross value of commercial production. What we are saying is that Australia is selling on the export market virtually at a loss. The major market for our pulp exports is still Japan. We sell our eggs in a range of countries, many of which are in the Pacific. World egg production has been rising over the past 10 years or so, so there is simply no way that the Australian industry can keep up this level of production. I am afraid to say that hen quotas will have to be cut severely in 1981-82 to try to cut back on the large exportable surplus.

This industry is one that will undergo some change. It is one that always has been undergoing change and adjusting to the economic conditions. All the regulations between the States and at the Commonwealth level do not seem to have prevented the very basic thing which was attempted to be avoided, that is, over production. Since the introduction of the quota scheme the State egg boards have attempted to reduce the percentage of commercial production being sold on the export market but this simply has not worked. The structure of the industry has been towards fewer and larger farms and the capacity to sell hen quotas has accelerated this process, though the trend now is being seen to have slowed down as the potential to achieve further size economies has been reduced.

In looking at the number of farms that have been shaken out of the industry it can be seen that the number has decreased by an incredible 77 per cent since 1968-69. This is a faster rate of contraction than occurred even in the dairy industry, where the number of farms has dropped enormously in the last 10 years. As I have said before and as I often say, the people who talk about the problems of reconstruction or adjustment in the manufacturing industry just do not seem to be aware of the fact that the rural industries have adjusted enormously. People have been shed from the rural industries and adjustments have taken place on farms with respect to productivity increases. I guess one could argue-the industry would argue; certainly the Federal Council of Poultry Farmers would argue-that this charge will act as a constraint on production. It would say, of course, that we need a surplus at this time, just as we do with the dairy industry, of something like 10 per cent to go on the export market to guarantee against shortfalls. In a depressed export market any charge levied on an industry will add pressure to that industry. For that reason, I think the point needs to be made that this Government is simply trying to get $145,000 out of an industry that again cannot really afford it.
Turning to the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, I guess there has not been much of a chance to discuss honey in this House before.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important commodity.

—That is right, it is an important commodity, as the honourable member for Paterson has said. He would know that there are 2,141 apiarists in Australia , that they have on average 511 beehives and that they produce 24,954 tonnes of honey worth a bit over $19m. It is an industry spread throughout Australia and of course it is a vital industry for the fruit industry for pollination purposes . There have been some complaints to me from the industry in recent times, but, as I said earlier in my comments tonight, the Country Party assures me that everything is all for the best and the best of all possible worlds. Perhaps I talk to the wrong people. For example, at present there is a proposal to introduce a levy on honey sold on the domestic market to subsidise export sales of honey. It is a very familiar tale.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the view of many apiarists who have written to me that the attempt to get a levy system introduced has come about through pressure from the large export oriented honey packers. I looked up some of the records of this industry. An editorial in the May 1981 issue of the Beekeeper was very critical of the activities of the Honey Corporation of Australia. As I said, it is a familiar tale. Since that time many of the shareholders of the Honey Corporation of Australia have received payment in full for their honey after the threat of legal action. Of course, what the editorial was referring to was the slump in prices. The Honey Corporation of Australia packs a high percentages of the honey sold in the eastern States of Australia and it is the opinion of apiarists who have written to me that by causing many of its shareholders to sell their honey to other smaller packers at reduced prices a lack of confidence has caused an artificial glut situation.

It is very important for the industry to know the quantity of honey that is produced in any season. The season ends in June. Then the industry would have a greater understanding of whether there is actually a glut. Yet for the first time, I am informed, the Australian Honey Board has released its annual report for the financial year ending June 1981 without figures for Australia-wide production. Perhaps the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) could inform us why this is so. I hope he will take some interest in the honey industry. The Federal Council of Australia Apiarists Association has appointed a five-man committee to look into the problems facing the industry in conjunction with five honey packer representatives. Again my information is that some of the apiarists were not all that happy with the people who were put on to that committee as representatives of the apiarists themselves.

This industry does export quite a bit. On the figures available to me it exported in 1980-81 about 8,373 tonnes or about 33.5 per cent of its production. So it is a large exporter in percentage terms. It earns something like $9.5m. The major buyers are the United Kingdom and West Germany. Australia, it should be known, is the eighth largest honey producing country in the world and we can be proud of that. The industry is very concerned about the inspection charge, again coming as it does at a time when the market is in its most depressed state for over a decade. At present the export scene is not bright, although it has stabilised somewhat recently. Two major factors account for the depressed market arrangements for our honey exports. They are, firstly, the upwards movement in the Australian dollar compared with sterling and the Deusche mark and, secondly, the flooding of the international market with cheap honey from China. The end result is that it is becoming unprofitable for many buyers to sell on the export market and they have begun to compete for access to the domestic market, causing depression of the price in that market. The industry is looking for means of price stabilisation at present. Although about $6.75 a tonne is not a great deal , it does come at a time when the industry is desperately trying to remain profitable and really needs to find new overseas markets. The Opposition does not oppose these Bills but, again, this measure is a penny pinching measure.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise on the adjournment the continuing problem which confronts Vietnam veterans because, for some two years now, they have sought unsuccessfully from both a series of Ministers for Veterans' Affairs and the Government, a judicial inquiry which would inquire into their exposure to the range of defoliants employed in Vietnam and deal with the problems of the physical, mental and other conditions which confront these veterans and their families as a result of such exposure. The range of problems which confront these servicemen and their families is, I believe, well known to honourable members of this Parliament and does not on this occasion require repetition by me.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Government has equally steadfastly refused such an inquiry despite the fact that the argument for it has received support from honourable members on both sides of the House, including indeed some Ministers. I have been at a loss to understand the Government's reluctance to have a judicial assessment made of those problems. Today a document was published in the Age newspaper which, according to that newspaper and my belief, emanated from within the defence structure. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: HQ 1 ATF NUI DAT 19 Mar 69
Distribution Below:
DEFOLIATION PROGRAMME 1 ATF NUI DAT APR-NOV 69
Introduction

1. During the wet season a defoliation programme will be carried out at Nui Dat to defoliate the perimeter wire, ammunition dump surrounds, radio aerial complexes and any other sites which may present a fire hazard during the following dry season.
Types of Defoliants
2. During this programme two types of defoliants will be used. The characteristics of these defoliants are as follows:

a. knock down type-This chemical affects that part of the vegetation which is above the ground causing it to dry off in approx 48 hours. It does not affect the root system of the plant consequently normal growth resumes in 7 days.

b. Sterilant Type-This chemical actually sterilises the soil surrounding the root system of the plant and denies growth to any type of vegetation for a period of up to two years. It requires something in the order of three inches of rain to soak this chemical into the soil and its effects are not seen for approx 5 weeks.
Unit Responsibilities
3. To ensure that the spraying programme is effective units must be prepared to carry out the following tasks:
a. During the current dry season, burn vegetation along the perimeter wire and keep this growth down to a minimum until such time as the perimeter can be sprayed.
b. During spraying operations in the unit, provide personnel to lift any mines and flares along the perimeter wire and to open up the wire to give access to all portions of the perimeter.
Personnel

4. The field regiment and each infantry battalion is to detach one soldier to HQ Coy 1 ATF for the period 1 Apr-30 Nov 69. Because of the toxicity of the chemicals used and the rigid safety precautions which must be observed, the soldiers provided must be intelligent types.

5. It is preferable that the personnel provided remain unchanged throughout the entire period of the programme. If this is not possible they must not be changed more frequently than once every three months.
Control
6. During the period of their detachment, the four soldiers provided will be under the direct control of 1 ATF Hyg Offr.
Nominations
7. Details of the personnel being provided are to be advised to A Branch 1 ATF by 28 Mar 69.
W. G. HOFFMAN
Maj DAAG

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr HOLDING

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The Defence Department has seen this document and to date its authenticity has not been denied. I believe that as a result of a Press statement which I made this afternoon the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has seen the document, but to date has chosen to make no comment upon it .

INTERJECT.PARA: In October 1969, the United States military forces suspended the use of agent orange and other defoliants in populated areas of Vietnam because of the toxicity of such chemicals and the problems they became aware of regarding the exposue to them of civilian populations. However, the then Australian Government continued to use highly dangerous chemicals until 1971. That is borne out by the statements which are contained in the document that I have had incorporated.

During the whole of that period, the present Prime Minister was the Minister for Defence. I refer the House to his statement in this place on 9 March 1971. The then Minister for Defence, the present Prime Minister, told the House that the conduct of Australian military operations in Vietnam was ultimately his decision, his responsibility. He dealt at some length and in some detail with the way in which the relationship between the military forces in Vietnam and himself as Minister for Defence operated. There can be no question that if, in fact, Australian military forces were being exposed to toxic defoliants either on the Prime Minister's own statement he knew or-and this is the only presumption the House can draw-he ought to have known.

Having regard to the answers that the Prime Minister has furnished on this matter to the Parliament over two years, I do not believe that he can any longer remain silent as to the extent of his knowledge and approval of the use of these toxic chemicals. As I said at the outset, I for one have been at a loss to understand the Government's inaction, despite the support given by honourable members on both sides and also some Ministers, who have told members of the Vietnam Veterans' Association that they believe their problems ought to be subject to a judicial inquiry, which they would support. At this stage I can only reach the conclusion that the real reason the Government is refusing these men and their families a judicial inquiry is that it is more concerned to protect the reputation of the Prime Minister, when he was Minister for Defence, concerning his responsibility in these matters, than it is to see justice done to the Vietnam veterans and their families. The documents that have now been made public require a full explanation from the Prime Minister as to his responsibility. I call upon him to make such a statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Residents of the Upper Hunter region are greatly concerned at the curtailment of the services of the Australian Broadcasting Commission broadcasting station 2UH, which is to take effect tomorrow, 26 February.

SPEECH.PARA: The Upper Hunter region is one of the fastest growing areas in Australia, in particular because of the expansion of coal mining and large associated industries, and it is very disappointing indeed that this action is contemplated . At this time, irrespective of economic conditions, there should not be an emasculation of ABC services to this area. The 2UH breakfast program has been in operation for many years and is heard by a wide circle of listeners over a huge area. A separate program for 2UH has been in operation for at least six years. It was further expanded in April 1981 to come into line with the other three stations around Australia.

The afternoon program on 2UH began as an experiment in May 1981. It has received a very enthusiastic and favourable reaction because ABC Sydney was providing a program for 2UH only. It must be remembered that a Sydney program which comes into a rich agricultural and mining area is of little consequence to listeners. It seemed more sensible to provide an interesting program from 2UH Newcastle. In addition, the important Rural Department wished market reports to be broadcast in the evening, thus bringing the station in line with three other radio stations.

Under the proposed reduction Station 2UH is to lose seven hours of local content. This is of importance to country people. Station 2UH market reports will not be read in the evening. The Rural Officer will still present rural material by fading it in and out of the Radio 1 program from Sydney. Market reports will be broadcast a day late, on the following morning. What is the use of market reports that are a day late? Farmers, graziers and country producers want market reports when the markets are being held, not a day late.

Station 2UH has a strength of one kilowatt, but it is interesting to note that Tennant Creek in the Northern Territory and Fingal in Tasmania also have a strength of one kilowatt. It is important to note that the vast majority of Radio 3 areas have a strength of at least 10 kilowatts and in most cases greater capacity.

To summarise, the morning program was not an experiment. The afternoon program was initially but, because Sydney ABC was providing a service for 2UH only and, because of the desire to broadcast market reports, it was agreed that Station 2UH should do its own programs.

This vastly important region is badly served by having a one kilowatt strength station. The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) has been asked to intervene to see that this great developing area receives the 2UH broadcasts as was formerly the situation. The service in no way should be curtailed to the detriment of the people in the Hunter Valley. This is an important matter. The people in the Valley regard it as important because the relaying of market information is vital to the carrying on of the primary industries in the area. The people want to know what their sheep, cattle, pigs and grain are bringing because it is important in regard to supplying the local markets. I ask that the Minister give immediate attention to this matter to give a service which is necessary to this progressive and developing area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I spoke about the disastrous effects of ad hoc government decisions on the private sector in Canberra. The recently announced freeze on Government expenditure is causing serious concern amongst local business and industry leaders. It is not good enough for the Government to freeze Commissioner for Housing loan funds one day and then lift the freeze several days later. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), in his reply to my speech last week, urged us all to believe that the situation is not so terrible now that the funds have been unfrozen.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the Minister has overlooked the major point of my speech which was to high-light the instability in the Canberra economy generated by the Government's stop-start policies. No business can operate efficiently in an unpredictable commercial environment and I am very disappointed that the Minister is not able to grasp this point and put Canberra's case in Cabinet more effectively. Tonight I would like to discuss some of the wide-ranging effects that the cutbacks will have in Canberra. Honourable members will be aware that as there is no state or local level of government in Canberra, Cabinet's sudden decision to throw out its Budget plan for the year has had an immediate effect on schools, hospitals, welfare services, housing and so forth. In other words, every time there is a cutback in Federal Government expenditure, Canberra is the area that feels it the most. Local contractors and business people have, overnight, been deprived of their livelihoods. I read from one of the letters I have received this week. It states:
Due to the recent period of low activity in the ACT the sole remaining source of work for my firm was commissions from the Department of Housing and Construction.
He goes on to explain that these had been cut and writes:

The effect of the cutbacks was to instantly cut off the source of income to my firm, since all existing commissions were at or nearing completion. Since this is a small local firm, it cannot now guarantee to pay staff beyond the end of this month, and will almost certainly have to lay off staff, including myself.

With almost all construction projects in Canberra in recent years being sent by the NCDC to interstate consultants and contractors, this instant cutting off to the small remaining amount of work for local firms has had a drastic effect at a time when the Government is publicising its desire to 'stimulate private enterprise in Canberra'.
I think those were the words of the Minister for the Capital Territory. He goes on:

The effects of continual blows to the local economy on private enterprise workers and their families, has received no publicity. I feel that the perpetrators of these petty economies, which can only cost more money in the long term, should be made aware of the effect they are having on ordinary people outside their ivory towers.

I repeat, that is a letter from a local businessman, from a person such as Government members are supposed to be supporting. In Canberra we have a situation where we have a large number of small businesses. Every day more of them are going under and the reason for that is that they want a stable economy in which to plan. They have come to terms with the fact that there will not be big growth in Canberra. But what they want to know is where they will be in five years' time. They want to plan and they want that plan adhered to. They do not want a continuation of the stop-start policies that we have seen in Canberra over the last six years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to do something unusual in the parliamentary sense because although honourable members are aware that frequently there are many matters and issues that bring us together, so often the forms of the House do not allow those who read Hansard or those who listen in to know that there are matters and issues that sometimes bring us together. Frequently we do not address ourselves to them. The first of the two matters I would like to mention relates to the unfortunate death of Emeritus Professor W. E. H. Stanner last year. Bill Stanner was well known to members of this House, because of his involvement in our committee system and because of his dedicated and life-long interest in the Aboriginal people of Australia. I know the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) was interested enough to join me in mentioning Bill Stanner because of his work, particularly with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. A number of eulogies have been written about Bill Stanner. Dr H. C. Coombs wrote about him in the journal of the Australian National University. He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Bill Stanner, in character as in career, was a man of many facets. To read even the shorthand of the Who's Who record of his life is to range across the world and through the major events and issues of this century. And to read the record of his Curriculum Vitae or the introduction to the book of essays written in his honour by his professional colleagues, is to become aware of the powerful impact of a creative imagination on the anthropological discipline to which so much of his life was devoted and of his involvement in the institutions and policies which developed and used its ideas.
The Canberra Times, I think more adequately than I could, reviewed his outstanding career. It stated:
From 1967 to 1977 he was a member of the small but very influential Council for Aboriginal Affairs, which advised a succession of Prime Ministers, from Mr Holt to Mr Fraser.
His ABC Boyer lectures in 1971 reached and touched many Australians because he wrote and spoke so beautifully.
I am sure that those who heard those lectures could not have failed to have been impressed. The article continues:
In 1979 he published 'White Man Got No Dreaming' . . . a collection of his best writing.

I knew him particularly when I became a member of this Parliament in 1973 because, strange as it may seem, I was co-opted, into what seems now to be a very natural interest, that of Aboriginal affairs. I joined the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. During that time when I served with Gordon Bryant and Bill Wentworth, names familiar to all honourable members for their interest in Aboriginal Affairs, Bill Stanner was the specialist adviser to the Committee between 1974 and 1975. I remember going around with him particularly in northern New South Wales. He was able to explain so much of what I was to see and to help me appreciate so much of the hardship that I think some honourable members readily know and understand. Professor Stanner was particularly a consultant to the Land Commissioner in the Northern Territory, Mr Justice Toohey, from 1977 to 1979. One could go on but it is clear that his career has been an outstanding one.

The other matter that I want to mention briefly is the role of the Parliamentary Amnesty Group in this parliament. The group had its annual meeting the other evening and some 51 members of Parliament have joined or rejoined to this time. I am pleased to mention to honourable members that the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) is now the Chairman of the group and, succeeding me as Secretary of the group, is the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). This is a group that has performed a great deal of outstanding work in the Parliament over a long period. I am pleased that it will be in good hands to continue its work during the life of this Parliament. We had the opportunity the other evening to hear from Professor Vinh. I am sure that honourable members could not read a more elucidating story of a man's life in terms of challenge from the dictators of both the right and the left.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not often agree 100 per cent with the comments of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) but on this occasion I do. SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) in his Press statement yesterday on funding of the Community Youth Support Scheme projects for the period 1 March to 30 June 1982 stated:
The great majority of projects will receive a substantial increase in funds of 15 per cent to cover increased costs and to help pay travel costs of disadvantaged CYSS participants.

It is difficult to imagine other than disadvantaged participants, but I leave in his qualification. This would put an end to what he termed 'Opposition scaremongering'. This latter epithet, no doubt, is his erudite criticism of our concern that a government which has already attempted to eliminate CYSS once might try it again. This 15 per cent-it is only 15 per cent in some projects; a maximum amount-is to cover fares and increased costs. Some projects which will be continued will receive no increases. As with all government statements it is always wise to separate rhetoric from actual experience; so I shall draw the attention of the House to the effect of this decision on two of the three projects in my electorate.

I take first the Victoria Park CYSS which, despite the fact that its number of participants is about the State average, receives the lowest funding in Western Australia. As honourable members would be aware, under the old funding scheme the travel fund was separated from the rest of the individual project budget. It is now included within it. On this basis, the Victoria Park CYSS spends about $ 760 weekly, of which $80 is spent on fares. Therefore, the incorporation of the fare component automatically requires a 10 per cent increase simply to stand still. So two-thirds of the increase disappears immediately.

Then it must be understood that the 15 per cent increase is calculated against a 42 week period, much of which was a period of crisis. Particularly at the latter end of the period when the Government threatened closure, usage fell in some areas quite dramatically. Throughout the period the financing of the projects relied heavily on project officers not taking pay rises and cutbacks in funds spent on CYSS activities. It would take much more than 5 per cent to restore the real funding of previous years. Thus, assuming the Victoria Park CYSS is to restore itself to its past level of operation, it requires at least a 15 per cent increase, I would say. Assuming that it gets that, then it will still find itself short. There has recently been a 10 per cent increase in bus fares. The Victoria Park project officers are the lowest paid of any project officers in Western Australia. The wages bill should go up by about $34 a week, which would mean an additional 5 per cent requirement on that alone. Effectively , a 15 per cent increase in grants to the Victoria Park CYSS would leave it behind its operating capabilities of last year.

I turn briefly to the Swan CYSS project to point out that 15 per cent of its previous $1,000 a week expenditure went on participants' travel. So assuming it receives the maximum amount, then it too will stand still in terms of receipts from the Government. When I asked the Minister last year whether he could give some consideration to adjusting the travel allowance, and I refer to question on notice No. 3080, he replied:
Should it emerge that the rate of allowance is inadequate for its purpose the Government will give consideration to adjusting the rate.

The CYSS projects in my area surveyed their participants to assess the adequacy of the then $6 a week for participants allowance. Of those visiting the projects daily, over one-third spent more than the $6 allowance simply as travel from their homes to the project. If they went out on visits for voluntary work, work experience and activities associated with CYSS, and the new guidelines seek greater emphasis on these activities, the weekly cost often exceeded $10.

There are particular difficulties in outer metropolitan CYSS projects such as the Swan CYSS project. But experience with such inadequacies is widespread. But on all my inquiries I have been informed, as I have said, that the granting of the $6 travel allowance will be up to the CYSS committees. It will not be automatic. If this is not the case in Western Australia I will be happy to be corrected. If I am right, then CYSS becomes unique because it will be the only one of the Government's schemes where the allowance, inadequate as it is, does not apply.

What all this means is that the 15 per cent increase is no increase. Given that it is not general and is based on expenditures in a period of unprecedented stringency in CYSS expenditures, most projects will experience cutbacks. That is not a promising start for the new guidelines, nor is it likely to lay the ghost of Opposition scaremongering haunting the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard recently of a great deal of incompetence in the administration of New South Wales. Public knowledge about that is growing rapidly. I will leave the members of the public to make their own decisions. I raise one matter that has become a glaring example of incompetence hurting a lot of young people. It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. I do not want to refer only to that. I want to refer first of all not only to incompetence but also to a growing fetish about secrecy to protect that incompetence.

SPEECH.PARA: I was reminded yesterday in a news release that the State Government of New South Wales, which is fearful about the problems in the power industry at the present time because of the backlash from the people, apparently decided that the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales should not be given permission to visit certain power stations in order to study the problems. For that reason I take it that that Leader of the Opposition had to visit Victoria yesterday to find out a few simple facts about the operation of power stations.

The thing that concerned me this morning was a report of secrecy or attempted secrecy relating to the Board of Senior School Studies which has recently conducted the marking of papers for the New South Wales Higher School Certificate, probably the most important examination for young people, more important in many ways than any examinations at universities, which in many cases can be taken again or deferred.

I reiterate that the Higher School Certificate is a tremendously important examination. When we find that some computer somewhere in the system has decided to spit out marks that are patently very way out; when we find that those marks are transmitted to people who then make decisions; and then when we find that some four or six weeks later some hundreds of young people have made decisions and commitments, many of which are irreversible, and are based on those incorrect computer marks, we just wonder whether we cannot get a little more competence somewhere to program computers or whatever is required so that those young people are not hurt.

I understand from the newspaper report that the members of the Board of Senior School Studies were told not to talk to the media about this mistake. It was a gross error. I always believe that if people make mistakes they ought to admit them, especially in the bureaucracy because the bureaucracy has no particular reason to do otherwise. It is tremendously important in a democracy for people to know what has happened. I suppose that means that perhaps some people have to take the rap sometimes. It is tremendously important to avoid secrecy in these matters.

I wonder what happened to many of those children who have been messed up in the marking of a particular paper. I believe it was the three unit English paper. I just wonder how many other papers have been messed up. We just do not know, do we? If it has happened in this case there is a statistical possibility that it happened in others. I despair that whatever system has been adopted in New South Wales for the marking of these examinations might be wrong. There may be some system that is not working. That can affect the whole future of many young people. It is just not good enough.

I know that in my own electorate of Eden-Monaro, where there are some 14 or 15 high schools, there are quite a number of people who sat for that three unit English paper. Over and above that, of course, there are thousands of children who sat for other papers. They must be sitting at home tonight wondering whether they really did get better marks. That sort of confusion is the wrong start in the lives of young people who are about to go out into tertiary education or into the work force. The tampering with young people's futures by incompetent people who, I suppose, will fall back on some excuse that is just not justified. I wonder whether next year the children will be able to have faith in the system and whether teachers will be able to say to the children: 'Work hard; you will be judged on your merits'. Certainly for many people in this case their merits were not judged and they have made their decisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Nugan Hand Bank, now in liquidation and the subject of various disturbing allegations, ever make an application under the Government's foreign investment guidelines to the Foreign Investment Review Board.
(2) If so, when was the application made, what was the nature of it and what action did the Board take.

(3) Was there ever any other communication, written or oral, between the Nugan Hand Bank and the Board or its secretariat in his Department; if so, when did that communication occur, what was the nature of it and what action did these authorities take.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The supplementary answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It has been brought to my attention that the answer I provided on 26 March 1981 to Question 456 of 26 February 1981 by Mr Willis, the honourable member for Gellibrand, as to whether the Nugan Hand Bank had had any dealings with the Foreign Investment Review Board or the Foreign Investment Division of the Treasury was not complete.

As indicated in my response, there were no foreign investment cases in respect of which the Nugan Hand Bank was a party and there was no indexed record of communication between the Nugan Hand group and the Foreign Investment Review Board or the Foreign Investment Division in the Department. It has now come to light that there was an application in 1976 involving Nugan Hand acting as an intermediary on behalf of a foreign client. As it was the practice at the time to enter in the index recording such applications only the names of principal parties concerned, there was no reference in it to Nugan Hand.

The proposal involved an application in November 1976 by Nugan Hand on behalf of a Hong Kong company seeking approval to acquire a shelf company in Australia as a corporate vehicle to invest funds with Nugan Hand. The proposal was examined in consultation with relevant Government authorities and approved by the Government in November 1976. Subsequently exchange control approval was given for a deposit of $150 000.

All relevant information known to my Department, the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Reserve Bank concerning the shelf company and its subsequent financial transactions has been supplied to the Commonwealth-State Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking which is investigating the Nugan Hand matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do section 8 of the Sales Tax Procedures Act and section 46 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act impose additional tax by way of penalty where a taxpayer endeavours to avoid payment of sales tax.
(2) If so, is the penalty now equal to 100 per cent increase on the amount of sales tax avoided rather than 10 per cent as formerly provided.
(3) On what date will these proposed changes take effect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 8 of the Sales Tax Procedure Act 1934 and Section 46 of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930 impose additional tax on a taxpayer in certain circumstances. Where a person fails or neglects to furnish any return or information required to be furnished, the additional tax is at the rate of 10 per cent per annum of the tax involved calculated for the period of the person's failure to furnish the return or information. Additional tax at the maximum rate of 200 per cent of the tax underpaid is imposed by section 8 in respect of certain other omissions, for example, failure to include taxable sales in a return or showing taxable sales in a return at an incorrect rate. The Commissioner of Taxation has the power to remit fully or in part the additional tax imposed by these sections if he considers the circumstances of a particular case warrants it.

(2) The proposals to amend the sales tax machinery and liability provisions announced on 20 August 1981 include a proposal (proposal 8) to bring the sales tax law on additional tax into line with the current income tax law. To this end , I indicated that it was the Government's intention to bring forward amendments which would, among other changes, change the rate of 10 per cent per annum to a flat rate of 100 per cent. The Commissioner's power of remission would remain. The circumstances in which the maximum rate of 200 per cent applies would be unchanged.

(3) The proposed amendments are scheduled for introduction into the Parliament during the Autumn Sittings and, insofar as proposal 8 is concerned, it is intended that the changes will take effect upon the amendments becoming law.

(2) What was the total cost to revenue of the tax deduction in 1980-81.
(3) What is the estimated cost to revenue of the tax deduction in 1981-82.

(4) Which occupational groups, categorised by industry, have utilised the provision in terms of the number of taxpayers with (a) income only from (i) salary and wages and (ii) salary and wages with net property income less than $ 400, (b) income only from (i) property or (ii) salary and wages with net income from property of $400 or more and (c) net income at loss from business.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, as 1980-81 income year returns will be assessed mainly during the current financial year the available information is incomplete. In the period up to 6 November 1981 the number of income tax returns in which deductions had been allowed for superannuation paid by self-employed individuals and unsupported employees was 38,358. This number represents about 0.9 per cent of taxable and non-taxable returns of individuals assessed during that period. It should be noted that assessments of taxpayers subject to provisional tax began being processed early in November 1981. This means that the available figures do not extend in any significant way to the class of taxpayer most likely to claim deductions under the new provisions. The returns processed to date that include claims for these deductions relate mainly to unsupported employees.

(2) and (3) The cost to income tax revenue in 1980-81 had been estimated at about $9m and the full-year cost at $100m. The cost of deductions allowed to date in respect of 1980-81 income year assessments is about $5.5m, but the total cost for the 1980-81 income year cannot be estimated precisely at this stage.

(4) A dissection of the numbers in (1) by industry is not available. However, 36,264 of the claims related to taxpayers with no provisional tax debit or credit, that is, mainly salary and wage earners.
