QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he in his statement of 20 October 1981, stipulate that the manufacture of the first of Australia's F/A-18 aircraft should not precede a specified number of aircraft in the United States program unless it was decided otherwise (Hansard, 20 October 1981, page 2199).
(2) If so, what is the specified number to which he refers.
(3) How long is it envisaged that the aircraft should have United States squadron experience before Australia proceeds with the purchase.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) 200 (two hundred).

(3) The F/A-18 entered squadron service in the United States in February 1981, when the First United States Navy Squadron, UFA125, received the first of its F/ A-18 aircraft. This means that the F/A-18 will have seen some two years of United States squadron experience before the main production contract for the first of our aircraft is let.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he, in his statement of 20 October 1981, state that his Department had yet to conclude discussions with the United States departments on a number of matters that relate to the F/A-18 aircraft (Hansard, 20 October 1981, page 2199) .
(2) If so, will he identify these matters and explain the reasons why each is the subject of further discussion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No. The matters which were unresolved at the time of the statement, related to particular purchase terms and conditions, were not factors in reaching the decision to select the F/A-18, and have now been largely resolved. To expose the details of the discussions which are continuing and which are fully expected to be satisfactorily concluded, could prejudice their final outcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he confirm that structural fatigue testing for the second 10 years of life of the F/A-18 has not yet been completed.
(2) If so, when is it expected that the tests will be completed.

(3) What conditions have been written into the contract to safeguard Australia from (a) additional costs caused by necessary modifications or (b) from the inability of the aircraft to meet successfully the test requirement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) All fatigue testing is planned to be complete by about the end of 1984.

(3) Design changes approved by the USN to meet the fatigue test requirements defined in the F/A-18 development specification will be incorporated in all Australian aircraft, either during production or by retrospective modification, at no increase to the established price.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he confirm that the United States of America Department of Defense had not given approval for the clearance of additional weapons for the air-to- surface attack role of the F/A18.
(2) What weapons for air-to-surface attack are envisaged to meet the requirements of (a) the United States Navy and (b) the R.A.A.F.
(3) Are the air-to-surface weapons required by the R.A.A.F. included in the estimates of costs given by him; if not, what is the estimated additional cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The United States Department of Defense has given approval for the work necessary to clear additional weapon systems for the air-to-surface attack role of the F/A18. That work is proceeding. It is expected to be completed during 1982. Present plans are for the United States Defense Systems Acquisition Review Council to review the results of the work, and clear the F/A18 for full production for the attack role by October 1982.
(2) The U.S.N. specifications for the F/A18 require the manufacturer, McDonnell Douglas, to qualify in flight, various configurations of air-to-surface weapon systems including:

(a) Air-to-Surface Missiles. Maverick missiles and HARM anti-radiation missiles . Additionally, the U.S.N. has plans to fit the F/A18 with a Harpoon anti- shipping missile capability. The aircraft is expected to be qualified with this capability by the time Australian aircraft are delivered.
(b) Guided Bombs.
(c) General Purpose Bombs.
(d) Cluster Bombs.
(e) Unguided Rockets.
These would cover the present R.A.A.F. requirements. Clearance of additional weapon systems to meet U.S.N. and/or R.A.A.F. requirements will be possible as requirements emerge.

(3) The air-to-surface munitions (missiles and bombs) required by the R.A.A.F. for use with the F/A18 will, to a large extent be common with requirements for other weapons systems in the Australian Service inventory. Stocks of air-to- surface munitions for the F/A18 will be added to existing stocks as necessary through separate arrangements later, when quantities are determined. Costs have yet to be established. Such purchases will be approved separately.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he inform the House on 7 April 1978 that the tactical fighter force aircraft would commence entry into service about 1983 and a first squadron of the new aircraft would become operational by about 1985 (Hansard, 7 April 1978, page 1225).
(2) Under the revised arrangements announced by him on 20 October 1981, when will the F/A18 commence entry into service and when will the first squadron of the new aircraft become operational.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 7 April 1978 I stated 'it is contemplated that aircraft would commence entry into service about 1983 and a first squadron of new aircraft would become operational by about 1985'. On 4 December 1980 I announced a year's deferment in the New Tactical Fighter selection for reasons outlined in detail in my statement of that date.

(2) On present planning the R.A.A.F. can look forward to receiving its first F/ A18 before the end of 1984. The first two aircraft will be produced in the United States and used initially for training air and ground crews and for testing of Australian modifications. The first aircraft assembled in Australia is planned for delivery in the second quarter of 1985. The first unit formed will be the Operational Conversion Unit (OCU) at Williamtown. When the OCU is up to strength, the first operational squadron will be formed. On current plans this will be about mid-1986 and the squadron will receive its full complement of aircraft over a period of about 12 months. This squadron will be declared operational some months after the receipt of its last aircraft.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Chief of Air Force Materiel state on 23 May 1978 that in the selection of the tactical fighter force, priority should be given to the air-to- air role rather than the air-to-surface role.
(2) If so, when and for what reasons, was the emphasis in selecting an aircraft changed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In mid 1978 the then Chief of Air Force Materiel made public statements explaining 'the reasons for the decision that project development of the Tactical Fighter Force should proceed with emphasis on a new fighter with primary capabilities in the air-to-air role'.

In the same statement, he also said 'it would be ideal if the TFF comprises aircraft fully competent in both roles. However, the nature of the roles is such that it is not yet technologically possible to achieve full specialisation in both roles in one aircraft. Modern aircraft designed for the air-to-air role, however, generally have an inherently good capability or potential for the air- to-surface role.' He also stated 'if an order of priority is to be established between the two TFF roles, less strategic risk would attend primacy being given to the air-to-air capability.

(2) In the early stages of the definition of the TFF project, it was not by any means apparent that a full multi-role aircraft would be available. In those circumstances, the primary requirement for an air-to-air fighter had been established, largely because an aircraft developed for that role could be more readily adapted for other roles.

A two type solution was considered a possibility at that stage, but as the evaluation process progressed and more became known about the support, cost and manpower penalties of such an approach, it became readily apparent that a two- type solution to Australian requirements within available resources would not have been a practical proposition.

Attainment of air superiority is generally regarded as a necessary condition for being able to undertake other tasks in the air. Therefore, a tactical fighter's proficiency in the air-to-air role has a fundamental importance. Consequently, the contenders on the Australian short list were narrowed down to aircraft that (as an essential elegibility criterion) could adequately satisfy these fundamental requirements. However, the service life of the New Tactical Fighter will be long, 20 to 25 years, and there is no certain knowledge of what emerging threats the TFF could be called upon to deter or combat over that timeframe. Accordingly, having short-listed a selection of aircraft that satisfied fundamental requirements, and having rejected beforehand the option of a two-type solution, the final evaluation was done on the basis of according equal emphasis to the air-to-air and air-to-surface roles.

The FA18 will provide a high and enduring level of competence in both the air- to-air and air-to-surface roles, and was selected on the basis that it represented the best investment of the large sums that would have been required regardless of which option was chosen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the White Paper on Defence issued in November 1976 point out that it was no longer practicable for pilots to be operationally efficient in the whole range of skills required in air-to-air and air-to-surface roles.
(2) When, and for what reasons, did the Government accept that it was practicable for pilots to be operationally efficient in both roles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1976 Defence White Paper stated that 'Tactical fighters and their associated weapons have been developed to such a stage of diversity that it is probably no longer practicable for pilots to be operationally efficient in the whole range of skills required in air-to-air and air-to-surface roles'. This statement was made before the overseas evaluation teams of 1979, 1980 and 1981 had gained an intimate knowledge of the capabilities of the contender aircraft.

(2) The human factors interface between man and machine was a subject that received close attention in the final evaluations. Advances in fighter aircraft technology and capabilities have been such that it is widely suggested that the capability of the human operator has become the limiting factor in overall weapons system capability. The evaluation teams noted the thousands of hours of simulator development work that had been conducted during the early design phase of the F/A-18. They concluded that the F/A-18 represents the most efficient interface between man and machine yet developed in a fighter aircraft and that the F/A-18 represents a quantum advancement in the number of complex operational tasks that a single pilot will be able to undertake efficiently under combat conditions. However, it will not be until more operational experience is gained on the aircraft that the RAAF will decide what proficiency levels pilots will be capable of maintaining in each role.

RAAF policy is to give equal emphasis to the air-to-air roles and air-to- surface roles in peace-time training in recognition of the fact that there is no certain knowledge of the contingent situations the TFF might in future be called upon to combat or deter. In the Mirage force each squadron denotes 50 per cent of its training time to each role; however, the policy could equally as well be satisfied by specialising to certain degrees in different squadrons whilst maintaining an equal emphasis across the total force. The degree of specialisation within different squadrons, if any, is a matter for future decision. The Tactical Fighter Force will continue, however, to maintain proficiency in both roles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Chief of Air Force Materiel on 23 May 1978 state that the first purchase of the tactical fighter force would be of the order of 25 to 30 aircraft.
(2) When, and for what reason, did the Government decide to purchase 75 aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1978, Department of Defence financial programming made allowance for an initial Phase 1 acquisition of 25 new tactical fighter aircraft for the air-to- air role. Planning for the subsequent phases for the remaining 50 aircraft was dependent on decisions to be made on the best means of satisfying the air-to- surface role requirements of the TFF. Whilst plans to acquire the full 75 aircraft were not formally endorsed at that stage, in my statement to the House on 7 April 1978 I noted that the Government believed that 'the retention of a three squadron structure together with an operational conversion unit is a desirable planning objective for the Defence Force'.

(2) On 19 February 1980, in the context of his statement 'Afghanistan: Australia's Assessment and Response', the Prime Minister announced that 'we will enter into a commitment later this year for 75 new tactical fighter aircraft'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the 1976 White Paper on Defence indicate that the case for the acquisition of multi-role or specialised aircraft or a combination of both was under investigation.
(2) When, and for what reason, was the decision made in favour of a multi-role aircraft rather than a mix of aircraft types or variants to air-to-air and air- to-surface roles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) See answer to Question No. 3538.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What parts of the F/A-18 aircraft, its engines and its electronic and mechanical systems will be manufactured in Australia.
(2) What will be the value of direct work carried out by Australian industry on the aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some 76 specific tasks have been designated to be accomplished by Australian industry in the manufacture of the F/A-18 aircraft for the RAAF. They include:
(a) aircraft final assembly and test:
(b) engine final assembly and test;
(c) radar system integration and test;
(d) manufacture of representative airframe items such as flaps, an aft fuselage segment, engine access doors;
(e) manufacture of representative engine components such as blades, housings and seals;

(f) manufacture and assembly of representative electronics items such as the radar data processor, flight control computer, head-up display, stores management set, hybrid micro-circuits and printed circuit boards;
(g) manufacture and assembly of representative mechanical items such as actuators, gearboxes, undercarriage, wheels, brakes and underwing pylons;

(h) design, development and manufacture of some items of Automatic Test Equipment such as the Avionic Fault Tree Analyzer, Integrated Avionic System Support Facility, and Intermediate Level Avionic Support System.
Other tasks of technological value, but not necessarily F/A-18 items, are included in the Australian industry program flowing from the F/A-18 acquisition.

(2) The direct work carried out by Australian industry on the RAAF F/A-18 aircraft is estimated to amount to approximately $190 million at August 1981 prices. Additional offset work for export is estimated to amount to approximately $370 million at August 1981 prices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he confirm that there are compensation provisions if the United States of America contractors fail to honour their commitments under the Australian Industry Participation Program associated with the purchase of the FA18.
(2) If so, will he provide details of the compensation provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Compensation provisions provide for:
(a) reimbursement of establishment costs if the United States contractors default in the placement of agreed work on RAAF aircraft; and
(b) payment of liquidated damages against a prescribed formula if the United States contractors default in the placement of agreed amounts of offset work for export in agreed timescales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that a report entitled Report of the Interdepartmental Committee on Economic Strategy was completed in 1980 following detailed inquires by that Committee.

(2) Was the membership of that Committee drawn from the Reserve Bank, and the Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury, Finance, Industry and Commerce, National Development and Energy and Trade and Resources.

(3) Did this report plead for an appropriately structured resource rent tax and assert that taxation arrangements for the mining industry already provide substantial incentives and that there is a case for minimising further concessions.
(4) What action has been taken on the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes.

(3) The report, which I tabled in the parliament on 27 Augjust 1980 after it had been made public without authority by the Leader of the Opposition the previous day, did not 'plead for' a resource rent tax. It said:

'Taxation and royalty arrangements are an important determinant of how Australians share in the gains. Taxation arrangements for the mining industry already provide substantial incentives, and there is a case for minimising further concessions. With the expansion of potentially very profitable resource projects, pressures could well arise for reconsideration of an appropriately structured resource rent tax.'

(4) The document was a report on the medium term outlook, which the Government considered when taking decisions on economic policy in 1980. The 1981-82 Budget contained some measures affecting taxation arrangements for mining enterprises.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) It is a fact that according to figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the balance of trade deficit for the month of September 1981 was $ 283 million, which represented an increase of $113 million over the figure for August 1981.
(2) Is the trade deficit for September 1981 greater than the total trade deficit of $259 million for 1980-81.
(3) Will Australia have to export approximately 30 per cent more than it can import over the following months in order to meet import freight costs, insurance costs and debt servicing.
(4) Is the September quarter trade deficit approximately $2 billion if the cost of freight, insurance and debt servicing (that is, invisibles) is added to the Bureau of Statistics figure.
(5) If this figure is extrapolated over the full financial year, by how much is the current trade deficit in excess of the original budget projection.
(6) What are the reasons for the growing trade deficit.
(7) What action does the Government propose to take to meet this balance of payments crisis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The trade deficit for the month of September 1981 was $238 million, which represented an increase of $170 million on the estimated deficit for August 1981 .
(2) No. The trade deficit for 1980-81 is presently estimated at $339 million.

(3) Australia usually experiences a deficit on the current account of its balance of payments (that is, the net outcome of all trade and 'invisible' transactions). This is the way in which the supplementation of Australia's domestic savings by foreign savings is translated into additional real goods and services required to enhance our rate of economic development. It has rarely been the case that exports receipts have matched the sum of imports and the deficit on net invisibles, nor is that a desirable goal in itself in Australia's case.
(4) Yes, as a matter of arithmetic. However, see answer to part (3).

(5) Because of seasonal variations, it would be unwise to extrapolate figures for a single quarter over the financial year as a whole. However, the trade and current account deficits in 1981-82 seem likely at this stage to be somewhat larger than expected at Budget time.

(6) The main reasons for the trade deficit in the recent September quarter appear to be the strength of domestic demand in Australia-and in particular the continuing strength of business fixed investment in Australia-relative to that in our main export markets (which has resulted in imports increasing faster than exports); industrial disputes and drought-related supply shortages in Australia which have reduced shipments of some export commodities; and the appreciation of the Australian dollar during 1980-81, which has facilitated the growth of imports and, in the process, provided a useful dampening of inflationary pressures within the Australian economy.

(7) There is no balance of payments crisis. The Government will continue to conduct its economic policies in such a way as to foster its economic objectives , including the pursuit of domestic and external balance.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Work Value Equivalent of the Australian Housewife

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.
